samples.title: Numitor
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor () of Alba Longa, was the maternal grandfather of Rome's founder and first king, Romulus, and his twin brother Remus.  He was the son of Procas, descendant of Aeneas the Trojan, and father of the twins' mother, Rhea Silvia, and Lausus.

In 794 BC Procas died and was meant to be succeeded by Numitor. Instead he was overthrown and removed from the kingdom by his brother, Amulius, who had no respect for his father's will or his brother's seniority. Amulius also murdered Numitor's sons, in an effort to remove power from his brother for himself.

Rhea Silvia was made a Vestal Virgin by Amulius rendering her unable to have children on pain of death; however, according to myth she was forcibly impregnated by the god Mars. Romulus and Remus overthrew Amulius and reinstated Numitor as king in 752 B.C .

Family tree

See also
Aeneid
The Golden Bough (mythology)

Notes

References

Kings of Alba Longa

Characters in Book VI of the Aeneid

easy_general.text:
In Roman mythology, King Numitor was an important figure in the story of Rome's founding. He was the son of Procas, who was a descendant of Aeneas, a famous hero from the Trojan War. King Numitor was the father of Rhea Silvia, the mother of Romulus and Remus, and Lausus.

In 794 BC, Procas passed away, and King Numitor was supposed to succeed him as king. However, his brother Amulius took over and killed King Numitor and his sons because he wanted to keep power for himself.

Amulius made Rhea Silvia a Vestal Virgin, which means she was not allowed to have children. But according to the myth, she was made pregnant by the god Mars. Later, Romulus and Remus fought against Amulius and helped King Numitor become king again in 752 BC.

Here's a simple family tree to help you understand:

- Procas (son of Aeneas)
- King Numitor (son of Procas)
- Amulius (brother of King Numitor)
- Rhea Silvia (daughter of King Numitor)
- Romulus and Remus (sons of Rhea Silvia)
- Lausus (son of King Numitor)

This story is mentioned in the Aeneid, a famous Roman poem, and The Golden Bough, a book about mythology.

References:
- Kings of Alba Longa
- Characters in Book VI of the Aeneid

The 14th century saw the consolidation of Polish power, with the establishment of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth. The 15th century was characterized by the expansion of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, with the acquisition of key territories. The 16th century was a period of cultural and intellectual flourishing, with the emergence of the Polish Renaissance.

The 17th century was marked by the decline of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, with the rise of the Habsburg Empire. The 18th century saw the emergence of the Polish Enlightenment, characterized by the development of new ideas and values. The 19th century was a period of significant political change, with the establishment of the First Polish Republic.

The 20th century was marked by the establishment of the Second Polish Republic (1918-39), followed by the Occupation of Poland (1939-45). The subsequent period was characterized by the Communist takeover and the establishment of the Polish People's Republic. The 21st century has seen the emergence of the Democratic Republic of Poland, characterized by significant economic and social changes.

This timeline provides a comprehensive overview of Polish history, highlighting significant events and developments that have shaped the country's trajectory. For further reading and external links, refer to the references and external links sections provided.

samples.title: Watarrka National Park
samples.original_text:
Watarrka National Park is a protected area  in the Northern Territory of Australia located about 1,316 kilometres (817 miles) south of the territory capital of Darwin and  southwest of Alice Springs.

It contains the much visited Kings Canyon at the western end of the George Gill Range and Kathleen Springs —  to the southeast of Kings Canyon.

Watarrka National Park was established in 1989 and gets its name from the Aboriginal name of the land.

In 1986, the national park was described by the Department of Environment as follows:One of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon contains some 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 different plant species and 80 species of birds. It is a 'living plant museum' and is notable for its stands of cycads & permanent rock pools. There are some well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area...

The national park is categorised as an IUCN Category II protected area. On 25 March 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

See also

Watarrka National Park was established in 1989 and is named after the Aboriginal name of the land. In 1986, the Department of Environment described the park as one of the most spectacular canyons in Central Australia. Kings Canyon is home to around 60 rare or relict plant species and a total of 572 different plant species, as well as 80 species of birds. It is often called a "living plant museum" and is known for its stands of cycads and permanent rock pools. Additionally, there are some well-preserved Aboriginal paintings and engravings in the area.

The park is classified as an IUCN Category II protected area. On March 25, 1986, it was listed on the now-defunct Register of the National Estate.

samples.title: Perieres
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Perieres () may refer to these two distinct individuals.
Perieres, king of Messenia and son of Aeolus.
 Perieres, Theban charioteer of Menoeceus (father of Creon). He was the one who wounded Clymenus, king of Minyans and father of Erginus. This resulted to the heavy tribute imposed by the Minyans to the Thebans.

Notes

References 

 Apollodorus, The Library with an English Translation by Sir James George Frazer, F.B.A., F.R.S. in 2 Volumes, Cambridge, MA, Harvard University Press; London, William Heinemann Ltd. 1921. ISBN 0-674-99135-4. Online version at the Perseus Digital Library. Greek text available from the same website.
 Hesiod, Catalogue of Women from Homeric Hymns, Epic Cycle, Homerica translated by Evelyn-White, H G. Loeb Classical Library Volume 57. London: William Heinemann, 1914. Online version at theio.com

Theban characters in Greek mythology
Characters in Greek mythology

easy_general.text: In Greek mythology, there are two different people named Perieres. One Perieres was a king of a place called Messenia, and he was the son of a man named Aeolus. The other Perieres was a charioteer from Thebes, and he hurt a king named Clymenus. Because of this, the Minyans had to give a lot of money to the Thebans.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, there are two different people named Perieres. One Perieres was a king of a place called Messenia, and he was the son of a man named Aeolus. The other Perieres was a charioteer from Thebes, a city in ancient Greek mythology. He was the son of Menoeceus, who was the father of Creon.

The charioteer Perieres is important because he hurt Clymenus, the king of a group of people called the Minyans. Because of this, the Minyans had to give a lot of money to the Thebans.

These stories are from two ancient sources: Apollodorus and Hesiod. Apollodorus wrote a book called "The Library," which is a collection of stories and myths. Hesiod wrote a book called "Catalogue of Women," which is a list of women in Greek mythology.

To learn more about these stories, you can find them online at the Perseus Digital Library and theio.com.

adult_technical.text: In the realm of Greek mythology, the name Perieres is associated with two distinct figures. The first Perieres is the king of Messenia, a son of Aeolus, the god of the winds. This Perieres is distinct from the second Perieres, a Theban charioteer who is notable for injuring Clymenus, the king of the Minyans. This injury led to the Minyans imposing a heavy tribute on the Thebans.

samples.title: Nässjö Municipality
samples.original_text:
Nässjö Municipality (Nässjö kommun) is a municipality in Jönköping County, southern Sweden where the town Nässjö is situated.

The present municipality was created in 1971 when the City of Nässjö (instituted in 1914) was amalgamated with five surrounding municipalities.

Localities
There are 11 urban areas (also called a Tätort or locality) in Nässjö Municipality.

In the table the localities are listed according to the size of the population as of December 31, 2005. The municipal seat is in bold characters.

Sister cities 
Nässjö has had two sister cities since the 1940s: Brønderslev in Denmark and Eidsberg in Norway.

samples.title: List of counties of Prince Edward Island
samples.original_text:
The Canadian province of Prince Edward Island has three counties that have historically been used as administrative divisions for the provincial government, and prior to Confederation (in 1873), the colonial government.

The current system of land division in Prince Edward Island, including its three counties, dates to a series of surveys undertaken in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army's Corps of Royal Engineers.  Holland's survey saw the island divided into the three counties, each of which had a "royalty" (or shire town) as a county seat.  The rest of the county outside the royalty was sub-divided into parishes for the Church of England, measuring approximately ; the parishes were further sub-divided into townships measuring approximately .

The counties are no longer used as administrative boundaries for the provincial government; however, they continue to be used as census divisions by Statistics Canada for statistical purposes in administering the Canadian census.

See also

Administrative divisions of Canada

References

 
Counties
Prince Edward Island

The way the island is divided into these three counties comes from a survey done in 1764-65 by Captain Samuel Holland of the British Army. Each county has a county seat, called a shire town. The rest of the county is divided into parishes for the Church of England, which are further divided into townships.

Today, the counties are not used as administrative areas by the provincial government, but they are still used by Statistics Canada for the census.

Each county has a main town called a "royalty," and the rest of the county is divided into smaller areas called parishes and townships. Today, these counties are still used by the government to collect information about the people who live there.

adult_technical.text:
The term "USS Triton" can refer to several distinct vessels in the United States Navy, each with its unique history and operational capabilities.

1. **USS Triton (1889-1930)**: This vessel was a tugboat in service from 1889 to 1930. Tugboats are small, maneuverable vessels designed to assist larger ships in various tasks, such as towing, mooring, and maneuvering. During its service, the USS Triton likely played a crucial role in supporting naval operations and logistics.

2. **USS Triton (1918)**: This USS Triton was also a tugboat, but its service was brief, lasting only a short period during 1918. The details of its service are not extensively documented, but it is likely that it was involved in supporting naval operations during World War I.

3. **USS Triton (1940-1943)**: This USS Triton was a submarine commissioned in 1940 and was unfortunately sunk in 1943. Submarines are underwater vessels designed for reconnaissance, attack, and other operations. During its service, the USS Triton played a critical role in supporting naval operations during World War II.

4. **USS Triton (1959-1969)**: This USS Triton was a submarine, later designated as SSN-586, in service from 1959 to 1969. The SSN-586 was a nuclear-powered submarine, which allowed it to operate for extended periods without refueling. During its service, the USS Triton played a significant role in supporting naval operations during the Cold War.

samples.title: Murray River National Park
samples.original_text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area  in South Australia located between  and  north east of the Adelaide city centre.  The national park was proclaimed in 1991 "to conserve a significant proportion of South Australia’s floodplain environments which are not represented widely in other reserve systems."  The national park consists of three sections adjoining the Murray River and extending from near Loxton in the south west to near Renmark in the north-east.  The first which is known as the ‘Katarapko’ section is located on the north side of the river between Loxton in the south and Berri in the north.  The second section which is known as the ‘Lyrup Flats’ section is located on the north side of the river midway between Berri and Loxton.  The third section is known as the ‘Bulyong’ section is located on the west side of the river upstream from Renmark.     The national park is classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area.

See also

easy_general.text:
Murray River National Park is a protected area in South Australia that is located near the city of Adelaide. It was created in 1991 to protect important parts of South Australia's floodplain environments that are not found in other protected areas.

The park is divided into three main parts. The first part is called the 'Katarapko' section and is on the north side of the river between Loxton and Berri. The second part is called the 'Lyrup Flats' section and is also on the north side of the river, but halfway between Berri and Loxton. The third part is called the 'Bulyong' section and is on the west side of the river, upstream from Renmark.

The park is classified as an IUCN Category VI protected area, which means it is a protected area that is managed to protect the environment and wildlife.

Other nearby protected areas in South Australia include the Katarapko Game Reserve, the Riverland Biosphere Reserve, and the Riverland Mallee Important Bird Area.

For more information, you can visit the official Murray River National Park website or the page on the Protected Planet website.

samples.title: Tuireann
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann (Old Irish: Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo) was the father by Danu (or Brigid) of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

His other sons, by his daughter Danand, included Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba, who killed Lugh's father Cian. As an erec (a recompense fine), they were sent on a quest recounted as Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin. After Lugh had taken his elaborate revenge, Tuireann died of grief over their graves.

He is stated in various portions of Lebor Gabála Érenn to be the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References

Tuatha Dé Danann

easy_general.text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann is a significant figure. He is the father of Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu by his wife Danu (also known as Brigid).

Tuireann also had other children with his daughter Danand: Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. Unfortunately, these sons killed Lugh's father, Cian. As a punishment, they were sent on a quest, which is described in the story of Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann). This story is one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin.

After Lugh completed his revenge, Tuireann died from grief over the graves of his sons.

Tuireann is sometimes considered the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also known as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References:
- Tuatha Dé Danann

adult_non_technical.text:
In Irish mythology, Tuireann is a significant figure. He is also known as Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo in Old Irish. Tuireann had a wife named Danu, who is sometimes referred to as Brigid. Together, they had three children: Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu.

Tuireann also had a daughter named Danand, with whom he had three sons: Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. These sons committed a terrible crime when they killed Lugh's father, Cian. As a result of this crime, they were sent on a quest to pay a heavy fine, known as an erec. This quest is described in a story called Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann, which translates to "The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann." This story is one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin.

After the long quest, Lugh finally got his revenge. Tuireann, now overcome with grief, passed away while crying over the graves of his sons.

Tuireann is sometimes considered the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, another important figure in Irish mythology. Delbáeth mac Ogma is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References:

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of Irish mythology, Tuireann, also known as Tuirenn or Tuirill Biccreo, is a significant figure within the Tuatha Dé Danann, a pantheon of gods and goddesses. He is the father of several notable figures, including Creidhne, Luchtaine, and Goibniu, who are all children of Danu (or Brigid).

Tuireann's relationship with his daughter Danand is particularly noteworthy, as she is the mother of his sons, Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba. These sons play a crucial role in the narrative of Irish mythology, as they are said to have killed Lugh's father, Cian. As a form of an erec, or recompense fine, they are sent on a quest recounted as Oidheadh Chlainne Tuireann (The Tragedy of the Sons of Tuireann), one of the Three sorrowful tales of Erin.

Following Lugh's elaborate revenge, Tuireann is said to have succumbed to grief over the graves of his sons. This tragic event is documented in various portions of the Lebor Gabála Érenn, where Tuireann is identified as the same person as Delbáeth mac Ogma, who is also credited as the father of Brian, Iuchar, and Iucharba.

References:
Tuatha Dé Danann

samples.original_text:
Mathematical optimization is the theory and computation of extrema or stationary points of functions.

Optimization, optimisation, or optimality may also refer to:

easy_general.text: Optimization means finding the best way to do something. In math, it's about finding the highest or lowest point of a function. It can also mean many other things, like making a program work better or making a product more appealing. For example, in business, optimization can mean finding the most efficient way to produce something.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Optimization: A Simple Guide**

Optimization is a term that might sound complicated, but it's actually a pretty straightforward concept. It's all about finding the best solution to a problem. Imagine you're trying to find the fastest route to a friend's house or the most efficient way to complete a task. That's what optimization is all about!

In mathematical terms, optimization is the study of finding the maximum or minimum value of a function. Think of it like trying to find the highest or lowest point on a graph. This is often referred to as finding the "extrema" or "stationary points" of a function.

But optimization isn't just about math. It's used in many different fields, from engineering to biology to video games. Here are a few examples:

* **Engineering optimization**: This is used to find the most efficient way to build a structure, like designing a bridge or a building.
* **Feedback-Directed Optimization**: This is a technique used in computing to improve the performance of algorithms.
* **Optimality model in biology**: This is a way of understanding how living things evolve and adapt.
* **Optimality Theory**: This is a theory in linguistics that explains how we learn and use language.
* **Optimization (role-playing games)**: This is a style of playing video games.
* **Optimize (magazine)**: This is a magazine that covers optimization.
* **Process optimization**: This is used to improve the efficiency of a production process.
* **Product optimization**: This is used to improve the quality and desirability of a product or a new product's concept.
* **Program optimization**: This is used to improve the efficiency of software.
* **Search engine optimization**: This is used in internet marketing to improve a website's visibility and ranking on search engines.

There are also some related terms that might be confusing:

* **Optimum**: This is the best or most efficient solution.
* **Optimality theory**: This is the study of optimality and its applications.
* **Optimism**: This is a feeling of hope or confidence about the future.
* **Maximization** and **Minimization**: These are techniques used to find the optimal solution.

In summary, optimization is about finding the best solution to a problem, and it's used in many different fields. By understanding the principles of optimization, we can make better decisions and create more efficient systems.

adult_technical.text:
Mathematical optimization is the study of finding the maximum or minimum values of a function, as well as stationary points where the derivative is zero. This field encompasses both theoretical foundations and computational techniques to achieve these goals.

Beyond mathematical optimization, the term 'optimization' is also used in various other contexts:

1. **Engineering Optimization**: This refers to the process of enhancing the performance of engineering systems, often involving the design, analysis, and implementation of systems to achieve desired outcomes.

2. **Feedback-Directed Optimization**: In computing, this approach involves iteratively refining a solution based on feedback from the system being optimized.

3. **Optimality Model in Biology**: This model posits that biological systems are designed for optimal performance, often in the context of evolutionary biology and ecology.

4. **Optimality Theory**: A theory in linguistics that suggests certain linguistic structures are necessary or optimal for effective language acquisition and communication.

5. **Optimization (Role-Playing Games)**: This is a play style in role-playing games where players aim to maximize their performance or success.

6. **Optimize (Magazine)**: A publication that focuses on optimization techniques and applications across various disciplines.

7. **Process Optimization**: In business and engineering, this refers to methodologies used to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of production processes, often involving process design, quality control, and resource allocation.

8. **Product Optimization**: In business and marketing, this involves improving the quality and desirability of a product or product concept, often through market analysis, customer feedback, and iterative testing.

9. **Program Optimization**: In computing, this refers to techniques used to improve the efficiency and execution time of software programs, such as code optimization, resource management, and performance tuning.

10. **Search Engine Optimization**: In internet marketing, this involves improving a website's visibility and ranking in search engines by optimizing content, meta tags, and user experience.

See also:

- **Optimum (Disambiguation)**
- **Optimality Theory (Disambiguation)**
- **Optimism (Disambiguation)**
- **Optimist (Disambiguation)**
- **Optimistic (Disambiguation)**
- **Maximization (Disambiguation)**
- **Minimization (Disambiguation)**

These applications highlight the interdisciplinary nature of optimization and its importance across diverse fields to enhance performance, efficiency, and effectiveness in various domains.

samples.title: 186 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 186 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus (or, less frequently, year 568 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 186 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 The rapid spread of the Bacchanalia cult throughout the Roman Republic, which, it is claimed, indulges in all kinds of crimes and political conspiracies at its nocturnal meetings, leads to the Roman Senate issuing a decree, the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus, by which the Bacchanalia are prohibited throughout all Italy except in certain special cases which must be approved specifically by the Senate.

 Asia Minor 
 Eumenes II of Pergamum defeats Prusias I of Bithynia.

 China 
 The first burial at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui is made during the Western Han Dynasty of China.

Births 
 Ptolemy VI Philometor, king of Egypt, who will reign from 180 BC (d. 145 BC)

Deaths 
 Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, buried in one of the Mawangdui

References

easy_general.text: In the year 186 BC, many important events happened in different parts of the world. In Rome, a cult called Bacchanalia became very popular, but some people thought it was bad. So, the Roman Senate decided to ban it in most places. In Asia Minor, a man named Eumenes II of Pergamum won a battle against Prusias I of Bithynia. In China, the first burial at a famous site called Mawangdui was made during the Western Han Dynasty. During this time, a man named Ptolemy VI Philometor was born, who later became the king of Egypt. Also, a man named Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, passed away and was buried at the Mawangdui site.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 186 BC, many significant events took place across different parts of the world. This year was part of the pre-Julian Roman calendar, which was the original calendar used by the ancient Romans. The year 186 BC was called the Year of the Consulship of Albinus and Philippus, or less commonly, year 568 Ab urbe condita. The name 186 BC has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar became the standard way of naming years.

One of the most important events of 186 BC was the spread of the Bacchanalia cult in the Roman Republic. The Bacchanalia was a festival that involved wild parties and celebrations, but it was also believed to be a time for criminal activities and political plots. The Roman Senate was so concerned about this that they issued a decree called the Senatus consultum de Bacchanalibus. This decree banned the Bacchanalia throughout Italy, except in special cases that had to be approved by the Senate.

In Asia Minor, Eumenes II of Pergamum defeated Prusias I of Bithynia. This battle was significant because it expanded the power of Pergamum, a major city-state in Asia Minor.

In China, the first burial was made at the famous archaeological site of Mawangdui during the Western Han Dynasty. Mawangdui is known for its well-preserved tombs, which provide valuable insights into ancient Chinese culture and history.

One notable birth in 186 BC was Ptolemy VI Philometor, who would later become the king of Egypt. Ptolemy VI reigned from 180 BC until his death in 145 BC.

Another death in 186 BC was Li Cang, Marquis of Dai, who was buried in one of the Mawangdui tombs.

References:
- (Insert references here)

samples.title: Dodoni
samples.original_text:
Dodoni () is a village and a municipality in the Ioannina regional unit, Epirus, Greece. The seat of the municipality is the village Agia Kyriaki (community Theriakisi).

The modern village of Dodoni is located near the ancient city of same name and site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. Oedipus the King was shot here in 1967.

Municipality
The present municipality Dodoni was formed at the 2011 local government reform by the merger of the following 4 former municipalities, that became municipal units:
Agios Dimitrios
Dodoni
Lakka Souliou
Selloi

The municipality Dodoni has an area of 657.499 km2, the municipal unit Dodoni has an area of 101.016 km2, and the community Dodoni has an area of 8.748 km2.

The modern village of Dodoni is situated near the ancient city of the same name and is renowned as the site of the ancient oracle of Dodona. It is also notable as the location where the film "Oedipus the King" was shot in 1967.

samples.title: Florence, Illinois
samples.original_text:
Florence is a village in Pike County, Illinois, United States. The population was 71 at the 2000 census.

Geography
Florence is located at  (39.628248, −90.610328).

According to the 2010 census, Florence has a total area of , all land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 71 people, 30 households, and 21 families residing in the village. The population density was 350.4 people per square mile (137.1/km). There were 45 housing units at an average density of 222.1 per square mile (86.9/km). The racial makeup of the village was 100.00% White.

There were 30 households, out of which 16.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 50.0% were married couples living together, 16.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.0% were non-families. 23.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.37 and the average family size was 2.67.

In the village, the population was spread out, with 22.5% under the age of 18, 5.6% from 18 to 24, 22.5% from 25 to 44, 26.8% from 45 to 64, and 22.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 44 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.2 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.7 males.

The median income for a household in the village was $20,000, and the median income for a family was $22,679. Males had a median income of $19,000 versus $20,625 for females. The per capita income for the village was $9,878. There were 8.0% of families and 15.1% of the population living below the poverty line, including no under eighteens and 5.0% of those over 64.

In the realm of Buddhism, "Daigo" is a Zen concept that translates to "great enlightenment" or "great realization." This term is closely associated with the teachings of Eihei Dōgen, particularly in his work "Shōbōgenzō," where "Daigo" is a central theme. The historical "Daigo Temple" (醍醐寺) is a significant site and is named after Emperor Daigo, who reigned from 897 to 930.

In the context of people, "Daigo" can refer to several notable figures. Emperor Daigo (醍醐天皇) was a pivotal figure in Japanese history, serving as Emperor from 897 to 930. The Daigo family, a branch of the Ichijō family, is a lineage of Japanese nobility. Additionally, Daigo (musician) (born 1978) is a renowned Japanese singer-songwriter, actor, talent, and voice actor. Geographically, "Daigo" is associated with several locations in Japan. Daigo, Fushimi, Kyoto is a district in the ward of Fushimi-ku, Kyoto. Daigo Station (Kyoto) (醍醐駅) and Daigo Station (Akita) (醍醐駅) are both train stations. Daigo, Ibaraki (大子町) is a town in Ibaraki Prefecture.

It is worth noting that "Daigou" (代购), which refers to the unauthorized import of foreign goods into China, is a distinct concept and should not be confused with the other interpretations of "Daigo."

In summary, "Daigo" is a term with diverse meanings across various fields, each contributing to a rich tapestry of knowledge and understanding.

samples.title: Pane carasau
samples.original_text:
Pane carasau (, ; "toasted bread" in Sardinian language, from the past participle of the Sardinian verb  "to toast", referring to the crust) is a traditional flatbread from Sardinia. It is called  in Italian, meaning "sheet music", in reference to its large and paper-thin shape, which is said to be so thin before cooking that a sheet of music can be read through it.

The bread is thin and crisp, usually in the form of a dish half a meter wide. It is made by taking baked flat bread (made of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water), then separating it into two sheets which are baked again. The recipe is very ancient and was conceived for shepherds, who used to stay far from home for months at a time: pane carasau can last up to one year if it is kept dry. The bread can be eaten either dry or wet (with water, wine, or sauces). A similar, yeast-free bread, with added seasoning, is known as  "dripped bread".

Remains of the bread were found in archeological excavations of nuraghes (traditional Sardinian stone buildings) and it was therefore already eaten on the island prior to 1000 BC.

References

External links
 A video showing the production of Pane carasau
 History of Pane Carasau

Italian breads
Flatbreads
Cuisine of Sardinia
Ancient dishes

easy_general.text: Pane carasau is a type of bread from Sardinia, Italy. It's called 'toasted bread' in the local language because the crust is crispy. It's also called'sheet music' because it's so thin that you can read music through it. The bread is made by taking a regular flatbread and separating it into two sheets, then baking it again. It's very old and was made for shepherds who had to be away for long periods. The bread can last up to a year if it's kept dry and can be eaten either dry or wet. It has been eaten in Sardinia since 1000 BC.

adult_non_technical.text:
Pane carasau is a type of bread that comes from the island of Sardinia. It's a flatbread, meaning it's thin and flat like a pancake. The name 'Pane carasau' comes from the Sardinian language and means 'toasted bread' because the crust of the bread is golden brown after it's cooked.

The bread is made by taking a type of flour called durum wheat flour and mixing it with salt, yeast, and water. Then, it's baked until it's crispy and golden brown. The bread is then cut into two very thin sheets and baked again to make it even crispier.

Pane carasau has a very long history. It was originally made for shepherds who had to stay away from home for months at a time. The bread can last up to a year if it's kept dry, which is perfect for shepherds who had to carry it with them on their journeys.

Pane carasau can be eaten either dry or with water, wine, or sauces. There's also a similar bread that doesn't have yeast, which is called 'dripped bread'.

Remains of pane carasau have been found in the ruins of ancient Sardinian stone buildings called nuraghes. This means that people were already eating pane carasau on the island over 3,000 years ago.

References

adult_technical.text:
Pane carasau, a traditional flatbread from Sardinia, is characterized by its large, paper-thin shape, which gives it its Italian name, "sheet music." This bread is typically prepared in the form of a dish approximately half a meter wide and is made by separating a baked flat bread composed of durum wheat flour, salt, yeast, and water into two sheets, which are then baked again. The recipe for pane carasau is ancient and was originally developed for shepherds who would travel long distances for months at a time. The bread has a shelf life of up to one year when stored dry and can be consumed either dry or moistened with water, wine, or sauces.

A yeast-free version of pane carasau, known as "dripped bread," exists with added seasoning. Archaeological excavations of traditional Sardinian stone buildings, known as nuraghes, have revealed that pane carasau was already consumed on the island prior to 1000 BC.

samples.original_text:
Year 346 (CCCXLVI) was a common year starting on Wednesday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. In the Roman Empire, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius (or, less frequently, year 1099 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 346 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
 Asia 
 In Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom is absorbed by Goguryeo.
 Geunchogo becomes king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

 By topic 
 Religion 
 Emperor Constans I uses his influence to secure the return of Athanasius. He is restored as Patriarch of Alexandria, and documents are compiled relating to his expulsion, under the title Apology Against the Arians.
 Macedonius I, Patriarch of Constantinople, is deposed again by Paul I.
 Julius Firmicus Maternus writes De erroribus profanarum religionum.
 The Visigoths are converted to Arianism by Wulfila.

Births 
 Zhang Tianxi, Chinese ruler of Former Liang (d. 406)

Deaths 
 He Chong (or Cidao), Chinese politician (b. 292)
 Maximin of Trier, German bishop (approximate date)
 Zhang Jun (or Gongting), Chinese prince (b. 307)

References

easy_general.text:
In the year 346, many important events happened around the world. Here's a summary of some of the key events:

**Asia:**

* In Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom was absorbed or absorbed by a larger kingdom called Goguryeo.
* Geunchogo became the king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

**Religion:**

* Emperor Constans I used his power to help Athanasius return to his position as Patriarch of Alexandria.
* Athanasius wrote a book called "Apology Against the Arians," which explained why he had been removed from his position.
* Macedonius I, Patriarch of Constantinople, was removed from his position by Paul I.
* Julius Firmicus Maternus wrote a book called "De erroribus profanarum religionum," which talked about the mistakes of other religions.
* The Visigoths, a group of people, were converted to Arianism by Wulfila.

**Births:**

* Zhang Tianxi, a Chinese ruler, was born in this year.

**Deaths:**

* He Chong, a Chinese politician, passed away in this year.
* Maximin of Trier, a German bishop, also passed away in this year.
* Zhang Jun, a Chinese prince, passed away in this year.

These are just a few of the many important events that happened in the year 346.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 346, many important events happened around the world. This year, also known as CCCXLVI, started on a Wednesday in the Julian calendar, which is a type of calendar used in Europe during the Middle Ages. In the Roman Empire, this year was called the Year of the Consulship of Constantius and Claudius, or year 1099 Ab urbe condita.

One of the most significant events of this year occurred in Asia. In Korea, the Buyeo Kingdom was absorbed by Goguryeo, which means that Buyeo was taken over by Goguryeo. Additionally, Geunchogo became the king of the Korean kingdom of Baekje.

In the religious sphere, several important things happened. Emperor Constans I used his influence to help Athanasius return to his position as Patriarch of Alexandria. Athanasius was a prominent figure who had been removed from his position. After his return, he wrote a book called Apology Against the Arians, which explained why he had been removed.

Another religious event was the deposition of Macedonius I, the Patriarch of Constantinople, by Paul I. This means that Macedonius I was removed from his position.

Julius Firmicus Maternus wrote a book called De erroribus profanarum religionum, which translates to "On the Errors of Profane Religions." This book likely discussed the flaws of other religions.

Lastly, the Visigoths, a group of people, were converted to Arianism by a man named Wulfila.

During this year, a notable ruler was born. Zhang Tianxi, a Chinese ruler of the Former Liang dynasty, was born. He would later die in 406.

Unfortunately, some important people also passed away during this year. He Chong, a Chinese politician, died. He was born in 292. Maximin of Trier, a German bishop, also passed away, although the exact date of his death is not known. Zhang Jun, a Chinese prince, died. He was born in 307.

In summary, the year 346 was a significant year with many important events happening around the world. In Asia, new kingdoms were formed, and in the religious sphere, important figures were restored to their positions and new books were written. Additionally, some notable people lived and passed away during this year.

samples.title: Tetonia, Idaho
samples.original_text:
Tetonia is a city in Teton County, Idaho, United States, about  northeast of Idaho Falls, Idaho (center to center) and about  northwest of Denver, Colorado. The population was 269 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has a total area of , all land.
Tetonia is located at 43°48′50″N 111°9′35″W, in Teton County Idaho.

History
Tetonia was established as an agricultural town in the late 19th century, taking its name from the nearby Teton Range. Many of the businesses previously operating in Haden relocated to Tetonia following the arrival of the Union Pacific railroad.

Demographics

2010 census
As of the census of 2010, there were 269 people, 95 households, and 62 families residing in the city. The population density was . There were 122 housing units at an average density of . The racial makeup of the city was 92.2% White, 0.7% Native American, 6.3% from other races, and 0.7% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 10.8% of the population.

There were 95 households, of which 46.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 49.5% were married couples living together, 11.6% had a female householder with no husband present, 4.2% had a male householder with no wife present, and 34.7% were non-families. 28.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.83 and the average family size was 3.61.

The median age in the city was 35.1 years. 36.1% of residents were under the age of 18; 5.1% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 26.7% were from 25 to 44; 24.5% were from 45 to 64; and 7.4% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.7% male and 51.3% female.

samples.original_text:
Hubley Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 854 at the 2010 census, a drop of less than 1% from the previous census in 2000.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 889 people, 345 households, and 260 families living in the township.  The population density was 68.0 people per square mile (26.2/km).  There were 369 housing units at an average density of 28.2/sq mi (10.9/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.21% White, 0.22% African American, 0.11% Asian, 0.22% Pacific Islander, 0.11% from other races, and 0.11% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.12%.

Of the 345 households 29.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.7% were married couples living together, 5.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.6% were non-families. 21.2% of households were one person and 11.9% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.58 and the average family size was 2.98.

The age distribution was 21.7% under the age of 18, 6.7% from 18 to 24, 28.3% from 25 to 44, 23.3% from 45 to 64, and 19.9% 65 or older.  The median age was 41 years. For every 100 females, there were 107.7 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.3 males.

The median household income was $41,250 and the median family income  was $46,538. Males had a median income of $32,734 versus $24,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $17,377.  About 4.2% of families and 5.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.6% of those under age 18 and 7.9% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: Kebechet
samples.original_text:
In Egyptian mythology, Kebechet (spelt in hieroglyphs as Qeb-Hwt, and also transliterated as Khebhut, Kebehut, Qébéhout, Kabehchet and Kebehwet) is a goddess, a deification of embalming liquid. Her name means cooling water.

Myths
Kebechet is a daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, Kebechet is referred to as a serpent who "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh.

Kebechet was thought to give water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was probably related to mummification where she would fortify the body against corruption, so it would stay fresh for reanimation by the deceased's ka.

References

Egyptian death goddesses

easy_general.text:
In ancient Egypt, there was a goddess named Kebechet. She was known as the deification of embalming liquid, which was used to preserve the body after death. Her name means "cooling water."

Kebechet was the daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, she was described as a serpent who refreshes and purifies the pharaoh.

She was believed to help with the mummification process by giving water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the body to be preserved. It was thought that Kebechet would protect the body from decay, so it would stay fresh for the deceased's spirit to come back.

Kebechet was an important figure in Egyptian mythology, especially in the context of death and the afterlife.

Kebechet was the daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In ancient Egyptian texts, she was described as a serpent who refreshes and purifies the Pharaoh. Kebechet was believed to provide water to the spirits of the dead while they waited for the mummification process to be complete. She was also thought to help with mummification by protecting the body from decay, so it would stay fresh for the soul of the deceased to use.

adult_technical.text:
In the pantheon of Egyptian mythology, Kebechet, transcribed as Qeb-Hwt in hieroglyphs and also transliterated as Khebhut, Kebehut, Qébéhout, Kabehchet, and Kebehwet, is a deity associated with embalming liquid. Her name, which translates to "cooling water," underscores her role in the preservation of the deceased.

Kebechet is identified as the daughter of Anubis and his wife Anput. In the Pyramid Texts, she is depicted as a serpent who "refreshes and purifies" the pharaoh, signifying her role in the sanctification of the ruler.

The mythology surrounding Kebechet is intertwined with the mummification process. She is believed to provide water to the spirits of the deceased while they await the completion of the embalming process. Additionally, she is likely associated with the fortification of the body against corruption, thereby ensuring its preservation for the reanimation by the deceased's ka.

samples.title: Oostburg
samples.original_text:
Oostburg (Zeelandic Flemish: Wòstburg) is a town in the south-western Netherlands. It is the largest town in the municipality of Sluis, in the province of Zeeland. As of 1 January 2015, its population is 4731, down from 5008 in January 2005. It received city rights in 1237. Before 1 January 2003, Oostburg was also the name of a municipality. It merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the new municipality of Sluis. The municipality covered an area of 224.93 km², of which 1.05 km² was water. As well as the town of Oostburg, the former municipality also included the following towns, villages and townships:
Breskens
Cadzand
Groede
Hoofdplaat
IJzendijke
Nieuwvliet
Schoondijke
Waterlandkerkje
Zuidzande

Oostburg is typically a tourist town very close to the beaches at Cadzand. Every Wednesday is market day all year round but in the summer the town is busy and has many fun events.

The unicorn
Oostburg's symbol is the unicorn, from which the townsfolk are said to derive strength and courage. In reality, the unicorn's presence is represented by a sculpture produced by the sculptress Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek who for many years, with her husband, lived in the area: she evidently took inspiration from the name of a former inn. The sculpture has been repositioned at least once since it first appeared in 1952 during the postwar reconstruction: at one stage it adorned a small car park. Currently it shares with a modern fountain a spot in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) beyond the northern end of the old market square in the town centre.

WW2 Monument
During the Second World War approximately 140 Oostburg townsfolk died and most of all the buildings, shops and churches were destroyed. This monument is a tribute to them and the rebuilding of the town. Around the lower part of the monument are the names of those who perished.

Former municipalities of Zeeland
Sluis

adult_technical.text:
Oostburg, also known as Wòstburg in Zeelandic Flemish, is a town situated in the south-western Netherlands. It serves as the largest town within the municipality of Sluis, located in the province of Zeeland. As of 1 January 2015, the population of Oostburg was 4,731, a decline from 5,008 in January 2005. Oostburg was granted city rights in 1237. Prior to 1 January 2003, Oostburg was also a municipality, which later merged with Sluis-Aardenburg to form the new municipality of Sluis. The former municipality covered an area of 224.93 square kilometers, of which 1.05 square kilometers were water. In addition to Oostburg, the municipality included the following towns, villages, and townships: Breskens, Cadzand, Groede, Hoofdplaat, IJzendijke, Nieuwvliet, Schoondijke, Waterlandkerkje, and Zuidzande.

Oostburg is primarily a tourist destination, conveniently located near the beaches at Cadzand. Every Wednesday, Oostburg hosts a market day, which is active year-round but becomes particularly busy during the summer months when the town hosts various events.

The symbol of Oostburg is the unicorn, which is believed to represent strength and courage for the townsfolk. This symbol is immortalized through a sculpture created by Liesbeth Messer-Heijbroek, a sculptress who lived in the area with her husband. The sculpture, inspired by the name of a former inn, has been relocated at least once since its creation in 1952 during the postwar reconstruction. Currently, it is located in "Eenhoornplantsoen" (Unicorn Place) in the town center, alongside a modern fountain.

During World War II, approximately 140 residents of Oostburg lost their lives, and most of the town's buildings, shops, and churches were destroyed. A monument was erected to honor these victims and commemorate the rebuilding of the town. The monument features the names of those who perished.

Oostburg, along with other municipalities in the Netherlands, is part of the list of municipalities that disestablished in 2003.

samples.title: Leaf River Township, Wadena County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Leaf River Township is a township in Wadena County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 515 at the 2000 census.

Leaf River Township was named after the Leaf River.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 515 people, 174 households, and 135 families residing in the township.  The population density was 14.6 people per square mile (5.7/km2).  There were 196 housing units at an average density of 5.6/sq mi (2.2/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 94.37% White, 2.14% African American, 1.75% Native American, 0.58% Asian, 0.19% Pacific Islander, and 0.97% from two or more races.

There were 174 households, out of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.9% were married couples living together, 0.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 22.4% were non-families. 21.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.68 and the average family size was 3.16.

In the township the population was spread out, with 26.2% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 23.9% from 25 to 44, 33.6% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females, there were 138.4 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $37,292, and the median income for a family was $46,750. Males had a median income of $32,411 versus $20,795 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,681.  About 6.5% of families and 19.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 11.1% of those under age 18 and 28.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

samples.title: Haddocks' Eyes
samples.original_text:
"Haddocks' Eyes" is a term for the name of a song sung by The White Knight from Lewis Carroll's  1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass, chapter VIII.

"Haddocks' Eyes" is an example used to elaborate on the symbolic status of the concept of "name": a name as identification marker may be assigned to anything, including another name, thus introducing different levels of symbolization. It has been discussed in several works on logic and philosophy.

Naming

The White Knight explains to Alice a confusing nomenclature for the song.

To summarize:

The song's name is called Haddocks' Eyes
The song's name is The Aged Aged Man
The song is called Ways and Means
The song is A-sitting on a Gate

The complicated terminology distinguishing between 'the song, what the song is called, the name of the song, and what the name of the song is called' both uses and mentions the use–mention distinction.

The song

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims as his own invention, but which Alice recognises as "I give thee all, I can no more". By the time Alice heard it, she was already tired of poetry.

The song parodies the plot, but not the style or metre, of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth.

Upon the Lonely Moor

Like "Jabberwocky," another poem published in Through the Looking Glass, "Haddocks’ Eyes" appears to have been revised over the course of many years. In 1856, Carroll published the following poem anonymously under the name Upon the Lonely Moor. It bears an obvious resemblance to "Haddocks' Eyes."

See also

Nonsense verse

References

British poems
1871 poems
Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
Nonsense poetry
Parodies of literature

easy_general.text:
Haddocks' Eyes" is a song sung by the White Knight in Alice's Adventures in Wonderland. The song has many names, including The Aged Aged Man, Ways and Means, and A-sitting on a Gate. The White Knight sings it to a tune he made up, but Alice recognizes it as "I give thee all, I can no more." The song is a parody of a poem by William Wordsworth.

The song has been revised over time, and in 1856, Lewis Carroll published a poem called "Upon the Lonely Moor" that is similar to "Haddocks' Eyes."

"Haddocks' Eyes" is an example of nonsense verse, a type of poetry that is meant to be playful and silly.

adult_non_technical.text:
Haddocks' Eyes" is a song from Lewis Carroll's novel "Through the Looking-Glass," sung by the White Knight. This song is interesting because it has many different names, including "The Aged Aged Man," "Ways and Means," and "A-sitting on a Gate." The White Knight sings the song to a tune he made up, but Alice recognizes it as "I give thee all, I can no more." The song is a parody of a poem by William Wordsworth called "Resolution and Independence."

The song "Haddocks' Eyes" is also interesting because it illustrates the concept of naming and symbolism. For example, the name "Haddocks' Eyes" can be used to refer to the song itself, the name of the song, or the name of the name of the song. This is known as the "use-mention distinction" in philosophy.

Overall, "Haddocks' Eyes" is a fascinating and complex song that has been studied by philosophers and logicians alike.

adult_technical.text:
Haddocks' Eyes" is a term used to refer to a particular song sung by The White Knight in Lewis Carroll's 1871 novel "Through the Looking-Glass," specifically in chapter VIII. This song serves as a elucidate example to illustrate the symbolic status of the concept of "name," where a name as an identification marker can be assigned to anything, including another name, thereby introducing different levels of symbolization. This concept has been extensively discussed in various works on logic and philosophy.

### Nomenclature

The White Knight explains to Alice a complex nomenclature for the song, which can be summarized as follows:

1. The song is referred to as "Haddocks' Eyes."
2. The song is also known as "The Aged Aged Man."
3. The song is further called "Ways and Means."
4. The song is termed "A-sitting on a Gate."

This intricate terminology, which distinguishes between "the song, what the song is called, the name of the song, and what the name of the song is called," both employs and references the use–mention distinction.

### The Song

The White Knight sings the song to a tune he claims as his own invention, but Alice recognizes it as "I give thee all, I can no more." By the time Alice hears the song, she is already weary of poetry.

The song parodies the plot of "Resolution and Independence" by William Wordsworth, although it does not mimic the style or meter of the original poem.

### Upon the Lonely Moor

Similar to "Jabberwocky," another poem from "Through the Looking-Glass," "Haddocks' Eyes" appears to have undergone revisions over the years. In 1856, Carroll published a poem anonymously under the title "Upon the Lonely Moor," which bears a striking resemblance to "Haddocks' Eyes."

### See Also

For further reading and discussion, consider the following topics:

- Nonsense verse
- British poems
- 1871 poems
- Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
- Nonsense poetry
- Parodies of literature

### References

- Lewis Carroll, "Through the Looking-Glass" (1871)
- Lewis Carroll, "Upon the Lonely Moor" (1856)
- William Wordsworth, "Resolution and Independence

 The Eunomia family of asteroids (named after the goddess)
15 Eunomia, the largest asteroid in that family
 Eunomia (plant), a genus of plants in the family Brassicaceae
 A fictional computer in SoltyRei; see List of SoltyRei characters#Eunomia

 Callicore eunomia, a nymphalid butterfly species

samples.title: Holland Township, Kandiyohi County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Holland Township is a township in Kandiyohi County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 369 at the 2000 census.

Holland Township was organized in 1888. A large share of the early settlers being natives of Holland caused the name to be selected.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which  of  land and 0.03% is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 369 people, 120 households, and 102 families residing in the township.  The population density was 10.4 people per square mile (4.0/km2).  There were 122 housing units at an average density of 3.5/sq mi (1.3/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.37% White, 0.27% African American, 1.08% from other races, and 0.27% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.08% of the population.

There were 120 households, out of which 47.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 84.2% were married couples living together, and 15.0% were non-families. 11.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.08 and the average family size was 3.40.

In the township the population was spread out, with 33.9% under the age of 18, 3.8% from 18 to 24, 30.4% from 25 to 44, 22.8% from 45 to 64, and 9.2% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 105.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 114.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $45,313, and the median income for a family was $46,875. Males had a median income of $30,750 versus $19,107 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,243.  About 7.1% of families and 7.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 7.6% of those under age 18 and none of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: SI derived unit
samples.original_text:
SI derived units are units of measurement derived from the
seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). They are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation. 

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units (for example, hertz, the SI unit of measurement of frequency), but the rest merely reflect their derivation: for example, the square metre (m2), the SI derived unit of area; and the kilogram per cubic metre (kg/m3 or kg⋅m−3), the SI derived unit of density. 

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for metre is "m".

Derived units with special names
The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, which includes two dimensionless derived units, the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived quantities and units

Other units used with SI
Some other units such as the hour, litre, tonne, bar, and electronvolt are not SI units, but are widely used in conjunction with SI units.

Supplementary units
Until 1995, the SI classified the radian and the steradian as supplementary units, but this designation was abandoned and the units were grouped as derived units.

See also
 International System of Quantities (ISQ)
 International Vocabulary of Metrology
 Metric prefix
 Metric system

References

Bibliography

External links

Derived

adult_non_technical.text:
The International System of Units (SI) is a set of rules for measuring things like length, mass, time, and temperature. It's based on seven base units, which are the building blocks for all other units.

SI derived units are units that are made by combining these base units. They can be dimensionless, meaning they don't have any units of measurement, or they can be made by multiplying one or more base units together.

There are 22 special names for these derived units, like hertz, which is a unit of frequency. The rest of the units are just derived from the base units, like the square meter, which is a unit of area.

The names of SI derived units are always written in lowercase, but the symbols for units named after people are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz", but the symbol for meter is "m".

Some other units like the hour, liter, tonne, bar, and electronvolt are not SI units, but they are often used in combination with SI units.

Before 1995, the radian and the steradian were considered supplementary units, but now they are just derived units.

The International System of Quantities (ISQ) and the International Vocabulary of Metrology are related to the SI.

adult_technical.text:
SI derived units are units of measurement that are derived from the seven base units specified by the International System of Units (SI). These units are either dimensionless or can be expressed as a product of one or more of the base units, possibly scaled by an appropriate power of exponentiation.

The SI has special names for 22 of these derived units, such as the hertz, which is the SI unit of measurement of frequency. The names of the remaining derived units merely reflect their derivation. For instance, the square meter (m²) is the SI derived unit of area, and the kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³) is the SI derived unit of density.

The names of SI derived units, when written in full, are always in lowercase. However, the symbols for units named after persons are written with an uppercase initial letter. For example, the symbol for hertz is "Hz," while the symbol for meter is "m."

The International System of Units assigns special names to 22 derived units, including two dimensionless derived units: the radian (rad) and the steradian (sr).

Examples of derived quantities and units include:

- Hertz (Hz)
- Square meter (m²)
- Kilogram per cubic meter (kg/m³ or kg⋅m⁻³)
- Radian (rad)
- Steradian (sr)

Other units used in conjunction with SI units include the hour, liter, tonne, bar, and electronvolt. While these units are not SI units, they are widely used in conjunction with SI units.

Prior to 1995, the radian and the steradian were classified as supplementary units. However, this designation was abandoned, and the units were subsequently grouped as derived units.

For further information, refer to the International System of Quantities (ISQ), the International Vocabulary of Metrology, metric prefixes, and the metric system.

samples.title: Separate-channel signaling
samples.original_text:
Separate-channel signaling is a form of signaling in which the whole or a part of one or more channels in a multichannel system is used to provide for supervisory and control signals for the message traffic channels.  

The same channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, that are used for signaling are not used for message traffic.

See also

 Common-channel signaling

References

Telephony signals

easy_general.text: Imagine you have a big room with many chairs, and each chair represents a communication channel. Now, let's say you want to send a message to some people in the room. Instead of using all the chairs for the message, you use some special chairs to help the message get to the people. These special chairs are like separate channels that help the message travel.

adult_non_technical.text:
Imagine you're in a chat room with your friends, and each person has their own separate channel to talk. Now, let's say you want to send a special message to your friend, but you don't want to interrupt the main conversation. Instead, you can use a small, separate channel to send that message.

This is similar to what happens in a separate-channel signaling system. It's a way to send special messages or control signals through a separate channel, without interrupting the main message traffic.

In a separate-channel signaling system, the channels that are used for sending control messages are different from the channels that are used for the main message traffic. This way, the system can handle both the main message traffic and the control messages without any interference.

adult_technical.text:
Separate-channel signaling is a method employed in multichannel systems that involves the utilization of one or more channels for transmitting supervisory and control signals associated with message traffic channels. This approach distinguishes itself from common-channel signaling, which utilizes the same channels for both signaling and message traffic.

In separate-channel signaling, the signaling channels, such as frequency bands or time slots, are distinct from those used for message traffic. This separation allows for the transmission of signaling information without interfering with the primary message traffic.

See also:
- Common-channel signaling

References:
- Telephony signals

samples.title: 1440s BC
samples.original_text:
The 1440s BC is a decade which lasted from 1449 BC to 1440 BC.

Events and trends
 1449 BC: Fíachu Labrainne, Milesians' High King of Ireland, is killed and succeeded by Eochu Mumu
 c. 1448 BC: The Gnbtyw people (Genebtyw or Genebtyu) first appear in Ganibatum during the 32nd year of reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt
1445–1444 BC: The Book of Leviticus is written.
 c. 1440 BC: first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar which controlled the Gulf of İzmir

References

easy_general.text:
The 1440s BC is a period of time that started in 1449 BC and ended in 1440 BC. During this time, many important events happened.

In 1449 BC, a man named Fíachu Labrainne, who was a high king in Ireland, passed away. His brother, Eochu Mumu, became the new king.

Around 1448 BC, a group of people called the Gnbtyw or Genebtyu appeared in a place called Ganibatum. This happened during the 32nd year of a pharaoh in Egypt named Thutmose III.

Between 1445 BC and 1444 BC, an important book called the Book of Leviticus was written.

Around 1440 BC, a city was built near a mountain called Mount Yamanlar. This city was very important because it controlled the Gulf of İzmir.

These are just some of the important events that happened during the 1440s BC.

adult_non_technical.text:
The 1440s BC is a decade that spans from 1449 BC to 1440 BC. During this time, several important events and trends occurred.

In 1449 BC, Fíachu Labrainne, who was the High King of Ireland, passed away. He was succeeded by Eochu Mumu. This change in leadership marked a significant shift in the political landscape of Ireland.

Around 1448 BC, the Gnbtyw people, also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu, first appeared in Ganibatum, a region in Egypt. This happened during the 32nd year of the reign of Pharaoh Thutmose III, who was the sixth ruler of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt.

Between 1445 BC and 1444 BC, the Book of Leviticus, one of the five books of the Hebrew Bible, was written. This book is known for its teachings on religious laws and practices.

In around 1440 BC, the first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar was established. This settlement had strategic control over the Gulf of İzmir, making it an important location for trade and commerce.

These events and trends highlight the significant changes and developments that occurred during the 1440s BC.

adult_technical.text:
The 1440s BC, spanning from 1449 BC to 1440 BC, represents a significant decade in the annals of ancient history. This period is marked by several pivotal events and trends that underscore the complex interplay of cultural, political, and social developments of the time.

In 1449 BC, Fíachu Labrainne, the High King of Ireland, associated with the Milesians, meets his demise. This event signifies a notable shift in the political landscape of Ireland, as Eochu Mumu succeeds him as the High King. This transition represents a critical moment in the consolidation of power and the continuation of the Milesian influence in the region.

Simultaneously, around 1448 BC, the Gnbtyw people, also known as Genebtyw or Genebtyu, make their first appearance in Ganibatum. This event coincides with the 32nd year of the reign of Thutmose III, the sixth Pharaoh of the Eighteenth Dynasty of Egypt. The presence of the Gnbtyw people in Ganibatum highlights the extensive diplomatic and trade relations that existed between Egypt and other regions during this period.

Furthermore, between 1445 and 1444 BC, the Book of Leviticus is composed. This religious text, part of the Hebrew Bible, is a seminal work in the religious and cultural history of the ancient world. The composition of Leviticus during this decade underscores the development of religious thought and the consolidation of religious practices and beliefs.

Lastly, around 1440 BC, the first recorded urban settlement on or near Mount Yamanlar emerges. This settlement, with strategic control over the Gulf of İzmir, represents a significant milestone in the development of urbanization and political power in the region. The establishment of such a settlement in a strategic location like Mount Yamanlar reflects the growing importance of urban centers in the political and economic landscape of the time.

In summary, the 1440s BC is a decade characterized by key events and trends that reflect the multifaceted nature of ancient history. The transition from Fíachu Labrainne to Eochu Mumu, the appearance of the Gnbtyw people in Ganibatum, the composition of the Book of Leviticus, and the establishment of the first urban settlement on Mount Yamanlar all highlight the significant developments of this period.

samples.title: Tague, West Virginia

Tague is an unincorporated community in Braxton County, West Virginia, United States, along the Right Fork Steer Creek.  The community took its name from nearby Tague Fork creek. On March 8, Póvoa de Varzim, a city in Portugal, received a foral from Denis of Portugal. On April 15, Abu Hammu I became the king of the Kingdom of Tlemcen after his brother Abu-I Zayyan passed away. On November 27, Henry VII, the King of Germany, was elected Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. On December 28, Emperor Hanazono became the king of Japan.

The exact dates of some events are not known. For example, the Capet-Anjou family began to rule Hungary, and the Sultanate of Rûm ended. Some notable births in this year included Stefan Dušan, who became the Emperor of the Serbs, Longchenpa, a Tibetan Buddhist teacher, Laura de Noves, a French countess, and Prince Moriyoshi, a Japanese shōgun.

On the other hand, some important people passed away during this year. In summary, the year 1308 was a significant year with many important events, births, and deaths. It saw the marriage of King Edward II and Isabella of France, the establishment of Póvoa de Varzim, the election of Henry VII as Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, and the reign of Emperor Hanazono of Japan.

adult_non_technical.text:
PKD" can mean different things depending on the context. Here are a few examples:

1. **Philip Kindred Dick**: This is the name of an American science fiction writer. He's known for writing stories about the future and advanced technology.

2. **ICAO PKD**: This stands for the International Civil Aviation Organization Public Key Directory. It's a directory that helps people find information about public keys.

3. **Paroxysmal Kinesigenic Dyskinesia**: This is a rare movement disorder that causes people to move uncontrollably.

4. **Pi Kappa Delta**: This is a forensics honor society, which is a group of students who excel in debate and public speaking.

5. **Polycystic Kidney Disease**: This is a genetic disorder that causes cysts to form in the kidneys.

6. **PKD1 and PKD2**: These are human genes that are related to polycystic kidney disease.

7. **Proliferative Kidney Disease**: This is a rare condition caused by a parasite called Tetracapsuloides.

So, "PKD" can refer to many different things depending on the situation.

adult_technical.text:
The acronym PKD can represent several distinct entities, each with its own unique context and significance. Here, we will explore the various interpretations of PKD, focusing on the technical aspects and their implications.

Firstly, PKD can refer to Philip Kindred Dick, a renowned American science fiction writer. Dick is celebrated for his contributions to the genre, particularly in the realm of speculative fiction. His works are characterized by their intricate blend of science, technology, and philosophical themes, making him a significant figure in contemporary literature.

In the aviation domain, PKD can signify the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Public Key Directory. This directory is a critical resource for global aviation security, facilitating the exchange of cryptographic keys among aviation entities. The ICAO PKD plays a pivotal role in ensuring the integrity and confidentiality of aviation communications.

In the context of neurological disorders, PKD can represent paroxysmal kinesigenic dyskinesia, a rare movement disorder characterized by sudden, involuntary movements. This condition is often associated with other neurological abnormalities and requires precise diagnosis and management to mitigate its impact on the patient's quality of life.

Additionally, PKD can be associated with Pi Kappa Delta, a prestigious forensics honor society. Pi Kappa Delta is recognized for its commitment to academic excellence, public speaking, and leadership development, fostering a community of students who excel in these critical areas.

In the field of genetics and medicine, PKD can refer to polycystic kidney disease, a genetic disorder characterized by the formation of numerous cysts in the kidneys. PKD1 and PKD2 are two primary human genes implicated in the development of polycystic kidney disease. Mutations in these genes can lead to the accumulation of cysts in the kidneys, resulting in renal dysfunction and associated complications.

Lastly, PKD can represent proliferative kidney disease, a parasitic infection caused by the parasite Tetracapsuloides. This condition is characterized by the proliferation of abnormal cells in the kidneys, leading to renal dysfunction and potential complications. The parasite Tetracapsuloides is a protozoan organism that can infect various hosts, including humans, and is typically transmitted through contaminated water or food.

In summary, the acronym PKD encompasses a diverse range of entities across various domains, including literature, aviation, neuroscience, forensics, genetics, and medicine. Each interpretation of PKD carries distinct technical implications and requires a nuanced understanding of the underlying biological mechanisms and clinical pathophysiology for effective management and treatment.

Eagle Point Township was organized in 1890, and named for an eagle's nest in a nearby grove.

Geography

As of the census of 2000, there were 33 people, 13 households, and 10 families residing in the township. The population density was 1.2 people per square mile (0.5/km2). There were 18 housing units at an average density of 0.6/sq mi (0.2/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 20.0% of families and 20.7% of the population living below the poverty line, including 50.0% of under eighteens and none of those over 64.

Year 834 (DCCCXXXIV) was a common year starting on Thursday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar.

samples.title: Tell Township, Huntingdon County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Tell Township is a township in Huntingdon County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 662 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 42.5 square miles (110.2 km), all of it land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 648 people, 238 households, and 179 families residing in the township.  The population density was 15.2 people per square mile (5.9/km).  There were 343 housing units at an average density of 8.1/sq mi (3.1/km).  The racial make-up of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 238 households, out of which 36.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 64.3% were married couples living together, 7.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 24.4% were non-families. 23.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.70 and the average family size was 3.17.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.9% under the age of 18, 8.8% from 18 to 24, 30.2% from 25 to 44, 21.5% from 45 to 64, and 13.6% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 98.8 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 100.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $32,679, and the median income for a family was $39,444. Males had a median income of $34,444 versus $19,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,832.  About 3.9% of families and 8.5% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.9% of those under age 18 and 9.0% of those age 65 or over.
