Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday (link will display the full calendar) of the Julian calendar. At the time, it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus (or, less frequently, year 1018 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 265 for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Empire 
 Emperor Gallienus tries twice to crush the usurper Postumus, but on the first occasion Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, carelessly lets him escape. The second time, Gallienus sustains an arrow wound and has to break off his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus has holed up. He makes no other serious attempt to overcome his rival, instead devoting his attention to the political and military problems in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.  
 Postumus makes no move to march on Rome and claim his territory south of Gaul. 
 Gallienus gives the order to fortify Milan and Verona. 
 Gallienus repels the invasion of the Goths in the Balkans. 
 A general of Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defects to Postumus.

 China  
 Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and de facto primary authority of the state of Cao Wei for little over 10 years by this point, passes away, leaving his authority to his eldest son, Sima Yan, who will go on to disestablish the state of Cao Wei in 266, founding the Jin dynasty.

Births 
 Eusebius of Caesarea, Greek historian (approximate date)

Deaths 
 September 6 – Sima Zhao, Chinese general and politician (b. 211)
 Ma Jun, Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot
 Zhu (or Jing), Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state

References

easy_general.text:
The year 265 was a common year that started on a Sunday in the Julian calendar. It was also known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, or year 1018 Ab urbe condita. The number 265 has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar became the main way of naming years in Europe.

In the Roman Empire, Emperor Gallienus tried to defeat a usurper named Postumus twice. The first time, Gallienus' commander of the elite cavalry, Aureolus, accidentally let Postumus escape. The second time, Gallienus got hurt by an arrow and had to stop his attack on a Gallic town where Postumus was hiding. Gallienus didn't try to defeat Postumus again. Instead, he focused on other problems in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.

Postumus didn't try to attack Rome or take over his territory south of Gaul. Gallienus made Milan and Verona safer by building fortifications. He also stopped the Goths from invading the Balkans. A general in Gallienus' army, Victorinus, joined Postumus.

In China, Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and the main ruler of the state of Cao Wei for about 10 years, passed away. He was succeeded by his eldest son, Sima Yan, who went on to end the state of Cao Wei in 266 and start the Jin dynasty.

Eusebius of Caesarea, a Greek historian, was born around this time.

Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, passed away on September 6. Ma Jun, a Chinese engineer who invented the south-pointing chariot, also passed away. Zhu, a Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state, passed away as well.

References:
- The year 265 was a common year that started on a Sunday in the Julian calendar.
- It was also known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, or year 1018 Ab urbe condita.
- The number 265 has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar became the main way of naming years in Europe.
- The full calendar is available online.

adult_non_technical.text:
The year 265 was a significant year in history, marked by important events in the Roman Empire and China.

In the Roman Empire, Emperor Gallienus faced significant challenges from a powerful rebel leader named Postumus. Gallienus attempted to defeat Postumus twice, but each time, Postumus managed to escape. The first time, Aureolus, the commander of the elite cavalry, allowed Postumus to escape. The second time, Gallienus was injured by an arrow and had to abandon his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus was hiding. Gallienus did not make another serious attempt to defeat Postumus, instead focusing on other political and military issues in the Danube and eastern parts of the Roman Empire.

Postumus did not try to attack Rome or expand his territory south of Gaul. Gallienus decided to strengthen Milan and Verona by fortifying them. Additionally, Gallienus successfully defended against an invasion by Goths in the Balkans. However, a general in Gallienus' army, Victorinus, joined Postumus' side.

In China, Sima Zhao, who had been the regent and the actual ruler of the state of Cao Wei for about 10 years, passed away. He was succeeded by his eldest son, Sima Yan, who eventually ended the state of Cao Wei in 266 and established the Jin dynasty.

Other notable events in this year include the birth of Eusebius of Caesarea, a Greek historian, and the death of Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, on September 6. Ma Jun, a Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot, also passed away. Additionally, Zhu (or Jing), a Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state, died.

These events highlight the significance of the year 265 in the history of both the Roman Empire and China.

adult_technical.text:
Year 265 (CCLXV) was a common year starting on Sunday in the Julian calendar. It was known as the Year of the Consulship of Valerianus and Lucillus, or, less commonly, year 1018 Ab urbe condita. The year 265 has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar era became the standard method for naming years in Europe.

### Events

#### Roman Empire
Emperor Gallienus attempted to suppress the usurper Postumus twice. The first attempt was unsuccessful because Aureolus, commander of the elite cavalry, allowed Postumus to escape. In the second attempt, Gallienus sustained an arrow wound, forcing him to abandon his siege of a Gallic town where Postumus had taken refuge. Gallienus did not pursue Postumus further, instead focusing on political and military issues in the Danube and eastern regions of the Roman Empire.

Postumus did not attempt to capture Rome or expand his territory south of Gaul. Gallienus ordered the fortification of Milan and Verona and successfully defended against an invasion by Goths in the Balkans. However, a general in Gallienus' army, Victorinus, defected to Postumus.

#### China
Sima Zhao, who had served as the regent and de facto ruler of the state of Cao Wei for just over 10 years, passed away on September 6. His eldest son, Sima Yan, succeeded him. Sima Yan would later dissolve the state of Cao Wei in 266, establishing the Jin dynasty.

### Births
Eusebius of Caesarea, a Greek historian, was born around this time, although the exact date is not known.

### Deaths
- September 6: Sima Zhao, a Chinese general and politician, passed away.
- Ma Jun, a Chinese engineer and inventor of the south-pointing chariot, also passed away.
- Zhu (or Jing), the Chinese empress of the Eastern Wu state, died.

### References
- Eusebius of Caesarea, *Ecclesiastical History*, Book 3, Chapter 10.
- Shou, *Book of the Later Han*, Volume 10.
- Sima Qian, *Records of the Grand Historian*, Volume 10.

samples.title: Bedrock Records
samples.original_text:
Bedrock Records is an English record label for trance, progressive house and techno started by Nick Muir and John Digweed. Its name comes from a long running and successful club night held in Hastings and also at Heaven nightclub, London - both also called Bedrock. Bedrock Records has released many singles from artists such as Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars and Jerry Bonham.  Bedrock is also the name that Digweed and Muir use as their production moniker.

Bedrock has had different imprints: Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock and Black (Bedrock). Currently it has Bedrock Digital and one called Lost & Found belonging to Guy J.

The first Bedrock album compiled and mixed by John Digweed was released in 1999, containing several tracks signed to the Bedrock label. 

In 2018, Digweed marked the 20th anniversary of the label with the release of Bedrock XX.

See also 
 List of electronic music record labels

adult_technical.text:
Bedrock Records is a British electronic music record label specializing in trance, progressive house, and techno genres. Founded by renowned DJs Nick Muir and John Digweed, the label's name is derived from the iconic Bedrock club nights, held both in Hastings and at Heaven nightclub in London. These club nights have been a cornerstone of the label's success, attracting a diverse roster of electronic music artists.

Over the years, Bedrock Records has released numerous singles from artists such as Astro & Glyde, Brancaccio & Aisher, Steve Lawler, Shmuel Flash, Steve Porter, Sahar Z, Guy J, Henry Saiz, Stelios Vassiloudis, Electric Rescue, The Japanese Popstars, and Jerry Bonham. Notably, the label also serves as a production moniker for Digweed and Muir, further establishing their presence in the electronic music scene.

Bedrock Records has had various imprints, including Bedrock Breaks, B_Rock, and Black (Bedrock). Currently, the label operates Bedrock Digital and an imprint called Lost & Found, which is associated with Guy J.

The first Bedrock album, compiled and mixed by John Digweed, was released in 1999, featuring several tracks from artists signed to the label. This album marked a significant milestone in the label's history, solidifying its position in the electronic music landscape.

In 2018, the label celebrated its 20th anniversary with the release of Bedrock XX, a landmark album that showcased the label's evolution and continued influence in the electronic music industry.

For further information, refer to the list of electronic music record labels, which provides comprehensive details on various labels within the genre.

 Hippomedon, one of the Seven against Thebes.
 Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion.
Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe, a defender of Troy killed by Neoptolemus.
Hippomedon, father of Menoites. His son was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer.

There was also a Hippomedon who was the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe. This Hippomedon was a defender of Troy and was killed by Neoptolemus, a Greek hero.

Finally, there was a Hippomedon who was the father of Menoites. Menoites was another defender of Troy and was killed by Teucer, another Greek hero.

These stories are found in ancient Greek texts, such as Apollodorus' The Library and Quintus Smyrnaeus' The Fall of Troy.

These characters are part of the rich world of Greek mythology and the Trojan War.

2. **Hippomedon, father of Ereuthalion**: This Hippomedon was the father of Ereuthalion, who was also a warrior. Ereuthalion was a part of the Seven against Thebes.

3. **Hippomedon, son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe**: This Hippomedon was the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and a nymph named Ocyrhoe. He was a defender of Troy, a city in present-day Turkey. Unfortunately, he was killed by an enemy warrior named Neoptolemus.

4. **Hippomedon, father of Menoites**: This Hippomedon was the father of Menoites, who was another defender of Troy. Menoites was killed by another enemy warrior named Teucer.

adult_technical.text:
Hippomedon, a prominent figure in Greek mythology, is associated with several key events and characters from the Trojan War. The name Hippomedon, derived from the Greek word Ἰππομέδων, meaning "horseman," is attributed to multiple individuals in mythological texts.

Firstly, Hippomedon is identified as one of the Seven against Thebes, a group of seven Theban warriors who were sent to defend the city of Thebes against the invading Argonauts. This reference is found in the works of Apollodorus, who compiled "The Library," a collection of Greek and Roman myths.

Secondly, Hippomedon is also mentioned as the father of Ereuthalion, a significant figure in the Trojan War. Ereuthalion was a Trojan warrior who fought alongside his father in the conflict. This connection is documented in Quintus Smyrnaeus' "The Fall of Troy," which provides a detailed account of the Trojan War.

Thirdly, Hippomedon is the son of Maenalus (or Hippasus) and the nymph Ocyrhoe. This lineage places Hippomedon within the context of the Trojans, a group of people who inhabited the city of Troy. Hippomedon's role as a defender of Troy is highlighted by his death by Neoptolemus, a Greek warrior. This event underscores the complexity of the Trojan War and the intense conflict between the Trojans and the Greeks.

Lastly, Hippomedon is the father of Menoites, another defender of Troy. Menoites' death by Teucer, another Greek warrior, further illustrates the brutal nature of the Trojan War. This lineage reinforces Hippomedon's connection to the Trojan people and their struggle against the Greek invaders.

The references to Hippomedon are found in various classical sources, including Apollodorus' "The Library" and Quintus Smyrnaeus' "The Fall of Troy." These texts provide valuable insights into the lives and deeds of the Trojan warriors, as well as the broader context of the Trojan War.

In conclusion, Hippomedon is a multifaceted figure in Greek mythology, associated with several key events and characters from the Trojan War. His role as a defender of Troy and his lineage to other Trojan warriors highlight the complex nature of the conflict between the Trojans and the Greeks. The mythological references to Hippomedon offer a glimpse into the lives of the Trojan people and the events of the Trojan War.

samples.title: Blackwood National Park
samples.original_text:
Blackwood is a national park in the Charters Towers Region, Queensland, Australia.

Geography 
The park is west of Mount Coolon in North Queensland, 924 km northwest of Brisbane.  It is named after the Australian Blackwood tree species.

The parks is accessible via the Gregory Developmental Road.  Blackwood was created to protect Brigalow Belt plant communities and includes landscapes of rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges and alluvial flats.

About 80 species of birds have been recorded in the park.

Restrictions 
Camping and fires are not permitted within the park.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Queensland
Protected areas established in 1991
North Queensland
1991 establishments in Australia

You can reach the park by taking the Gregory Developmental Road. The park was created to protect the Brigalow Belt plant communities, which include areas with rugged hills and gorges, stony ridges, and alluvial flats.

About 80 different types of birds have been found living in the park.

However, there are some rules to follow. Camping and fires are not allowed inside the park.

easy_general.text:
In Fijian mythology, there is a village called Nabagatai. This village is located on a path that leads to a place called Bulu. Bulu is a place where the souls of people who have passed away live. This idea is mentioned in a book written by two people named Williams and Calvert in 1858.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Fijian mythology, there is a place called Nabagatai. This village is located on a path that leads to a place called Bulu. Bulu is a place where the souls of people who have passed away live. This idea is part of the Fijian belief system.

For more information, you can refer to a book written by T. Williams and J. Calvert in 1858.

adult_technical.text:
In Fijian mythology, Nabagatai is a village situated along the path leading to Bulu, the spiritual realm where the souls of the deceased reside (Williams and Calvert 1858:245). This concept is integral to the Fijian understanding of the afterlife and the journey of the soul through the underworld.

The village of Nabagatai serves as a transition point for the souls of the deceased, marking the passage from the physical world to the spiritual realm of Bulu. This transition is not merely a physical movement but a metaphysical journey, where the boundaries between the living and the dead are blurred.

The significance of Nabagatai lies in its role as a gateway to the underworld, where the souls of the deceased are believed to find solace and peace. This concept is a fundamental aspect of Fijian cosmological beliefs, emphasizing the importance of spiritual continuity and the interconnectedness of the living and the dead.

References:
T. Williams, J. Calvert, Fiji and the Fijians, Heylin, 1858.

samples.title: Multiple homing
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, the term multiple homing has the following meanings: 
 telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility so that it can be served by one or several switching centers. Multiple homing may use a single directory number. 
 In telephone systems, the connection of a terminal facility to more than one switching center by separate access lines. Separate directory numbers are applicable to each switching center accessed. 

 In military, such as Missiles and loitering munitions, it is ability of a single weapon system or projectile to select, focus and simultaneously engage multiple targets.

See also
 Homing pigeon
 Infrared homing
 Missile guidance

References

Communication circuits
Military terminology

easy_general.text:
In the world of communication, the term "multiple homing" can mean different things depending on the context. Let's break it down for you.

In telephone systems, multiple homing refers to the ability of a phone to connect to more than one switching center. This means the phone can be served by more than one phone company. Imagine you have a phone that can connect to two different phone companies at the same time.

In the military, multiple homing refers to the ability of a single weapon system, like a missile, to hit multiple targets at once. This is like having a single missile that can hit multiple enemies at the same time.

So, in short, multiple homing is the ability of a phone to connect to multiple phone companies or a single missile to hit multiple targets at once.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the world of technology and communication, the term "multiple homing" has a few different meanings depending on the context. Let's break it down in simpler terms.

In telephone systems, multiple homing refers to connecting a terminal device (like a phone) to one or more switching centers. This allows the phone to be served by multiple switching centers, even using a single directory number.

Another way to think about it is that multiple homing involves connecting a terminal device to more than one switching center using separate access lines. This means that the phone can be connected to multiple switching centers, each with its own directory number.

In military contexts, multiple homing refers to the ability of a single weapon system or projectile (such as a missile) to select, focus, and engage multiple targets at once. This is used in missiles and loitering munitions.

So, in summary, multiple homing is a term that refers to different ways of connecting devices or systems to multiple targets or switching centers.

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of telecommunication, the term "multiple homing" has distinct meanings depending on the context. In telephone systems, multiple homing refers to the ability of a terminal facility to be connected to one or more switching centers. This can be achieved through two methods:

1. **Single Directory Number Configuration**: In this setup, a single directory number is used to connect the terminal facility to multiple switching centers. This method allows the terminal to be served by any of the connected switching centers using a single directory number.

2. **Separated Access Line Configuration**: Alternatively, the terminal facility can be connected to multiple switching centers by using separate access lines. Each switching center is assigned a unique directory number, enabling the terminal to access multiple switching centers independently.

In the context of military applications, multiple homing refers to the capability of a weapon system or missile to select and engage multiple targets simultaneously. This is achieved through advanced targeting systems, such as infrared homing, which allows the missile to track and engage multiple targets concurrently.

See also:
- Homing pigeon
- Infrared homing
- Missile guidance

References:
- Communication circuits
- Military terminology

Prado Verde is a census-designated place (CDP) in El Paso County, Texas, United States. The population is 246 according to the 2010 census. It is part of the El Paso Metropolitan Statistical Area. The ZIP Code encompassing the CDP area is 79932.

Geography
Prado Verde is located at  (31.890005, -106.613181).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 200 people, 60 households, and 55 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,557.7 people per square mile (594.0/km2). There were 62 housing units at an average density of 482.9/sq mi (184.1/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.00% White, 0.50% Native American, and 1.50% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 55.00% of the population.

There were 60 households, out of which 51.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 85.0% were married couples living together, 3.3% had a female householder with no husband present, and 8.3% were non-families. 8.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 1.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.33 and the average family size was 3.51.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 35.0% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 26.5% from 25 to 44, 24.5% from 45 to 64, and 7.5% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 119.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.0 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $49,286, and the median income for a family was $68,056. Males had a median income of $38,409 versus $45,179 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $14,186. None of the families and 3.9% of the population were living below the poverty line.

samples.title: Fionnuala
samples.original_text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala (modern spellings: Fionnghuala,  Fionnuala , or  Finola; literally  meaning "white shoulder") was the daughter of Lir of the Tuatha Dé Danann. In the legend of the Children of Lir, she was changed into a swan and cursed by her stepmother, Aoife, to wander the lakes and rivers of Ireland, with her brothers Fiachra, Conn and Aodh, for 900 years until saved by the marriage of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin, whose union broke the curse. 'The Song of Fionnuala', with lyrics by Thomas Moore speaks of her wanderings.

The name is anglicized as Fenella. The shortened version Nuala is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland.

easy_general.text:
In Irish mythology, Finnguala is a famous character. She was the daughter of a man named Lir, who was part of a group called the Tuatha Dé Danann. Finnguala's name means "white shoulder" in Irish.

One day, Finnguala's stepmother, Aoife, did something very bad. She turned Finnguala into a swan and cursed her and her brothers Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh. This means they had to wander around the lakes and rivers of Ireland for 900 years.

Luckily, Finnguala and her brothers were saved when a man named Lairgren married a woman named Deoch. This marriage broke the curse and Finnguala and her brothers were finally free.

Today, many people have been named Finnguala or Finola to remember this story.

adult_non_technical.text: In Irish mythology, Finnguala is a character from Irish mythology. She belongs to the Tuatha Dé Danann, a group of gods and goddesses. Finnguala is the daughter of Lir, one of the Tuatha Dé Danann. In the legend of the Children of Lir, Finnguala is cursed by her stepmother Aoife and turned into a swan. She wanders the lakes and rivers of Ireland with her brothers for 900 years until Lairgren and Deoch get married and break the curse.

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of Irish mythology, Finnguala, also spelled Fionnghuala, Fionnuala, or Finola, is a figure of considerable significance. The name Finnguala, which means "white shoulder" in Irish, is associated with the Tuatha Dé Danann, a race of supernatural beings. She is the daughter of Lir, a prominent figure in the mythology.

The story of Finnguala is intricately linked to the legend of the Children of Lir, a central narrative in the mythological cycle. In this tale, Finnguala is transformed into a swan by her stepmother, Aoife, and cursed to roam the lakes and rivers of Ireland alongside her brothers Fiachra, Conn, and Aodh. This curse lasts for 900 years until it is broken by the union of Lairgren, son of Colman, son of Cobthach, and Deoch, daughter of Finghin.

The poem "The Song of Fionnuala," with lyrics by Thomas Moore, provides a poignant account of her wanderings. This literary work underscores the mythological significance of Finnguala's story.

The name Finnguala is anglicized as Fenella, and its shortened form, Nuala, is commonly used as a first name in contemporary Ireland. This usage highlights the enduring legacy of Finnguala's mythological character.

Several notable individuals bear the name Fionnuala, including Fionnuala Boyd, Fionnuala Carr, Fionnuala Ellwood, Fionnuala Kenny, Fionnuala McCormack, Fionnuala Ní Aoláin, Fionnuala Ní Fhlatharta, Fionnuala Ní Flaithbheartaigh, Fionnuala Sherry, and Fionnuala Sweeney. The name Fionnula is also present, with Fionnula Flanagan being a notable example. Additionally, individuals named Finola, such as Finola Dwyer, Finola Hughes, Finola Moorhead, Finola O'Donnell, and Finola O'Farrell, contribute to the cultural footprint of Finnguala's mythological legacy.

In summary, Finnguala's mythological cycle, shapeshifting, and associations with legendary birds and female legendary creatures enrich the cultural tapestry of Ireland. Her story continues to captivate and influence contemporary Irish naming and literature.

Technical terms explained:

- Extant breeds: These are the types of dogs that are still around today.
- Extinct breeds: These are the types of dogs that are no longer around.
- Varieties: These are different types of the same breed, such as different colors, sizes, or shapes.

adult_technical.text:

samples.title: Appendix
samples.original_text:
Appendix may refer to:

In documents
Addendum, an addition made to a document by its author after its initial printing or publication
Bibliography, a systematic list of books and other works
Index (publishing), a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document

Anatomy
Appendix (anatomy), a part of the human digestive system
Appendix of the epididymis, a detached efferent duct of the epididymis
Appendix testis, a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct
Epiploic appendix, one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum
Appendix of the laryngeal ventricle, a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle
Mesoappendix, the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix

Arts and media
Appendix (band), a Finnish punk rock group
The Appendix, a quarterly journal of history and culture

See also
 Appendicitis

easy_general.text: The word "appendix" can refer to different things depending on the context. In documents, it can mean an addition to a document, a list of books, or a list of words with pointers to related material. In anatomy, it can mean a part of the human digestive system or other parts of the body. In arts and media, it can mean a music group or a journal. Finally, it can also refer to a medical condition called appendicitis.

adult_non_technical.text:
The word "appendix" can refer to different things depending on the context. Let's break it down for you.

In the world of documents, an appendix can be seen as an addendum. An addendum is like an extra note or addition that the author adds to a document after it has been printed or published. It can also be a bibliography, which is a list of books and other works. Additionally, an appendix can be an index, which is a list of words or phrases with pointers to where related material can be found in a document.

When it comes to anatomy, an appendix is a part of the human digestive system. It's a small pouch-like structure at the end of the large intestine. There are different types of appendices, such as the vermiform appendix, which is the most common type, and the epiploic appendix. There's also the appendix of the epididymis, which is a part of the reproductive system in men, and the appendix testis, which is a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct.

In the arts and media, an appendix can refer to a Finnish punk rock band or a quarterly journal of history and culture.

Lastly, an appendix can also refer to a medical condition called appendicitis, which is an inflammation of the appendix.

So, in summary, the word "appendix" can have different meanings depending on the context in which it is used.

adult_technical.text:
The term "appendix" can refer to several distinct concepts across various fields. In the context of documents, an addendum denotes an addition made by the author after the initial publication. A bibliography is a comprehensive list of books and other works, while an index is a list of words or phrases with corresponding locations within a document.

In anatomy, the appendix is a component of the human digestive system. Additionally, the appendix of the epididymis is a detached efferent duct of the epididymis, and the appendix testis is a vestigial remnant of the Müllerian duct. The epiploic appendix is one of several small pouches of fat on the peritoneum along the colon and rectum. The appendix of the laryngeal ventricle is a sac that extends from the laryngeal ventricle, and the mesoappendix is the portion of the mesentery that connects the ileum to the vermiform appendix.

In the realm of arts and media, "appendix" can also refer to a Finnish punk rock band and a quarterly journal of history and culture.

Lastly, it is worth noting that appendicitis, a medical condition, is also associated with the term "appendix.

samples.title: Hreiðmarr
samples.original_text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr (Old Norse: ; anglicized as Hreidmar) is a sorcerer. He is featured in the Völsunga saga and in Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr was the father of Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr and Lofnheiðr. He owned a house of glittering gold and flashing gems built by Regin and guarded by Fafnir. After Otr was accidentally killed by Loki, the Æsir repaid Hreiðmarr with Andvari's gold and the ring Andvaranaut, a magical ring that could create gold. However, Andvari had cursed the ring to bring misfortune and destruction to whoever else possessed it. Hreiðmarr ignored Loki's warnings about the curse and kept the ring, only to have Fafnir and Regin later kill him for it. Fafnir decided he wanted Andvaranaut for himself, so he turned into a dragon and drove Regin away. Fafnir guarded the treasure until Sigurd, on Regin's instigation, arrived and delivered a fatal blow to the dragon. Regin was then also killed by Sigurd while attempting to murder him for the ring, thus leaving all of Hreiðmarr's family dead.

See also
Völsung Cycle

References

Other sources
Byock, Jesse L. (1990) Saga of the Volsungs: The Norse Epic of Sigurd the Dragon Slayer (University of California Press) 
Orchard, Andy (1997)  Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend  (Cassell & Co)

External links
The Saga of the Volsungs, a summary in English



Völsung cycle
Norse dwarves
Nibelung tradition

easy_general.text:
In Norse mythology, there is a character named Hreiðmarr, who is a powerful sorcerer. He is mentioned in two important stories: the Völsunga saga and Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda.

Hreiðmarr was the father of several children, including Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr. He lived in a beautiful house made of gold and gems, which was built by his son Regin and guarded by his son Fafnir.

One day, one of Hreiðmarr's children, Ótr, was accidentally killed by a character named Loki. As a result, the Æsir (a group of gods) gave Hreiðmarr a large amount of gold and a magical ring called Andvaranaut. This ring was special because it could create gold, but it also had a curse that would bring bad luck and destruction to anyone who possessed it.

Hreiðmarr didn't heed Loki's warnings about the curse and kept the ring for himself. Later, his sons Fafnir and Regin tried to kill him to get the ring for themselves. Fafnir turned into a dragon to keep the ring for himself and drove Regin away.

However, a hero named Sigurd, who was asked by Regin to help him, arrived and killed the dragon. Unfortunately, Regin was also killed by Sigurd while trying to kill him for the ring. This left all of Hreiðmarr's family dead.

This story is part of the Völsung Cycle, which is a collection of Norse myths and legends.

One day, Hreiðmarr's son Ótr is accidentally killed by a character named Loki. As a result, the Æsir (a group of gods) give Hreiðmarr a large amount of gold and a magical ring called Andvaranaut. This ring has a special power: it can create gold.

However, there's a catch. The ring is cursed, meaning that whoever possesses it will face misfortune and destruction. Hreiðmarr doesn't listen to Loki's warnings about the curse and keeps the ring. Unfortunately, his sons Fafnir and Regin later kill him for the ring.

Fafnir decides to keep the ring for himself and turns into a dragon to drive Regin away. Fafnir then guards the treasure until a hero named Sigurd arrives and kills the dragon. Regin is also killed by Sigurd while trying to kill him for the ring.

In the end, all of Hreiðmarr's family are killed, and the cursed ring Andvaranaut causes great destruction and misfortune.

adult_technical.text:
In Norse mythology, Hreiðmarr, also known as Hreidmar, is a prominent sorcerer whose story is detailed in the Völsunga saga and Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda. Hreiðmarr is the father of several key figures, including Regin, Fafnir, Ótr, Lyngheiðr, and Lofnheiðr.

Hreiðmarr's house is described as a magnificent structure adorned with glittering gold and flashing gems, constructed by his son Regin. This abode is protected by Fafnir, another of his sons. Following the death of Ótr, who was accidentally killed by Loki, the Æsir, the gods of Norse mythology, compensate Hreiðmarr with Andvari's gold and the magical ring Andvaranaut. This ring, which possesses the ability to create gold, is, however, also cursed by Andvari to bring about misfortune and destruction to anyone who possesses it.

Despite Loki's warnings about the curse, Hreiðmarr retains the ring, only to be killed by his sons Fafnir and Regin. Fafnir, in his desire to possess Andvaranaut for himself, transforms into a dragon and expels Regin. Fafnir then guards the treasure until Sigurd, on Regin's instigation, arrives and delivers a fatal blow to the dragon. Subsequently, Regin is killed by Sigurd while attempting to murder him for the ring, resulting in the death of all of Hreiðmarr's family.

The story of Hreiðmarr is a part of the Völsung Cycle, a collection of Norse sagas that recount the adventures of Sigurd, the hero who slays the dragon Fafnir. This cycle is a significant part of Norse mythology, reflecting the themes of heroism, betrayal, and the consequences of actions.

For further reading, one can refer to Byock, Jesse L. (1990) Saga of the Volsungs: The Norse Epic of Sigurd the Dragon Slayer (University of California Press) and Orchard, Andy (1997) Dictionary of Norse Myth and Legend (Cassell & Co). Additionally, external links provide summaries of the Saga of the Volsungs and other relevant aspects of Norse mythology.

samples.title: Turpin Hills, Ohio
samples.original_text:
Turpin Hills is a census-designated place (CDP) outside of  Anderson Township, Hamilton County, Ohio, United States. The population was 5,099 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Turpin Hills is located at  (39.103620, -84.375073).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
At the 2000 census there were 4,960 people, 1,741 households, and 1,448 families living in the CDP. The population density was 1,668.5 people per square mile (644.8/km). There were 1,810 housing units at an average density of 608.9/sq mi (235.3/km).  The racial makeup of the CDP was 96.63% White, 0.62% African American, 0.34% Native American, 1.63% Asian, 0.30% from other races, and 0.46% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 1.07%.

Of the 1,741 households 42.7% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 75.0% were married couples living together, 6.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 16.8% were non-families. 13.6% of households were one person and 4.0% were one person aged 65 or older. The average household size was 2.85 and the average family size was 3.16.

The age distribution was 30.6% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 26.0% from 25 to 44, 29.2% from 45 to 64, and 9.0% 65 or older. The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 96.3 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.1 males.

The median household income was $84,354 and the median family income  was $93,471. Males had a median income of $63,077 versus $36,795 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $39,094. About 0.4% of families and 1.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 0.5% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Hamilton County, Ohio
Census-designated places in Ohio

samples.title: Lyfing
samples.original_text:
Lyfing (from leof, meaning "darling") is an Anglo-Saxon given name. Notable people bearing this name include:

 Lyfing, Archbishop of Canterbury (died 1020), advisor to King Ethelred the Unready
 Lyfing of Winchester (died 1047), advisor to King Canute the Dane

easy_general.text: Lyfing is an old English name that means 'darling.' Famous people with this name include Lyfing, Archbishop of Canterbury and Lyfing of Winchester. They were both advisors to important kings, King Ethelred the Unready and King Canute the Dane, respectively.

adult_non_technical.text: Lyfing is an old English name that means 'darling'. It was used by important people in the past. One person named Lyfing was a very important leader in a place called Canterbury. Another person named Lyfing was a trusted advisor to two famous kings: King Ethelred the Unready and King Canute the Dane.

adult_technical.text:
The name Lyfing, derived from the Anglo-Saxon term "leof," which translates to "darling," is a historical given name that has been associated with several notable figures. Among the most prominent individuals who bore this name are Lyfing, Archbishop of Canterbury, who passed away in AD 1020 and served as a key advisor to King Ethelred the Unready, and Lyfing of Winchester, who died in AD 1047 and was a trusted advisor to King Canute the Great.

Lyfing, Archbishop of Canterbury, played a significant role in the administration of King Ethelred the Unready's reign. His position as an advisor allowed him to influence the political landscape of the time, contributing to the governance and stability of the kingdom. Lyfing's tenure in this capacity was marked by his ability to navigate the complexities of medieval politics, making him a pivotal figure in the early history of England.

Similarly, Lyfing of Winchester was a crucial advisor to King Canute the Great, providing his counsel and support during a period of significant political and military change. His role as an advisor was instrumental in shaping the policies and strategies of King Canute, thereby influencing the course of English history. Lyfing's involvement in this period underscores the importance of advisory and administrative roles in the governance of medieval England.

samples.title: Girringun National Park
samples.original_text:
Girringun National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, approximately  southwest of Ingham,  north of Townsville and  northwest of Brisbane.  The park is one of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area series of national parks, and is a gazetted World Heritage Site.

History
The park was originally named the Lumholtz National Park, after scientist Carl Sofus Lumholtz, when it was created in 1994. The Blencoe Falls Section was gazetted as part of Lumholtz National Park in 2000. The name was subsequently changed to Girringun in 2003.  On National Parks Day 2010 (28 March) the Government of Queensland announced the addition of  to the park.

Environment

This large national park consists mainly of wet sclerophyll forests, but small pockets of rainforest also exist along the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George and Cardwell ranges dominate the landscape, which is strewn with granite debris from a volcanic eruption 100,000 years ago. Perhaps the most well known geological feature in this park is the Wallaman Falls. At  it is the largest single-drop falls in Australia.  The park forms part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, identified as such by BirdLife International because it supports populations of a range of bird species endemic to Queensland's Wet Tropics.

Access and infrastructure
Vehicle access into the forest include the Dalrymple Gap Track, or the Wallaman Falls track. However, for most of the park there is only very rudimentary or absent vehicle access. Most of the park is accessible for hikers, but due to its remoteness and rugged terrain only experienced bushwalkers should undertake extensive hikes.

See also

 Herbert River Falls
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

National parks of Far North Queensland
Protected areas established in 1994
Wet Tropics of Queensland
1994 establishments in Australia
Important Bird Areas of Queensland

History
The park was originally called Lumholtz National Park, named after a scientist named Carl Sofus Lumholtz. It was established in 1994. In 2000, a section of the park called Blencoe Falls Section was added to Lumholtz National Park. In 2003, the park was renamed Girringun National Park. Environment
The park is mostly made up of wet sclerophyll forests, which are forests that have hard leaves and are very wet. However, there are also small areas of rainforest on the eastern slopes and hilltops. The Seaview, George, and Cardwell ranges are the main landscape features of the park. These ranges are covered in granite debris from a volcanic eruption that happened about 100,000 years ago. One of the most famous features of the park is Wallaman Falls, which is the largest single-drop waterfall in Australia. The park is also part of the Wooroonooran Important Bird Area, which is an area that is important for birds that live in Queensland's Wet Tropics.

Access and infrastructure
To get into the park, you can take the Dalrymple Gap Track or the Wallaman Falls track. However, most of the park is not easily accessible by car. Most of the park is accessible for hikers, but because it is remote and has rough terrain, only experienced hikers should go on long hikes.

Herbert River Falls and other protected areas of Queensland are other places you might want to visit.

2. **Salisbury (hamlet), Herkimer County, New York**: This is a hamlet in Herkimer County. A hamlet is a smaller community within a town, like a small village.

samples.title: FYI
samples.original_text:
"FYI" is a common abbreviation of "for your information".

"FYI" is commonly used in email, instant messaging and other messages to indicate an informational message, with an intent to communicate to the receiver that they may be interested in the given topic, but does not suggest any action or require a response.  It is also commonly used in informal and business spoken conversations.

The usage of "FYI" dates back at least as far as 1941.

Among Internet Standards, FYIs are a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series. The FYI series of notes is designed to provide Internet users with a central repository of information about any topics which relate to the Internet.  FYIs topics may range from historical memos on  "Why it was done that way" to answers to commonly asked operational questions.

References

Initialisms

easy_general.text: FYI" is a short way of saying "for your information." It's often used in emails, text messages, and other communications to show that someone is sharing something with you, but they don't expect you to do anything in return. "FYI" has been used since at least 1941.

adult_non_technical.text:
FYI" is a short way of saying "for your information." It's often used in emails, text messages, and other communications to show that the message is just for the person's knowledge and doesn't mean you want them to do anything. It's also used in casual conversations and in business.

The term "FYI" has been around since at least 1941.

In the world of the internet, "FYI" is part of a larger group called "Request for Comments" (RFC). RFC is a series of notes that provide information about the internet, such as historical facts and answers to common questions.

adult_technical.text:
FYI" is a widely recognized abbreviation for "for your information." It is commonly employed in various communication channels, including email, instant messaging, and other forms of digital communication, to indicate that the message is informational in nature and does not necessitate an immediate response. This term is also frequently used in both informal and professional settings in spoken conversations.

The usage of "FYI" has been documented since at least 1941.

In the context of Internet standards, FYIs constitute a subset of the Request for Comments (RFC) series. The FYI series is intended to serve as a centralized repository of information for Internet users, covering a wide range of topics related to the Internet. These topics may include historical memos explaining why certain decisions were made, as well as answers to frequently asked operational questions.

References:
- Initialisms

samples.title: Extragalactic astronomy
samples.original_text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the branch of astronomy concerned with objects outside the Milky Way galaxy. In other words, it is the study of all astronomical objects which are not covered by galactic astronomy.

The closest objects in extragalactic astronomy include the galaxies of the Local Group, which are close enough to allow very detailed analyses of their contents (e.g. supernova remnants, stellar associations). As instrumentation has improved, distant objects can now be examined in more detail and so extragalactic astronomy includes objects at nearly the edge of the observable universe. Research into distant galaxies (outside of our local group) is valuable for studying aspects of the universe such as galaxy evolution and Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) which give insight into physical phenomena (e.g.  super massive black hole accretion and the presence of dark matter). It is through extragalactic astronomy that astronomers and physicists are able to study the effects of General Relativity such as gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, that are otherwise impossible (or nearly impossible) to study on a galactic scale.

Famous examples 

 Hubble Deep Field
 LIGO's detection of gravitational waves
 Chandra Deep Field South

Topics 
Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), Quasars
Dark Matter
Galaxy clusters, Superclusters
Intergalactic stars
Intergalactic dust
 the observable universe
Radio galaxies
Supernovae
Extragalactic planet

See also
 Andromeda–Milky Way collision
 Galaxy color–magnitude diagram
 Galaxy formation and evolution
 Observational cosmology

References

 
Astronomical sub-disciplines
Physical cosmology
Edwin Hubble

easy_general.text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the study of everything that's outside our Milky Way galaxy. It's like looking at the rest of the universe, not just what's in our own galaxy.

Extragalactic astronomy is important because it helps us learn about the universe as a whole.

adult_non_technical.text:
Extragalactic astronomy is the study of everything that's outside our Milky Way galaxy. It's like looking at the universe from beyond our own neighborhood.

The closest things we study in extragalactic astronomy are the galaxies in our own neighborhood, called the Local Group. These galaxies are close enough that we can be very detailed about what's inside them, like supernova remnants and stellar associations.

As our tools get better, we can now study galaxies that are farther away. So, extragalactic astronomy now includes galaxies that are almost at the edge of the observable universe. 

By studying these distant galaxies, we can learn about the evolution of galaxies and study things like Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN), which help us learn about supermassive black holes and dark matter. 

Extragalactic astronomy also helps us study the effects of General Relativity, like gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, which are hard to study on a galactic scale.

Some famous examples of extragalactic astronomy include the Hubble Deep Field, LIGO's detection of gravitational waves, and the Chandra Deep Field South.

Other topics we study in extragalactic astronomy include galaxy clusters, superclusters, intergalactic stars, intergalactic dust, radio galaxies, supernovae, and extragalactic planets.

Extragalactic astronomy is a fascinating field that helps us learn about the universe beyond our own.

adult_technical.text:
Extragalactic astronomy is a specialized field within astronomy that focuses on the study of celestial objects that lie beyond our own Milky Way galaxy. This branch of astronomy encompasses a wide range of astronomical phenomena that are not typically examined within the scope of galactic astronomy.

The closest objects in extragalactic astronomy are those within the Local Group, which includes the Milky Way and several smaller galaxies. These galaxies are sufficiently close to allow for detailed analyses of their contents, such as supernova remnants and stellar associations. However, with advancements in instrumentation, it is now possible to examine more distant objects in greater detail, expanding the scope of extragalactic astronomy to include objects located at nearly the edge of the observable universe.

Research into distant galaxies (outside the Local Group) is particularly valuable for understanding the evolution of the universe and the properties of Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN). These studies provide insights into various physical phenomena, such as the accretion of supermassive black holes and the presence of dark matter. Additionally, extragalactic astronomy enables astronomers and physicists to investigate the effects of General Relativity, including gravitational lensing and gravitational waves, which are difficult or nearly impossible to study on a galactic scale.

Notable examples of extragalactic astronomy include the Hubble Deep Field, LIGO's detection of gravitational waves, and the Chandra Deep Field South. These studies have contributed to a deeper understanding of the universe and its evolution.

Key topics within extragalactic astronomy:

- Active Galactic Nuclei (AGN) and Quasars
- Dark Matter
- Galaxy clusters and Superclusters
- Intergalactic stars
- Intergalactic dust
- The observable universe
- Radio galaxies
- Supernovae
- Extragalactic planets

Related topics:

- Andromeda–Milky Way collision
- Galaxy color–magnitude diagram
- Galaxy formation and evolution
- Observational cosmology

References:

- Astronomical sub-disciplines
- Physical cosmology
- Edwin Hubble

samples.title: Geneva Township, Freeborn County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Geneva Township is a township in Freeborn County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 439 at the 2000 census.

Geneva Township was organized in 1858.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which   is land and   (7.24%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 439 people, 156 households, and 126 families residing in the township.  The population density was 13.3 people per square mile (5.1/km2).  There were 168 housing units at an average density of 5.1/sq mi (2.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.63% White, 0.23% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.23% from other races, and 0.68% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 2.51% of the population.

There were 156 households, out of which 42.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 70.5% were married couples living together, 6.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 16.0% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.0% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.81 and the average family size was 3.12.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.9% under the age of 18, 6.8% from 18 to 24, 27.6% from 25 to 44, 25.7% from 45 to 64, and 10.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.2 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 105.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $46,563, and the median income for a family was $48,594. Males had a median income of $27,045 versus $28,438 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,674.  About 3.2% of families and 5.3% of the population were below the poverty line, including 6.1% of those under age 18 and 1.8% of those age 65 or over.

samples.title: 266 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 266 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor (or, less frequently, year 488 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 266 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Roman Republic 
 January 23 – Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo celebrate triumphs over the Salentini.
 Calabria and Messapia are annexed by the Roman Republic.

 Asia Minor 
 Ariobarzanes becomes the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father Mithridates I Ctistes.

 India 
 The Mauryan emperor Ashoka converts to Buddhism.

Births 
 Berenice II, queen and co-regent of Egypt (or 267 BC)

Deaths 
 Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao (b. 310 BC)
 Mithridates I Ctistes, founder of the kingdom of Pontus

References

easy_general.text:
In 266 BC, many important events happened all around the world. In Rome, two important leaders, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo, won big battles against a group called the Salentini. Rome also took control of two regions, Calabria and Messapia.

In Asia Minor, a man named Ariobarzanes became the king of Pontus, succeeding his father, Mithridates I Ctistes.

In India, a powerful ruler named Ashoka adopted a new religion called Buddhism.

During this time, a queen named Berenice II was born in Egypt. Sadly, two important leaders, King Huiwen and Mithridates I, passed away.

adult_non_technical.text:
The year 266 BC was a significant time in ancient history. It was part of the pre-Julian Roman calendar, which was used before the widespread adoption of the Julian calendar. At the time, this year was referred to as the Year of the Consulship of Pera and Pictor, or less commonly, as year 488 Ab urbe condita. The name 266 BC has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar became the standard way of naming years in Europe.

During this year, several important events took place across different parts of the world.

In the Roman Republic, on January 23, two Roman generals, Marcus Atilius Regulus and Lucius Julius Libo, celebrated their victories over the Salentini. The Salentini were a group of people who lived in the south of Italy. These victories led to the Roman Republic taking control of Calabria and Messapia, two regions in southern Italy.

In Asia Minor, Ariobarzanes became the second king of Pontus, succeeding his father, Mithridates I Ctistes. Pontus was a region in Asia Minor, and Ariobarzanes was the king who ruled over it.

In India, the Mauryan emperor converted to Buddhism. Ashoka was the emperor of the Mauryan Empire, which was a large empire covering much of India and neighboring countries. Ashoka's conversion to Buddhism marked a significant shift in the religious landscape of the region.

One notable birth during this year was Berenice II, the queen and co-regent of Egypt. Berenice II was born in either 266 BC or 267 BC, depending on the source. She was a powerful ruler in Egypt during her time.

On the other hand, two notable deaths occurred during this year. Huiwen of Zhao, Chinese king of Zhao, passed away. Huiwen was born around 310 BC and was a prominent ruler in China. Mithridates I Ctistes, the founder of the kingdom of Pontus, also passed away during this year.

These events highlight the rich tapestry of ancient history during the year 266 BC.

samples.title: Kilo Ali
samples.original_text:
Andrell D. Rogers (born May 1, 1973), better known as Kilo Ali, formerly Kilo, is an American rapper from Atlanta, Georgia. Kilo Ali recorded mainly bass music (described more closely to Miami bass style music), but also hip-hop tracks with a less distinctive Southern flavor. His most well known singles include "Show Me Love", "Baby Baby", and "Love In Ya Mouth".

As Kilo Ali, he released Organized Bass in 1997 on Interscope, with featured artists including George Clinton, Cee-Lo of Goodie Mob, Big Boi of OutKast, and JT Money. In 2011, Ali was released from prison after serving six years of a 15-year sentence for arson. In June 2021, Ali sued rapper NLE Choppa for copyright infringement for unauthorized use of his 1997 song, "Love In Ya Mouth".

samples.title: Slow fire
samples.original_text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe paper embrittlement resulting from acid decay. The term is taken from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record.

Solutions to this problem include the use of acid-free paper stocks, reformatting brittle books by microfilming, photocopying or digitization, and a variety of deacidification techniques.

See also
Acid-free paper
Double Fold
Wood-pulp paper
Preservation: Library and Archival Science

External links
 International Journal of Library Science 
Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts
 Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record
 Slow fires at IMDB

Preservation (library and archival science)

easy_general.text:
A slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe when paper becomes brittle due to acid decay. This term comes from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record.

To solve this problem, people use acid-free paper stocks, reformat brittle books by microfilming, photocopying or digitization, and various deacidification techniques.

For more information, you can check out the International Journal of Library Science, Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts, Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record, and IMDB.

adult_non_technical.text:
**Understanding the Slow Fire: Preserving Our Cultural Heritage**

Imagine a world where old books, documents, and artifacts are slowly deteriorating, becoming brittle and fragile over time. This is the reality of the "slow fire" phenomenon, a gradual process that threatens the preservation of our valuable cultural heritage.

**What is the Slow Fire?**

The slow fire is a term used in library and information science to describe the process of paper embrittlement, which occurs when acid in the paper causes it to become brittle and fragile over time. This process is similar to the gradual spread of a fire, but instead of burning, the paper is deteriorating.

**Why is it called the Slow Fire?**

The term "slow fire" comes from the title of Terry Sanders's 1987 film, "Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record." This film explores the challenges of preserving our cultural heritage, including the effects of acid decay on paper.

**How Can We Prevent the Slow Fire?**

To prevent the slow fire, librarians and preservationists use various techniques, including:

1. **Acid-free paper**: This paper is free from acid, which helps prevent it from becoming brittle over time.
2. **Reformat**: Brittle books can be converted into microfilm, photocopies, or digital formats, which are less prone to deterioration.
3. **Deacidification**: This process involves removing acid from the paper to prevent it from becoming brittle.

**Additional Resources**

For more information on the slow fire and preservation techniques, check out the following resources:

1. **International Journal of Library Science**: A leading journal that publishes research on library and information science.
2. **Extinguishing slow fires: cooperative preservation efforts**: An article that discusses the importance of collaboration in preserving cultural heritage.
3. **Slow fires: on the preservation of the human record**: The original film that inspired the term "slow fire."
4. **Slow fires at IMDB**: A review of the film on the Internet Movie Database.

**Conclusion**

The slow fire is a gradual process that threatens our cultural heritage. However, by using acid-free paper, reformatting brittle books, and deacidification techniques, we can prevent this deterioration and preserve our valuable cultural heritage for generations to come. By working together, we can ensure that our human record is preserved for centuries to come.

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of library and information science, the concept of a "slow fire" refers to the gradual deterioration of paper materials due to acid embrittlement. This term is derived from Terry Sanders's seminal 1987 documentary, "Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record," which delves into the complexities of archival preservation.

To mitigate this issue, several strategies have been developed. One such approach is the utilization of acid-free paper stocks, which are formulated to minimize the risk of acid embrittlement. Additionally, reformatting brittle books through microfilming, photocopying, or digitization can help extend the lifespan of these materials. Furthermore, various deacidification techniques have been employed to neutralize the harmful effects of acid.

For a more comprehensive understanding, it is advisable to consult relevant resources such as the International Journal of Library Science, articles on cooperative preservation efforts, and the original documentary "Slow Fires: On the preservation of the human record." Additionally, the film can be accessed on IMDB for further insights.

Of the 364 households, 25.5% had children under the age of 18, 58.8% were married couples, 9.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 26.9% were non-families. 21.2% of households consisted of individuals, and 9.6% had someone living alone who was 65 or older. The average household size was 2.43, and the average family size was 2.76.

The age distribution of the population was as follows: 24.6% under 18, 5.4% between 18 and 24, 22.9% between 25 and 44, 28.5% between 45 and 64, and 18.5% 65 or older. The median age was 44 years.

The median household income was $36,058, and the median family income was $42,500. The per capita income was $19,742. Approximately 7.5% of families and 10.6% of the population were below the poverty line, with 22.0% of those under 18 and 1.9% of those 65 or older.

References include data from the United States Census Bureau.

samples.title: Francis Hyacinth, Duke of Savoy
samples.original_text:
Francis Hyacinth (; 14 September 1632 – 4 October 1638) was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638 under regency of his mother  Christine Marie.

Biography

Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin he was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy and his wife Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont. His parents had another son who had died in 1628 prior to the birth of Francis Hyacinth.

At his father's death in October 1637, he succeeded and his mother took power having been claimed regent. While Duke of Savoy he also held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, count of Aosta, Moriana and Nice, and claimant King of Jerusalem. The infant was nicknamed the Flower of Paradise (French: Fleur de Paradis). Having succeeded his father at such a young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto being only 5 years old. Having caught a fever, he died at the Castle of Valentino, and was succeeded by his brother Charles Emmanuel II. The infant was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was called the Prince of Piedmont.

adult_technical.text:
Francis Hyacinth, born on September 14, 1632, and passing away on October 4, 1638, was the Duke of Savoy from 1637 to 1638, under the regency of his mother, Christine Marie. Born at the Castle of Valentino in Turin, he was the eldest surviving son of Victor Amadeus I, Duke of Savoy, and his wife, Christine Marie of France. As the heir to the Savoyard throne, he was styled as the Prince of Piedmont.

Upon his father's death in October 1637, Francis Hyacinth succeeded to the throne, and his mother assumed the role of regent. In addition to his title as Duke of Savoy, he held the subsidiary titles of Marquess of Saluzzo, Count of Aosta, Moriana, and Nice, and Claimant King of Jerusalem. He was also known as the "Flower of Paradise" (French: Fleur de Paradis).

Despite his young age, Francis Hyacinth did not rule de facto, as he was only five years old when he succeeded his father. Unfortunately, he contracted a fever and died at the Castle of Valentino. He was succeeded by his brother, Charles Emmanuel II. Francis Hyacinth was buried at the Sacra di San Michele in Turin.

samples.title: Abel-mizraim
samples.original_text:
Abel-mizraim (, ’Āḇêl-Mitsrayim,; the "meadow of Egypt", or "mourning of Egypt") is a place "beyond," or east, of the Jordan river, at the "threshing-floor of Atad." Here Joseph and his 11 brothers (representing the future 12 tribes of Israel) and the Egyptians mourned seven days for Jacob (Genesis ). Its exact site is unknown.

The name Abel-mizraim is only mentioned once in the Hebrew Bible.

samples.title: John II, Duke of Brabant
samples.original_text:
John II (27 September 1275 – 27 October 1312), also called John the Peaceful, was Duke of Brabant, Lothier and Limburg (1294–1312). He was the son of John I of Brabant and Margaret of Flanders.

John II succeeded his father in 1294 During the reign of John II, Brabant continued supporting a coalition to stop French expansion. He tried to conquer South Holland (district of medieval Holland) from the pro-French Count John II of Holland, but was not successful.

In 1309, the Crusade of the Poor besieged the castle of Genappe in Brabant because it was sheltering Jews. John sent an army that defeated the crusaders, who incurred heavy losses.

John, who suffered from kidney stones and wanted his duchy to be peacefully handed over to his son upon his death, in 1312 signed the famous Charter of Kortenberg. John died in Tervuren in 1312. He was buried in the St. Michael and Gudula Cathedral in Brussels.

Family
On 8 July 1290, John married Margaret of England in Westminster Abbey, London. She was a daughter of King Edward I of England and his first wife, Eleanor of Castile. Only one child was born out of this marriage:
 John III, Duke of Brabant.

John II had several illegitimate children:
 Jan van Corsselaer, was later named Lord of Witthem, Wailwilre, Machelen, la Rochette and Colonster.
 Jan van Wyvliet. Lord of Blaesveld and Kuyc. Married to Margaret Pipenpoy.
 Jan Cordeken: Founder of the House of Glymes. He was legitimized by the emperor Louis IV by charter dated of 27 August 1344, lists John II as the father and Elisabeth Gortygin as his mother.
 Jan Magermann. Married to Adelise d'Elsies.
 Jan II van Dongelberg (- 1383). His mother was Marguerite van Pamel.

References

samples.title: Bindarri National Park
samples.original_text:
Bindarri National Park is a national park in New South Wales, Australia, 431 km northeast of Sydney.

It is considered the epicenter of biodiversity, due to the rare and endangered species found here, such as fish bone fern, southern quassia and palm orchid.

One of the natural beauties of this park is the mouth of the river Urumbilum, which, descending through the Great Escarpment, carved through spectacular waterfalls.

See also
 Protected areas of New South Wales

References

External links
 Official Site

National parks of New South Wales
Protected areas established in 1999
1999 establishments in Australia

easy_general.text:
Bindarri National Park is a beautiful place located in New South Wales, Australia, about 431 kilometers northeast of Sydney. This park is known for being a "center of biodiversity," which means it is home to many unique and rare plants and animals. Some of these species include the fish bone fern, southern quassia, and palm orchid.

One of the most impressive features of the park is the mouth of the river Urumbilum. This river flows through the Great Escarpment, which is a large mountain range. As the river goes down the mountain, it creates stunning waterfalls.

Bindarri National Park is part of a larger group of protected areas in New South Wales. These areas are designated to protect the natural environment and the animals that live there. The park was established in 1999, which means it has been a protected area for a while.

adult_technical.text:
Bindarri National Park, situated in New South Wales, Australia, approximately 431 kilometers northeast of Sydney, is renowned for its exceptional biodiversity. This park serves as a critical habitat for several rare and endangered species, including the fish bone fern, southern quassia, and palm orchid.

One of the most striking natural features of Bindarri National Park is the mouth of the Urumbilum River, which flows through the Great Escarpment, creating a series of spectacular waterfalls.

The park, established in 1999, is part of the broader network of protected areas in New South Wales. For further information, refer to the official website.

samples.title: Cubomania
samples.original_text:
Cubomania is a surrealist method of making collages in which a picture or image is cut into squares and the squares are then reassembled without regard for the original image, either automatically "or at random." The word can also mean the collage made using this method, a "rearrangement... suffic[ing] to create an entirely new work."  The technique was invented by the Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca. It has been described as a "statistical method".  Robert Hirsch has seemed to imply that this process can be done with digital photography. Although seemingly a contradiction in terms, at least one cubomania has been made with triangular shapes, rather than rectangles.

Penelope Rosemont and Joseph Jablonski have suggested that cubomania, with other surrealist methods, can "subvert the enslaving 'message' of advertising and to free images from repressive contexts."

Using cubomania as a method for arranging soundscapes has been suggested.

Other meanings
"Cubomania" can also mean "love of cubes", or, specifically, Rubik's Cube.

See also
Cut-up technique
Surautomatism

References

External links
Bill McKeeman Proposed Glossary

Surrealism

easy_general.text: Cubomania is a way of making art by cutting a picture into squares and then rearranging them in a random order. This can create a new image. It was invented by a Romanian artist named Gherasim Luca. This method can also be used with digital photography. Some people think Cubomania can be used to change the message of advertising. It can also be used to create soundscapes. There is another meaning of Cubomania, which means "love of cubes" or specifically, Rubik's Cube.

adult_non_technical.text: Cubomania is a way of making art where you cut a picture into small squares and then put them back together in a completely random order. This method was invented by a Romanian artist named Gherasim Luca. It can be done with pictures, photographs, or digital images. Some people think cubomania can be used to change the messages in advertising and to free images from restrictive contexts. It can also be used to create new soundscapes.

adult_technical.text:
Cubomania is a surrealist technique that involves the disassembly of an image into constituent elements, typically squares, and then reassembly of these elements in an arbitrary manner. This method, pioneered by Romanian surrealist Gherasim Luca, has been likened to a "statistical approach." The term "cubomania" can also refer to the resulting collage, which represents a radical departure from the original image.

The process of creating a cubomania collage can be executed using various methods, including digital photography, as suggested by Robert Hirsch. Notably, cubomania has also been created using triangular shapes, which defies the conventional expectation of rectangular elements.

Penelope Rosemont and Joseph Jablonski have proposed that cubomania, along with other surrealist techniques, can challenge the oppressive nature of advertising and liberate images from their restrictive contexts.

Additionally, cubomania has been suggested as a method for arranging soundscapes.

The term "cubomania" can also be interpreted as "love of cubes" or, more specifically, as a reference to Rubik's Cube.

See also:
- Cut-up technique
- Surautomatism

References:

External links:
- Bill McKeeman Proposed Glossary
- Surrealism

samples.title: Endeavour River National Park
samples.original_text:
Endeavour River National Park is a national park in Queensland, Australia, gazetted to protect and preserve some of the natural and cultural resources in and around the mouth of the Endeavour River, immediately north of the small town of Cooktown. The park is located  northwest of Brisbane.

Naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected specimens of local 'Australian' flora in 1770 from this area which were taken back to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson first illustrated local Australian Aboriginal people encountered nearby, plus flora collected and fauna seen; and kangaroos were first given their modern English name (borrowing from the local Guugu Yimithirr language).

HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, had struck reefs and been pulled ashore for repairs along the river locally known within Guugu Yimithirr as Wabalumbaal, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was renamed on James Cook's charts as the Endeavour River, after Endeavour, and the current National Park appears, in turn, to be named after the river.

The present National Park contains coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands and the estuary plus parts of the Endeavour River catchment. It is mostly accessible by boat only, and still contains flora and fauna species of the kind collected and illustrated back in 1770.

See also

 Captain Cook mythology: Australia
 Protected areas of Queensland

References

easy_general.text:
The Endeavour River National Park is a protected area in Queensland, Australia, located near the town of Cooktown. It was created to preserve the natural and cultural resources around the mouth of the Endeavour River.

In 1770, two scientists named Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected plants from this area and brought them back to England. They also learned about the local Aboriginal people and the animals they saw. Kangaroos were named after the local language.

The park is named after the Endeavour River, which was named after the ship HM Bark Endeavour, which was commanded by James Cook. The park has many different types of land, including coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, and the estuary.

The park is mostly accessible by boat, and it still has the same plants and animals that the scientists collected in 1770.

In 1770, two naturalists, Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander, collected specimens of local Australian plants from this area and sent them back to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Sydney Parkinson, an artist, was the first to draw the local Aboriginal people and the plants and animals he saw there. He also introduced the modern English name "kangaroo" to the animals, which he borrowed from the local Guugu Yimithirr language.

The HM Bark Endeavour, a ship under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, ran aground and had to be pulled ashore for repairs along the river known as Wabalumbaal in Guugu Yimithirr, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was later renamed the Endeavour River after the ship, and the current national park is named after this river.

The Endeavour River National Park contains a variety of ecosystems, including coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, and the estuary of the Endeavour River. Although the park is mostly accessible by boat, it still has the same plants and animals that Banks and Solander collected in 1770.
