adult_technical.text:
The Endeavour River National Park is a protected area situated in Queensland, Australia, specifically designated to safeguard the natural and cultural resources of the Endeavour River mouth, immediately north of the small town of Cooktown. This park is located approximately  northwest of Brisbane.

Historically, the area has been a focal point for exploration and scientific inquiry. In 1770, naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander collected specimens of local flora from this region, which were transported to the Royal Botanic Gardens in England. Concurrently, Sydney Parkinson documented the Aboriginal people he encountered, along with the flora and fauna he observed. Notably, the term "kangaroo" was first introduced into the English language, derived from the Guugu Yimithirr language spoken by the local Aboriginal population.

The HM Bark Endeavour, under the command of Lieutenant James Cook, ran aground and was pulled for repairs along the river, known as Wabalumbaal in Guugu Yimithirr, possibly near the present site of Cooktown. The river was subsequently renamed the Endeavour River in honor of the ship, and the current National Park is indeed named after the river.

The park encompasses a diverse array of ecosystems, including coastal dunes, freshwater wetlands, mangrove forests, heathlands, tropical woodlands, and the estuary of the Endeavour River. Additionally, parts of the Endeavour River catchment are included within the park's boundaries. The park is primarily accessible by boat, and it continues to harbor flora and fauna species similar to those documented in 1770.

samples.title: Boardman, North Carolina
samples.original_text:
Boardman is a town in Columbus County, North Carolina, United States. The population was 157 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Boardman is located at  (34.439790, -78.948495).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the town has a total area of , of 
which 3.1 square miles (8.1 km2)  is land and  of it (0.64%) is water.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 202 people, 79 households, and 54 families residing in the town. The population density was 64.8 people per square mile (25.0/km2). There were 89 housing units at an average density of 28.6 per square mile (11.0/km2). The racial makeup of the town was 54.46% White, 44.55% African American, 0.99% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.99% of the population.

There were 79 households, out of which 22.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 39.2% were married couples living together, 24.1% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.4% were non-families. 29.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.56 and the average family size was 3.15.

In the town, the population was spread out, with 23.8% under the age of 18, 9.4% from 18 to 24, 28.7% from 25 to 44, 22.3% from 45 to 64, and 15.8% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 69.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 69.2 males.

The median income for a household in the town was $20,500, and the median income for a family was $28,333. Males had a median income of $25,500 versus $20,417 for females. The per capita income for the town was $10,339. About 19.0% of families and 27.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 45.5% of those under the age of eighteen and 28.6% of those 65 or over.

There were 79 households, with 22.8% having children under the age of 18 living with them, 39.2% being married couples living together, 24.1% having a female householder with no husband present, and 30.4% being non-families. 29.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 13.9% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.

The median income for a household in the town was $20,500, and the median income for a family was $28,333. Males had a median income of $25,500 versus $20,417 for females. The per capita income for the town was $10,339. About 19.0% of families and 27.6% of the population were below the poverty line, including 45.5% of those under the age of eighteen and 28.6% of those 65 or over.

samples.title: Psophometric voltage
samples.original_text:
Psophometric voltage is a circuit noise voltage measured with a psophometer that includes a CCIF-1951 weighting network. 

"Psophometric voltage" should not be confused with "psophometric emf," i.e., the emf in a generator or line with 600 Ω internal resistance. For practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the corresponding psophometric voltage. 

Psophometric voltage readings, V, in millivolts, are commonly converted to dBm(psoph) by dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V – 57.78.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
Psophometric voltage is a way to measure the noise voltage in a circuit. It's done using a special device called a psophometer, which includes a weighting network called CCIF-1951.

It's important to note that psophometric voltage is not the same as psophometric emf. Psophometric emf is the voltage generated in a generator or line with an internal resistance of 600 Ω. For most practical purposes, the psophometric emf is twice the psophometric voltage.

To convert the psophometric voltage readings from millivolts (mV) to a more common unit called dBm(psoph), you can use this formula: dBm(psoph) = 20 log10V - 57.78.

References

Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

adult_non_technical.text:
Imagine you're trying to measure the level of the background noise in a circuit. This noise is like the faint hum of a radio or the soft buzz of a fan. To measure this noise, you use a special tool called a "psophometer."

The psophometer has a built-in feature called a "CCIF-1951 weighting network," which helps it measure the noise in a specific way.

Now, there's another term that might be confusing: "psophometric emf." This is the amount of voltage in a generator or line with a 600 Ω internal resistance. In practice, the psophometric emf is about twice the psophometric voltage.

Once you've measured with the psophometer, you convert the reading into a unit called "dBm(psoph)," which is a common way to express the noise level.

Understanding these concepts is important in fields like electronics and telecommunications engineering.

adult_technical.text:
Psophometric voltage refers to the measurement of circuit noise using a psophometer equipped with a CCIF-1951 weighting network. It is essential to distinguish between psophometric voltage and psophometric emf, which is the electromotive force (emf) in a generator or line with a 600 Ω internal resistance. For practical applications, the psophometric emf is equivalent to twice the corresponding psophometric voltage.

Psophometric voltage readings, expressed in millivolts (mV), are typically converted to decibels (dB) using the formula:

dBm(psoph) = 20 log10(V) - 57.78

This conversion is crucial for accurate comparison and analysis in telecommunications engineering.

References:
Electrical parameters
Noise (electronics)
Telecommunications engineering

samples.title: Aristodemus
samples.original_text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus (Ancient Greek: Ἀριστόδημος) was one of the Heracleidae, son of Aristomachus and brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. He was a great-great-grandson of Heracles and helped lead the fifth and final attack on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers complained to the Oracle that its instructions had proved fatal to those who had followed them (the Oracle had told Hyllas to attack through the narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe). They received the answer that by the "third fruit" the "third generation" was meant, and that the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium. They accordingly built a fleet at Naupactus, but before they set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning (or shot by Apollo) and the fleet destroyed, because one of the Heraclidae had slain an Acarnanian soothsayer.

His brothers were later able to conquer the Peloponnese.

By his wife Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, he was the father of twin Kings Eurysthenes and Procles, the ancestors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources
Diodorus Siculus, iv. 57, 58.
Pausanias, i. 32, 41, ii. 13, 18, iii. I, iv. 3, v. 3.
Euripides, Heraclidae.
Pindar, Pythia, ix. 137.
Herodotus, ix. 27.
Karl Otfried Müller. Dorians, Part I, Chapter 3.
Connop Thirlwall. History of Greece, Chapter VII.
George Grote. History of Greece, Part I, Chapter XVIII.
Georg Busolt. Griechische Geschichte, Part I, Chapter 11, Section 7, where a list of authorities is given.

References

Heracleidae
Ancient Messenians

easy_general.text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus was a member of a famous family called the Heracleidae. He was the son of Aristomachus and brother of Cresphontes and Temenus. Aristodemus was a great-great-grandson of Heracles, a legendary hero.

Aristodemus and his brothers were trying to attack a place called Mycenae in a region called the Peloponnese. They were told by the Oracle, a wise woman who could predict the future, to attack through a narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. However, Aristodemus was struck by lightning and their fleet was destroyed.

Despite this, Aristodemus's brothers were able to conquer the Peloponnese. Aristodemus also had two sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who became the ancestors of two royal houses in Sparta.

adult_non_technical.text:
In Greek mythology, Aristodemus was a member of a famous family called the Heracleidae. He was a great-great-grandson of a legendary hero named Heracles. Aristodemus had two brothers, Cresphontes and Temenus, and they were planning to attack a place called Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers went to a wise woman called the Oracle to complain about the Oracle's instructions. The Oracle had told another hero, Hyllas, to attack through a narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. However, the Oracle explained that the "third fruit" actually meant the "third generation" and that the narrow passage was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium.

So, Aristodemus and his brothers built a fleet at a place called Naupactus. But before they could set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning and the fleet was destroyed. This happened because one of the Heraclidae had killed a soothsayer from a place called Acarnania.

Despite the loss of Aristodemus, his brothers were able to conquer the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus was married to a woman named Argia, who was the daughter of a king from a place called Thebes. Together, they had two sons, Eurysthenes and Procles, who became the ancestors of two royal houses in a place called Sparta.

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of Greek mythology, Aristodemus is a prominent figure within the Heracleidae, a lineage of heroes descended from the legendary hero Heracles. Born to Aristomachus, Aristodemus was the brother of Cresphontes and Temenus, as well as the great-great-grandson of Heracles. His role was particularly significant in the fifth and final assault on Mycenae in the Peloponnese.

Aristodemus and his brothers sought counsel from the Oracle of Delphi, lamenting the fatal consequences of previous guidance. The Oracle had instructed them to attack through the narrow passage when the third fruit was ripe. Upon further inquiry, they learned that the "third fruit" referred to the "third generation" and that the "narrow passage" was not the isthmus of Corinth, but the straits of Rhium.

Following this revelation, they constructed a fleet at Naupactus. However, before they could set sail, Aristodemus was struck by lightning or possibly shot by Apollo, resulting in the destruction of the fleet. This tragedy was attributed to the killing of an Acarnanian soothsayer by one of the Heraclidae.

Despite this setback, Aristodemus's brothers went on to conquer the Peloponnese.

Through his marriage to Argia, daughter of King Autesion of Thebes, Aristodemus fathered twin Kings Eurysthenes and Procles, who became the progenitors of the two royal houses of Sparta.

Sources:
- Diodorus Siculus, iv. 57, 58.
- Pausanias, i. 32, 41, ii. 13, 18, iii. I, iv. 3, v. 3.
- Euripides, Heraclidae.
- Pindar, Pythia, ix. 137.
- Herodotus, ix. 27.

- Connop Thirlwall. History of Greece, Chapter VII.
- George Grote. History of Greece, Part I, Chapter XVIII.
- Georg Busolt. Griechische Geschichte, Part I, Chapter 11, Section 7.
- Heracleidae
- Ancient Messenians

In the context of music, "Free Spirit" refers to a Christian spiritual and gospel band that emerged from the Free Methodist Church and was active between 1971 and 1980. In other contexts, "Free Spirit" can refer to a medieval heretical movement known as the Brethren of the Free Spirit, a frequent flyer program of Spirit Airlines, a section of Friedrich Nietzsche's work "Beyond Good and Evil," and an American home-built aircraft design, the CEI Free Spirit Mk II.

It is also worth noting that "Free Spirit" can be associated with the philosophical viewpoint of freethought, which asserts that beliefs should be rational rather than dictated by authority.

samples.title: Southern Moreton Bay Islands National Park

Southern Moreton Bay Islands is a national park in Queensland, Australia, 44 km southeast of Brisbane.  It forms part of the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area, so identified by BirdLife International because it supports large numbers of migratory waders, or shorebirds.

See also

 Protected areas of Queensland

Important Bird Areas of Queensland

easy_general.text:

This park is part of a larger area called the Moreton Bay and Pumicestone Passage Important Bird Area. BirdLife International has marked this area as important because it is home to many migratory waders, which are birds that live near the shore.

For more information, you can check out the protected areas of Queensland.

samples.title: Transmission level point
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a transmission level point (TLP) is a physical test point in an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where a test signal may be inserted or measured.  Typically, various parameters, such as the power of the signal, noise, or test tones inserted are specified or measured at the TLP.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is a function of system design and is an expression of the design gain or attenuation (loss).

Voice-channel transmission levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of ca. 1000 hertz. The dBm is an absolute level with respect to 1 mW. The TLP is thus characterized by the relation:

TLP = dBm — dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP,  the test point is called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. In general, the term TLP is commonly used as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, the expression 0TLP refers to a .  At a −16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm.

See also
 Alignment level
 Nominal level

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
In telecommunication, a transmission level point (TLP) is a specific point in an electronic circuit where a test signal can be inserted or measured. This point is often used to check the power of the signal, noise, or test tones.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is determined by the system design. It represents the gain or loss of the system.

For voice channels, the transmission level is measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of around 1000 hertz. dBm is a measure of the absolute level relative to 1 milliwatt (mW). The TLP is calculated using the formula:

TLP = dBm - dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP, it is called a zero transmission level point or zero-dBm TLP. The term TLP is often used as a unit, followed by the nominal level. For example, 0TLP refers to a nominal level of 0dBm.

Typically, the level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone, is connected is specified as 0dBm.

For example, if a TLP has a nominal level of -16dBm, the measured level of 0dBm would be +16dBm0.

See also:
- Alignment level
- Nominal level

References:
- Telecommunications engineering

adult_non_technical.text:
In the world of telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a special spot in an electronic circuit where you can insert or measure a test signal. Think of it like a checkpoint in a transmission channel where you can check how well the signal is traveling.

At a TLP, you can measure the power of the signal, the amount of noise, or even insert test tones to see if the signal is working as expected.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is determined by the system's design. It's a way to express how much gain the signal has or how much attenuation (loss) it experiences.

Voice-channel transmission levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of around 1000 hertz. dBm is a unit of measurement that represents an absolute level with respect to 1 milliwatt (mW). The TLP is then calculated using the formula:

TLP = dBm — dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP, it's called a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. The term TLP is often used as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For example, 0TLP refers to a zero-dBm TLP. At a -16TLP, the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is usually specified as 0dBm.

adult_technical.text:
In the context of telecommunications, a transmission level point (TLP) is a specific location within an electronic circuit, typically a transmission channel, where a test signal can be inserted or measured. This point serves as a critical reference point for specifying or measuring various parameters, such as the power of the signal, noise, or test tones inserted.

The nominal transmission level at a TLP is a direct consequence of system design, reflecting the intended gain or attenuation (loss) of the system.

For voice-channel transmission, the levels at test points are measured in decibel-milliwatts (dBm) at a frequency of approximately 1000 hertz. The dBm represents an absolute level relative to 1 milliwatt (mW). The TLP is thus defined by the relation:

TLP = dBm — dBm0

When the nominal signal power is 0dBm at the TLP, the test point is referred to as a zero transmission level point, or zero-dBm TLP. The term TLP is often used as if it were a unit, preceded by the nominal level for the test point. For instance, the expression 0TLP refers to a zero-dBm TLP, while a -16TLP indicates that the measured level of 0dBm is +16dBm0.

The level at a TLP where an end instrument, such as a telephone set, is connected is typically specified as 0dBm.

See also:
- Alignment level
- Nominal level

References:
- Telecommunications engineering

samples.title: X-dimension of recorded spot
samples.original_text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of recorded spot is the effective recorded spot dimension measured in the direction of the recorded line. The effective recorded spot dimension" is the largest center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, which gives minimum peak-to-peak variation of density of the recorded line. X-dimension of recorded spot implies that the facsimile equipment response to a constant density in the object (original) is a succession of discrete recorded spots.

References

Fax

easy_general.text: In a fax machine, the X-dimension of the recorded spot is the size of the recorded spot in the direction of the line being printed. This size is determined by the largest distance between the spots in the printed line. In other words, the X-dimension of the recorded spot means that the fax machine prints a series of separate spots instead of a continuous line.

adult_non_technical.text: In fax machines, the X-dimension of recorded spot refers to the size of the small dots on the paper. These dots are used to represent the density of the original image. The X-dimension is the maximum distance between these dots, which ensures that the density of the dots is as consistent as possible. This means that the fax machine can accurately reproduce the original image.

adult_technical.text:
In fax systems, the X-dimension of the recorded spot refers to the effective recorded spot dimension, which is measured in the direction of the recorded line. This dimension represents the maximum center-to-center spacing between recorded spots, resulting in the minimum peak-to-peak variation of density along the recorded line. The X-dimension of the recorded spot indicates that the response of the facsimile equipment to a uniform density in the original object is a series of discrete recorded spots.

References:
- Fax

samples.title: Tunneling
samples.original_text:
Tunneling or tunnelling may refer to:

 Digging tunnels (the literal meaning)
Hobby tunneling
 Quantum tunneling, the quantum-mechanical effect where a particle crosses through a classically forbidden potential energy barrier
 Tunneling (fraud), a fraud committed by a company's own management or by major shareholders
 Tunneling protocol, transmitting one computer network protocol that is encapsulated inside another network protocol

See also
 
 
 Tunnel (disambiguation)

easy_general.text: Tunneling" can mean different things depending on the context. It can refer to digging tunnels, a hobby, a scientific phenomenon, a type of fraud, or a method of computer communication. For example, quantum tunneling is when a particle passes through a barrier that it shouldn't be able to.

adult_non_technical.text:
**What is Tunneling?**

Tunneling is a term that can refer to several different things, depending on the context. Let's break it down:

**1. Tunneling as a Literal Activity:**

When you think of tunneling, you might imagine digging a tunnel through the ground. This is the literal meaning of tunneling, and it's a common activity that people do to create underground passages or tunnels.

**2. Tunneling as a Hobby:**

Some people enjoy tunneling as a hobby, where they dig tunnels in their homes or gardens. This type of tunneling is often done for fun or as a way to explore the underground.

**3. Quantum Tunneling:**

In the world of physics, tunneling is a fascinating phenomenon that occurs when a particle passes through a barrier that it normally shouldn't be able to. This is known as quantum tunneling, and it's a result of the strange laws of quantum mechanics.

**4. Tunneling (Fraud)**

Tunneling can also refer to a type of fraud that occurs when a company's own management or major shareholders mismanage the company's finances. This type of tunneling is a serious issue that can harm a company's financial health.

**5. Tunneling Protocol:**

In the world of computer networking, tunneling is a technique used to transmit data from one network to another. This is done by wrapping one protocol inside another, which helps to protect the data and make it more secure.

So, in summary, tunneling is a term that can refer to many different things, depending on the context. Whether it's digging a tunnel through the ground, a fascinating quantum phenomenon, or a type of fraud, tunneling is a term that has many different meanings and uses.

adult_technical.text:
The term "tunneling" can refer to several distinct concepts, each with its own technical implications and applications.

1. **Tunneling as Digging**: This is the most straightforward interpretation, referring to the physical act of excavating tunnels. These tunnels can be constructed for various purposes, such as transportation, mining, or utilities. The process involves the removal of soil, rock, or other materials to create a continuous passage.

2. **Hobby Tunneling**: In the context of hobbies, tunneling can refer to the act of creating a tunnel, such as a model tunnel or a tunnel made from materials like clay or sand. This type of tunneling is often done for entertainment, education, or as a form of craftsmanship and creativity.

3. **Quantum Tunneling**: In the realm of quantum mechanics, tunneling is a fundamental phenomenon that allows particles to pass through barriers that are classically insurmountable. This effect is a direct consequence of the wave-particle duality and the uncertainty principle, which states that the position and momentum of a particle cannot be simultaneously known with arbitrary precision. Quantum tunneling is crucial in fields such as nuclear physics, particle physics, and materials science.

4. **Tunneling (Fraud)**: In the context of corporate fraud, tunneling refers to a form of financial misconduct where a company's management or major shareholders manipulate the company's financial statements to benefit their own interests. This type of tunneling can involve the creation of fictitious, non-existent assets or liabilities, which can significantly impact the company's financial health and reputation.

5. **Tunneling Protocol**: In computer networking, tunneling refers to the process of encapsulating one network protocol within another. This technique is commonly used to secure virtual private networks (VPNs) and to transmit data over insecure networks. Tunneling protocols, such as IPsec (Internet Protocol Security) and GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation), are designed to ensure the integrity and confidentiality of data transmitted over the network.

In summary, the term "tunneling" encompasses a range of concepts, each with its own technical implications and applications. While physical tunneling and hobby tunneling are relatively straightforward, quantum tunneling and tunneling (fraud) require a deeper understanding of the underlying principles and mechanisms. Tunneling protocols, on the other hand, are essential tools for secure communication and data transmission over computer networks.

For more information on these concepts, please refer to the "Tunnel (disambiguation)" page.

samples.title: Joule per mole
samples.original_text:
The joule per mole (symbol: J·mol−1 or J/mol) is an SI derived unit of energy per amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For example, Gibbs free energy is quantified as joules per mole. It is also a SI derived unit of molar thermodynamic energy defined as the energy equal to one joule in one mole of substance. 

Since 1 mole = 6.02214076×1023 particles (atoms, molecules, ions etc.), 1 joule per mole is equal to 1 joule divided by 6.02214076×1023 particles, 1.66054×10−24 joule per particle. This very small amount of energy is often expressed in terms of a smaller unit such as the electronvolt (eV, see below).

Physical quantities measured in J·mol−1 usually describe quantities of energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. Division by the number of moles facilitates comparison between processes involving different quantities of material and between similar processes involving different types of materials.  The precise meaning of such a quantity is dependent on the context (what substances are involved, circumstances, etc.), but the unit of measurement is used specifically to describe certain existing phenomena, such as in thermodynamics it is the unit of measurement that describes molar energy.

For convenience and due to the range of magnitudes involved these quantities are almost always reported in kJ·mol−1 rather than in J·mol−1. For example, heats of fusion and vaporization are usually of the order of 10 kJ·mol−1, bond energies are of the order of 100 kJ·mol−1, and ionization energies of the order of 1000 kJ·mol−1. 

1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.239 kcal·mol−1, 1.04×10−2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm−1. At room temperature (25 °C, 77 °F, or 298.15 K) 1 kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.4034 .

References 

SI derived units

easy_general.text:
The joule per mole, often written as J·mol−1 or J/mol, is a unit of energy used in the International System of Units (SI). It measures the amount of energy associated with a certain amount of material. For example, Gibbs free energy is measured in joules per mole.

One joule per mole is equal to one joule divided by the number of particles in one mole, which is approximately 6.02214076×10^23 particles. This means that one joule per mole is equivalent to 1.66054×10^-24 joules per particle. This is a very small amount of energy, so it is often expressed in terms of a smaller unit called the electronvolt (eV).

The joule per mole is used to describe the energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. By dividing the energy by the number of moles, it becomes easier to compare processes involving different amounts of material.

In thermodynamics, the joule per mole is used to describe molar energy. However, the precise meaning of this unit depends on the context, such as the substances involved and the circumstances.

For convenience, these quantities are usually reported in kJ·mol−1, which is a larger unit of energy. For example, the heat of fusion and vaporization are typically on the order of 10 kJ·mol−1, bond energies are on the order of 100 kJ·mol−1, and ionization energies are on the order of 1000 kJ·mol−1.

One kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.239 kcal·mol−1, 1.04×10^-2 eV per particle, or 83.6 cm^-1. At room temperature (25°C, 77°F, or 298.15 K), one kJ·mol−1 is equal to 0.4034 joules.

References:
- SI derived units

Note: I've rewritten the text to make it easier to understand for a general reader around middle to high school level. I've used short, clear sentences, avoided technical words when possible, and provided concrete examples to help illustrate the concepts. I've also kept the important meaning of the original text, while using my own wording to ensure that the text is easy to understand.

adult_non_technical.text: The joule per mole, abbreviated as J·mol−1 or J/mol, is a unit of energy that relates to the amount of material. It's a way to measure the amount of energy in one mole of a substance. One joule per mole is equal to one joule divided by the number of particles in one mole, which is about 6.02214076×1023 particles. This unit is used to describe the amount of energy that occurs during phase transformations or chemical reactions. It's almost always reported in kJ·mol−1 rather than in J·mol−1.

adult_technical.text:
The joule per mole (symbol: J·mol−1 or J/mol) is an SI derived unit representing the energy per amount of material. Energy is measured in joules, and the amount of material is measured in moles. For instance, Gibbs free energy is quantified as joules per mole. It is also a SI derived unit of molar thermodynamic energy, defined as the energy equivalent to one joule in one mole of substance.

Given that 1 mole = 6.02214076×10²³ particles (atoms, molecules, ions, etc.), 1 joule per mole is equivalent to 1 joule divided by 6.02214076×10²³ particles, resulting in 1.66054×10⁻²⁴ joule per particle. This extremely small amount of energy is often expressed in terms of a smaller unit, such as the electronvolt (eV), as discussed below.

Physical quantities measured in J·mol−1 typically describe the energy transferred during phase transformations or chemical reactions. Dividing by the number of moles facilitates the comparison between processes involving different quantities of material and between similar processes involving different types of materials. The precise meaning of such a quantity depends on the context (substances involved, conditions, etc.), but the unit of measurement is specifically used to describe certain phenomena, such as in thermodynamics, where it is the unit of measurement for molar energy.

For convenience and due to the range of magnitudes involved, these quantities are almost always reported in kJ·mol−1 rather than in J·mol−1. For example, heats of fusion and vaporization are typically of the order of 10 kJ·mol−¹, bond energies are of the order of 100 kJ·mol−¹, and ionization energies are of the order of 1000 kJ·mol−¹.

1 kJ·mol−¹ is equivalent to 0.239 kcal·mol−¹, 1.04×10⁻² eV per particle, or 83.6 cm⁻¹. At room temperature (25 °C, 77 °F, or 298.15 K), 1 kJ·mol−¹ is equivalent to 0.4034 J·mol−¹.

References:

- SI derived units.

samples.title: Gentlemen, Be Seated!
samples.original_text:
"Gentlemen, Be Seated" is a science fiction short story by American writer Robert A. Heinlein.  It was first published in the May 1948 issue of Argosy magazine.  It was later included in two of Heinlein's collections, The Green Hills of Earth (1951), and The Past Through Tomorrow (1967).

Plot summary

The story tells of a visit to a tunnel on the surface of the Moon which goes awry when a pressure seal fails, trapping three men (a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker). The title of the story derives from the way they plug an air leak while awaiting rescue: by sitting on it.

The phrase "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" is the opening line of the interlocutor in a traditional minstrel show. It was also, at the time the story was written and while Heinlein attended, the opening line for all classes at the military and naval academies (as well as classes for officers at the various service schools) in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by an episode in "Baron Munchausen": The ship sprung a leak. It was my good fortune to discover it first. I found it a large hole about a foot diameter. ... This noble vessel was preserved, with all its crew, by a most fortunate thought! in short, I sat down over it. ... My situation, while I sat there, was rather cool, but the carpenter's art soon relieved me.

References

External links
 

1948 short stories
Short stories by Robert A. Heinlein
Works originally published in Argosy (magazine)

The phrase "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" is a famous line from a traditional minstrel show. It was also used to start classes at military schools in the United States.

The story might have been inspired by a story from a book called "Baron Munchausen." In that story, a ship had a leak, and the captain fixed it by sitting on it.

The story was included in two Heinlein collections: "The Green Hills of Earth" (1951) and "The Past Through Tomorrow" (1967).

Plot Summary

The narrative recounts a visit to a tunnel on the lunar surface, which culminates in a pressure seal failure, trapping three individuals—a supervisor, a reporter, and a tunnel worker. The story's title originates from the method they employ to seal an air leak while awaiting rescue: by sitting on it.

The phrase "Gentlemen, Be Seated!" serves as the opening line in a traditional minstrel show. Additionally, during Heinlein's time at the military and naval academies, this phrase was used to signal the commencement of classes in the United States.

The story may have been inspired by an episode from "Baron Munchausen": The ship sprung a leak, and it was my good fortune to discover it first. I found it a large hole about a foot in diameter. easy_general.text:
Here's a rewritten version of the text that is easy to understand for a general reader:

---

**Important Events in Ancient History**

1. **Sparta's King Eunomus Ascends to the Throne**: In 830 BC, King Polydectes of Sparta passed away, and his son, Eunomus, became the new king. Eunomus ruled Sparta until 780 BC.

2. **Peru's Paracas Culture Arrives**: Around the same time, early communities settled in the Chincha Valley in Peru, which became known as the Paracas culture.

3. **Hasanlu is Destroyed by a Fire**: In 800 BC, a massive fire completely destroyed the city of Hasanlu, which marked the end of Period IVB.

4. **Greek Colonization Begins**: During this time, the Greeks started to establish colonies in the Mediterranean and Black Sea.

5. **Homer Writes the Iliad and Odyssey**: Around 700 BC, the Greek poet Homer wrote his famous works, the Iliad and the Odyssey.

6. **Assyrian Army Employs New Technology**: The Assyrian army began using a new method to harden iron into steel, which made their weapons more effective.

7. **Earliest Sundial in Egypt**: The oldest known sundial was used in Egypt during this time.

8. **Iron Age Begins in Britain**: The Iron Age started in Britain, which lasted until 43 AD.

**Notable Deaths**

1. **Xiong Xun, the Monarch of Chu**: Xiong Xun was the ruler of the state of Chu during the Western Zhou Dynasty in ancient China.

2. **Hasanlu Lovers**: The Hasanlu Lovers are a pair of human remains found at Teppe Hasanlu, which may represent a couple.

**Gallery**

This section includes images and illustrations related to the events and people mentioned in the text.

---

"Ancient Events and Deaths"

**Events:**

adult_technical.text:
**Events**

1. **End of Polydectes' Reign**: The reign of Polydectes, king of Sparta, concluded in 830 BCE.

2. **Eunomus' Reign**: Eunomus, king of Sparta, began his reign, lasting until 780 BCE.

3. **Paracas Culture Emergence**: The first communities associated with the Paracas culture emerged in the Chincha Valley, Peru, located on the south coast of Peru.

4. **Hasanlu Destruction**: The end of Period IVB saw the complete destruction of Hasanlu by a fire.

5. **Greek Colonization**: The Greek colonization of the Mediterranean and Black Sea regions commenced.

6. **Archaic Period of Greece**: The Archaic period of Greece began, spanning from 800 BCE to 500 BCE.

7. **Homer's Works**: Homer, the Greek poet, wrote the *Iliad* and the *Odyssey* around 700 BCE.

8. **Assyrian Steel Technology**: The Assyrian army utilized the new technology of hardening iron into steel for weapons.

9. **Earliest Sundial**: The earliest surviving sundial was in use in Egypt.

10. **Iron Age in Britain**: The Iron Age began in Britain, lasting until 43 AD.

**Deaths**

1. **Xiong Xun**: Xiong Xun, monarch of the state of Chu during the Western Zhou Dynasty of ancient China, passed away.

2. **Hasanlu Lovers**: The Hasanlu Lovers, a pair of human remains found at Teppe Hasanlu, possibly a couple, were discovered.

**References**

**Gallery**

**Clarifications**

* The Paracas culture was a South American civilization that flourished from around 900 BCE to 200 BCE.
* The Archaic period of Greece lasted from 800 BCE to 480 BCE.
* The Iron Age in Britain lasted from around 1000 BCE to 43 AD.
* The Western Zhou Dynasty of ancient China lasted from 1046 BCE to 771 BCE.
* The earliest surviving sundial dates back to 700 BCE.

samples.title: Cordelia (moon)
samples.original_text:
Cordelia is the innermost known moon of Uranus. It was discovered from the images taken by Voyager 2 on January 20, 1986, and was given the temporary designation S/1986 U 7. It was not detected again until the Hubble Space Telescope observed it in 1997. Cordelia takes its name from the youngest daughter of Lear in William Shakespeare's King Lear. It is also designated Uranus VI.

Other than its orbit, radius of 20 km and geometric albedo of 0.08 virtually nothing is known about it. In the Voyager 2 images Cordelia appears as an elongated object with its major axis pointing towards Uranus. The ratio of axes of Cordelia's prolate spheroid is 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia acts as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring. Cordelia's orbit is within Uranus' synchronous orbit radius, and is therefore slowly decaying due to tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind.

See also 

 Moons of Uranus

References 

Explanatory notes

Citations

External links 
 Cordelia Profile by NASA's Solar System Exploration
 Uranus' Known Satellites (by Scott S. Sheppard)

Moons of Uranus
19860120

easy_general.text:
Cordelia is a small moon that orbits Uranus. It was discovered by the Voyager 2 spacecraft in 1986 and is named after a character from William Shakespeare's play King Lear. Cordelia is the innermost known moon of Uranus, meaning it is the closest moon to Uranus.

Cordelia is about 20 kilometers in size and has a long shape. It is important for keeping one of Uranus' rings in place.

Cordelia is very close to another moon called Rosalind.

We know very little about Cordelia. We know that it is about 20 kilometers in size and has a long shape. It is also close to Uranus, so it is slowly losing its orbit due to the planet's gravity.

Cordelia is close to another moon called Rosalind.

Named after the youngest daughter of King Lear in William Shakespeare's play, Cordelia is also known as Uranus VI.

Despite its relatively small size of 20 km in radius and geometric albedo of 0.08, little is known about Cordelia. In Voyager 2 images, Cordelia is depicted as an elongated object with its major axis facing Uranus. Its prolate spheroid has an axis ratio of 0.7 ± 0.2.

Cordelia serves as the inner shepherd satellite for Uranus' ε ring. Its orbit is located within Uranus' synchronous orbit radius, resulting in its gradual decay due to tidal deceleration.

Cordelia is very close to a 5:3 orbital resonance with Rosalind.

samples.title: Svenska Akademiens ordbok
samples.original_text:
Svenska Akademiens ordbok (), abbreviated SAOB, is a dictionary published by the Swedish Academy, with the official title Ordbok över svenska språket utgiven av Svenska Akademien. This dictionary is the Swedish counterpart of the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) or the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB). 

Work on the dictionary started in 1787 and the first volume was published in 1898 and as of 2021, when the latest volume appeared, work has progressed to the letter Å inclusively. The dictionary has approximately 450,000 main entries. The searchable web version has been available since 1997.

See also
Svenska Akademiens ordlista

External links

The Swedish Academy – Official site (in English)

Swedish Academy
Publications established in 1898
Swedish dictionaries
Online dictionaries
1898 establishments in Sweden

The dictionary started in 1787 and the first volume was published in 1898. It has about 450,000 words. The online version has been available since 1997.

This dictionary is similar to the famous Oxford English Dictionary (OED) or the Deutsches Wörterbuch (DWB), but it's specifically for the Swedish language.

The creation of the dictionary began in 1787, and the first volume was published in 1898. Since then, the dictionary has been updated and expanded, with the latest volume appearing in 2021, covering the letter Å. The dictionary contains around 450,000 main entries, making it a valuable resource for anyone learning or studying the Swedish language.

The online version of the dictionary has been available since 1997, allowing users to search for words and phrases easily. You can find more information about the dictionary on the Swedish Academy's official website.

samples.title: Mill Creek Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Mill Creek Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 721 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 19.3 square miles (50.1 km2), of which, 18.9 square miles (49.0 km2) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.1 km2) of it (2.12%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 639 people, 243 households, and 185 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.7 people per square mile (13.0/km2).  There were 265 housing units at an average density of 14.0/sq mi (5.4/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.75% White, 0.63% African American, 0.16% from other races, and 0.47% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.16% of the population.

There were 243 households, out of which 34.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.8% were married couples living together, 7.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 23.5% were non-families. 20.2% of all households were made up of individuals, and 8.6% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.59 and the average family size was 2.97.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 7.2% from 18 to 24, 27.4% from 25 to 44, 26.4% from 45 to 64, and 13.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females there were 100.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 99.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,219, and the median income for a family was $41,023. Males had a median income of $30,903 versus $23,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,928.  About 5.0% of families and 7.7% of the population were below the poverty line, including 9.0% of those under age 18 and 2.2% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Mercer County, Pennsylvania

The term "K9" or "K-9" can refer to various entities across different domains, including animals, fictional dogs, computing, entertainment, military, automotive, and other fields.

In the realm of animals, "K9" is commonly used to denote police dogs and the police dog unit itself. Additionally, "Canine" or "Canis" is a genus that includes dogs, wolves, coyotes, and jackals.

samples.title: 138 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 138 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. At the time it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus (or, less frequently, year 616 Ab urbe condita) and the Third Year of Jianyuan. The denomination 138 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 
Roman Empire
 Tautalus surrenders to the Romans.
 Valencia in Spain is founded as a Roman colony.

Asia Minor
 Attalus III succeeds Attalus II as Attalid king of Pergamon
Egypt
 Galaestes revolts.

Syria

The year 138 BC was a significant time in ancient history. It was known as the Year of the Consulship of Serapio and Callaicus, or Year 616 Ab urbe condita, and the Third Year of Jianyuan. The name 138 BC has been used since the early medieval period when the Anno Domini calendar became the standard way of naming years in Europe.

During this year, many important events happened across different parts of the world.

In the Roman Empire, a man named Tautalus surrendered to the Romans, which means he gave up his power and joined the Romans. Also, a new city called Valencia was founded in Spain as a Roman colony.

In Asia Minor, Attalus III succeeded Attalus II as the king of Pergamon, a city in Asia Minor.

In Egypt, a man named Galaestes started a rebellion against the government.

In Syria, Antiochus VII expelled Diodotus Tryphon, who was the king of the Seleucid Empire. Tryphon then attacked the city of Beirut.

In Parthia, Phraates II became the emperor of Parthia.

In China, Grand Empress Dowager Dou, the grandmother of Emperor Wu of Han, purged the high administration of officials to consolidate her power. She dismissed Prime Minister Dou Yong and her half-brother, General-in-Chief Tian Fen. Two of the young emperor's closest advisors, Zhao Wan and Wang Zang, were arrested and committed suicide.

In the arts and sciences, a poem called the Hymn to Apollo was written and inscribed on stone in Delphi, a city in Greece. It is one of the earliest surviving pieces of notated music in the western world.

Some important people were born during this year, such as Lucius Cornelius Sulla, a Roman general and statesman, and Phaedrus the Epicurean, a Greek scholar and philosopher.

Unfortunately, some important people also passed away during this year, such as Attalus II Philadelphus, the king of Pergamon, Diodotus Tryphon, the king of the Seleucid Empire, and Mithridates I, the king of Parthia.

Overall, the year 138 BC was a time of great change and development in ancient history, with many important events happening across different parts of the world.

samples.title: Cherry Grove Township, Warren County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Cherry Grove Township is a township in Warren County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population at the 2000 census was 228.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics

As of the census of 2000, there were 228 people, 92 households, and 72 families residing in the township.  The population density was 4.9 people per square mile (1.9/km2).  There were 368 housing units at an average density of 7.8/sq mi (3.0/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 92 households, out of which 23.9% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 66.3% were married couples living together, 7.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 21.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 5.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.48 and the average family size was 2.82.

In the township the population was spread out, with 20.6% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 25.9% from 25 to 44, 30.7% from 45 to 64, and 17.1% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 42 years. For every 100 females, there were 115.1 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 108.0 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $35,625, and the median income for a family was $40,313. Males had a median income of $35,625 versus $18,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,628.  About 7.8% of families and 5.8% of the population were below the poverty line, including 4.5% of those under the age of eighteen and none of those 65 or over.

References

Townships in Warren County, Pennsylvania
Townships in Pennsylvania

samples.title: Adaptive communications
samples.original_text:
Adaptive communications can mean any communications system, or portion thereof, that automatically uses feedback information obtained from the system itself or from the signals carried by the system to modify dynamically one or more of the system operational parameters to improve system performance or to resist degradation.  
The modification of a system parameter may be discrete, as in hard-switched diversity reception, or may be continuous, as in a 
predetection combining algorithm.

See also
Automatic Link Establishment
Channel use
CALM M5

Telecommunications techniques

easy_general.text:
Adaptive communications is a way of designing a communication system that automatically adjusts its settings based on feedback from the system itself or the signals it carries. This helps the system work better, even when things go wrong.

For example, if you're trying to send a message to a radio station, but the signal is weak, the system can adjust its settings to make the signal stronger. This can be done in different ways, like changing the strength of the signal or using a different channel.

There are different types of adaptive communications, like hard-switched diversity reception and predetection combining algorithms. These techniques help the system stay strong and work well.

To learn more about adaptive communications, you can read about Automatic Link Establishment, Channel use, CALM M5, and telecommunications techniques.

adult_non_technical.text:
Imagine you're talking to a friend on the phone, but your voice is coming through a noisy channel. To make sure your friend can hear you clearly, you might adjust your voice or move closer to the phone receiver. This is similar to what happens in adaptive communications.

Adaptive communications is a way for a communication system to adjust its settings based on feedback from the signals it's sending or receiving. This helps the system work better and stay reliable.

There are two types of adjustments: discrete and continuous. Discrete adjustments are like making small, sudden changes, while continuous adjustments are like making smooth, gradual changes.

One example of a discrete adjustment is called hard-switched diversity reception. This means the system makes quick changes to improve the quality of the signal.

On the other hand, a continuous adjustment is called a predetection combining algorithm. This means the system makes smooth, gradual changes to improve the quality of the signal.

So, in summary, adaptive communications is a way for a communication system to adjust its settings based on feedback to improve its performance and stay reliable.

adult_technical.text:
Adaptive communications refers to a class of systems that utilize dynamic feedback mechanisms to adjust their operational parameters in real-time, thereby enhancing performance or mitigating degradation. This adjustment can be achieved through both discrete and continuous methods, exemplified by hard-switched diversity reception and predetection combining algorithms, respectively.

See also: Automatic Link Establishment
Channel use
CALM M5
Telecommunications techniques

adult_technical.text:
The term "Worcester" can refer to various entities across different geographical and historical contexts. In the United Kingdom, Worcester is a city located in the county of Worcestershire, England. It is also a constituency in the UK Parliament. Additionally, Worcester Park is a notable landmark in London, England.

In the United States, Worcester is the largest city with the name in Massachusetts and is part of Worcester County. It is also a town in Missouri, Pennsylvania, Vermont, and Wisconsin. Worcester, New York, is a town, and Worcester (CDP) is a census-designated place within this town. Worcester Township in Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, is another notable entity. Worcester, Vermont, is a town, and Worcester (CDP) is a census-designated place within this town. Worcester, Wisconsin, is a town, and Worcester (community) is an unincorporated community within this town. Worcester County, Maryland, is a county, and Barry, Illinois, and Marquette, Michigan, were formerly known as Worcester and New Worcester, respectively.

Geographically, Worcester is also found in South Africa, specifically in Limpopo and Western Cape provinces, and in Antarctica, where Worcester Summit is located.

In the realm of transportation, Worcester is a locomotive class, specifically the GWR 3031 Class, which was built for the Great Western Railway between 1891 and 1915. Union Station in Worcester, Massachusetts, is also called "Worcester" by the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The name is associated with several ships, including HMS Worcester in the British Royal Navy and USS Worcester in the United States Navy.

Historical figures with the name include John of Worcester, an English monk and chronicler, Roger of Worcester, a Bishop of Worcester, and Sylvester of Worcester, another Bishop of Worcester. The name is also a surname.

In the culinary context, Worcester Pearmain is an English apple cultivar, and Worcestershire sauce, often referred to as "Worcester sauce," is a spicy condiment that originated in Worcester, England, in the 19th century.

Other notable entities include Worcester Academy, Worcester, Bosch Group (a British domestic heating company), Worcester College (disambiguation), and Royal Worcester (an English bone china and porcelain manufacturer).

Additionally, Worcester v. Georgia is a significant U.S. Supreme Court case from 1832, related to the issue of slave ownership.

samples.title: Gross world product
samples.original_text:
The gross world product (GWP) is the combined gross national income of all the countries in the world. Because imports and exports balance exactly when considering the whole world, this also equals the total global gross domestic product (GDP). According to the World Bank, the 2013 nominal GWP was approximately US$75.59 trillion. In 2017, according to the CIA's World Factbook, the GWP was around US $80.27 trillion in nominal terms and totaled approximately 127.8 trillion international dollars in terms of purchasing power parity (PPP). The per capita PPP GWP in 2017 was approximately Int$17,500 according to the World Factbook.  According to the World Bank, the 2020 GWP in current US$ was approximately US$ 84.705 trillion.

samples.title: Sour mix
samples.original_text:
Sour mix (also known as sweet and sour mix) is a mixer that is yellow-green in color and is used in many cocktails. It is made from approximately equal parts lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup and shaken vigorously with ice. This produces a pearly-white liquid with a pronounced flavor.

Optionally, egg whites may be added to make the liquid slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with liquor(s) to make a sour drink; most common are vodka sour (vodka) and whiskey sour (whiskey).

Pre-mixed versions are available, and are in use in many bars.  These typically consist of a powder which must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.

See also
List of cocktails

Drink mixers

easy_general.text:
Sour mix is a type of cocktail mixer that is yellow-green in color. It is made by shaking equal parts of lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup with ice. The result is a clear, pearly-white liquid with a strong flavor.

Sometimes, egg whites are added to make the liquid slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with alcohol to make a sour drink. For example, you can make a vodka sour by adding vodka or a whiskey sour by adding whiskey.

There are also pre-mixed versions of sour mix available. These come in the form of a powder and need to be mixed with water before use.

For more information, you can check out lists of cocktails and drink mixers.

adult_non_technical.text:
Sour mix is a type of drink that is often used in cocktails. It is made by mixing lemon and/or lime juice with simple syrup and shaking it vigorously with ice. This creates a clear, yellow-green liquid with a strong sour taste.

Sometimes, egg whites are added to make the drink slightly foamy.

Sour mix can be mixed with alcohol to make a sour drink. Two common types are vodka sour and whiskey sour.

Pre-mixed versions of sour mix can also be found in many bars. These come in the form of a powder that needs to be added to water before use.

For more information, you can check out lists of cocktails and drink mixers.

adult_technical.text:
Sour mix, also known as sweet and sour mix, is a versatile cocktail mixer characterized by its yellow-green hue. It is prepared by combining approximately equal parts of lemon and/or lime juice and simple syrup, shaken vigorously with ice. This process results in a pearly-white liquid with a distinct, pronounced flavor.

Optionally, egg whites may be incorporated to confer the liquid a slightly foamy texture.

Sour mix can be combined with various liquors to create a sour drink. The most common variations include the vodka sour, which utilizes vodka, and the whiskey sour, which employs whiskey.

Pre-mixed versions of sour mix are commercially available and are widely used in many bars. These products typically consist of a powder that must be rehydrated by adding water prior to use.

For further information, refer to the list of cocktails and drink mixers.

samples.title: Lucerne Mines, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Lucernemines, usually written as Lucerne Mines, is a census-designated place (CDP) in Indiana County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 937 at the 2010 census.

Geography
Lucerne Mines is located at  (40.554447, -79.155584).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all of it land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 951 people, 407 households, and 293 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 1,105.8 people per square mile (427.0/km2). There were 427 housing units at an average density of 496.5/sq mi (191.7/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 98.63% White, 1.05% African American, 0.11% Asian, and 0.21% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.84% of the population.

There were 407 households, out of which 23.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.2% were married couples living together, 10.8% had a female householder with no husband present, and 27.8% were non-families. 25.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 15.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.33 and the average family size was 2.76.

In the CDP the population was spread out, with 19.1% under the age of 18, 6.1% from 18 to 24, 27.8% from 25 to 44, 23.4% from 45 to 64, and 23.6% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 43 years. For every 100 females there were 94.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 93.2 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $28,427, and the median income for a family was $33,580. Males had a median income of $26,719 versus $18,036 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $13,976. About 10.4% of families and 10.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 14.5% of those under age 18 and 4.1% of those age 65 or over.

References

Census-designated places in Indiana County, Pennsylvania

samples.title: Worth Township, Mercer County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
Worth Township is a township in Mercer County, Pennsylvania, United States.  The population was 899 at the 2010 census.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 25.0 square miles (64.8 km2), of which, 24.8 square miles (64.2 km2) of it is land and 0.2 square miles (0.6 km2) of it (0.96%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 830 people, 319 households, and 238 families residing in the township.  The population density was 33.5 people per square mile (12.9/km2).  There were 329 housing units at an average density of 13.3/sq mi (5.1/km2).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.28% White, 0.12% Asian, 0.24% Pacific Islander, and 0.36% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.24% of the population.

There were 319 households, out of which 34.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 65.5% were married couples living together, 5.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 25.1% were non-families. 20.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.60 and the average family size was 3.04.

In the township the population was spread out, with 25.2% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 29.2% from 25 to 44, 24.1% from 45 to 64, and 15.9% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 100.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 106.3 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $41,328, and the median income for a family was $46,719. Males had a median income of $30,573 versus $21,818 for females. The per capita income for the township was $18,434.  About 5.3% of families and 8.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 13.6% of those under age 18 and 4.2% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Mercer County, Pennsylvania

Kiho may refer to:

 Kiho-tumu, the supreme god in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago
 Kihō, Mie, a town in Japan
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions, but generate spell effects.  Kiho nearly always require a shugenja or monk (sometimes specifically one or the other) to bow as part of the cost of playing the card
 In the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja that have some extraordinary or supernatural effect

, Japanese women's basketball player

In the game Legend of the Five Rings, kiho cards are played as actions but have special effects. Kiho can also be a Japanese feminine given name.

adult_non_technical.text:
Kiho is a term that can refer to several different things depending on the context. Here are a few examples:

1. Kiho-tumu is the supreme god in the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago, which is a group of islands in the Pacific Ocean.

2. Kihō, Mie is a town in Japan.

3. In the game Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions, but they have special effects attached to them. These cards often require a shugenja or monk to bow as part of the cost of playing the card.

4. In the game Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho are complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja that have some extraordinary or supernatural effect.

5. There are also people with the given name Kiho, including a Japanese women's basketball player.

6. Kiho is also a Japanese feminine given name.

So, in summary, Kiho can refer to a variety of different things depending on the context.

adult_technical.text: The term "kiho" has multiple interpretations across different cultural and gaming contexts. In the mythology of the Tuamotu archipelago, Kiho-tumu is the supreme deity. Kihō, Mie, is a town in Japan. In the context of the Legend of the Five Rings Collectible Card Game, kiho cards are played as actions but produce spell effects, often necessitating a shugenja or monk to bow as part of the card's cost. Similarly, in the Legend of the Five Rings Role-Playing Game, kiho refers to complex martial arts techniques learned by monks and sometimes shugenja, which possess extraordinary or supernatural effects. Additionally, kiho can also refer to individuals with the given name, including a Japanese women's basketball player, as well as Japanese feminine given names.

samples.title: SS7
samples.original_text:
SS7 or SS-7 may refer to:

 Signalling System No. 7, a set of telephone signaling protocols
 SS-7 Saddler, the NATO reporting name of R-16 missile
 China Railways SS7, an electric locomotive model in China
 Super Socket 7, a chip socket introduced by AMD

easy_general.text: SS7 or SS-7 can mean several different things. It can refer to a set of rules for telephone calls, a type of missile, a type of train in China, or a type of computer chip socket.

adult_non_technical.text:
The term "SS7" can refer to several different things, depending on the context. Let's break it down for you:

1. **Signalling System No. 7**: This is a set of rules used by phones to communicate with each other. Think of it like a set of instructions that phones can follow to talk to one another.

2. **SS-7 Saddler**: This is the name given to a type of missile called the R-16 by NATO. This missile is a powerful weapon that can be used in military conflicts.

3. **China Railways SS7**: This is a type of electric train used in China. It's a model of locomotive, which means it's a type of train that runs on tracks.

4. **Super Socket 7**: This is a type of chip socket introduced by AMD. A socket is a place where a computer chip can be inserted and used in a computer.

So, "SS7" can mean different things depending on how it's used.

adult_technical.text:
The acronym "SS7" or "SS-7" can denote several distinct entities:

1. **Signalling System No. 7**: A set of telephone signaling protocols.
2. **SS-7 Saddler**: The NATO reporting name for the R-16 missile.
3. **China Railways SS7**: An electric locomotive model used in China.
4. **Super Socket 7**: A chip socket introduced by AMD.

Each of these entities represents a specific concept within its respective field, demonstrating the versatility of the acronym "SS7" or "SS-7.

samples.title: Muslim brotherhoods of Senegal
samples.original_text:
This is a list of Sufi orders (Tariqas) in Senegal (and also the Gambia).  They are active Muslim organizations that can also be found in many other parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Their members are mainly Wolofs, Fulas and Tocouleurs.

List
The four largest Muslim brotherhoods in Senegal are:

 The Xaadir (Qādiriyya), the oldest, founded in Baghdad by the Sufi mystic Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century, now pan-Islamic, spread to Senegal in the 18th Century.
 The Tijaniyyah, the largest in membership, founded in Fez, Morocco by the Algerian born Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane.
 The Mourides, the richest and most active, founded by the Islamic leader Cheikh Amadou Bamba (1850–1927) of French West Africa, now Senegal. The order is centered in the city of Touba.
 The Layene are a smaller Sufi order, centered at Yoff north of Dakar.

External links
 Review of Sufism and Religious Brotherhoods in Senegal
 BBC:Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

Senegal
Islam in Senegal
Lists of Muslims
Sufi orders

easy_general.text:
This is a list of Sufi orders in Senegal and the Gambia. Sufi orders are Muslim groups that can be found in many parts of Africa and the Islamic world. Their members are mainly Wolofs, Fulas, and Tocouleurs.

The four largest Sufi orders in Senegal are:

1. The Xaadir (Qādiriyya) - This is the oldest Sufi order. It was founded in Baghdad by a man named Abdul Qādir al-Jilānī in the 12th century. Now, it is found in many countries and spread to Senegal in the 18th century.

2. The Tijaniyyah - This is the largest Sufi order in Senegal. It was founded in Fez, Morocco by a man named Cheikh Sīdī 'Aḥmad at-Tijānī, who was from Algeria. The order is centered in the city of Tivaouane.

3. The Mourides - This is the richest and most active Sufi order in Senegal. It was founded by a man named Cheikh Amadou Bamba, who lived from 1850 to 1927. The order is centered in the city of Touba.

4. The Layene - This is a smaller Sufi order that is centered in Yoff, which is north of Dakar.

For more information, you can check out these links:
- Review of Sufism and Religious Brotherhoods in Senegal
- BBC: Senegal's Mourides: Islam's mystical entrepreneurs

Sufi orders are an important part of Islam in Senegal and the Gambia. They help people connect with their faith and each other.

samples.title: ICMP
samples.original_text:
ICMP  may refer to:

Science and technology
 International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants, a culture collection in New Zealand
 International Congress on Mathematical Physics
 Internet Control Message Protocol, used in computer networking
 Ischemic cardiomyopathy, a type of heart disease

Other uses
 The Institute of Contemporary Music Performance, in London, UK

easy_general.text: ICMP can stand for a few different things. In science and technology, it can refer to a collection of microorganisms from plants in New Zealand, a conference on mathematical physics, a protocol for computer networking, or a type of heart disease. Other uses include a music school in London and an organization that helps find missing people.

adult_non_technical.text:
The acronym "ICMP" can mean many different things depending on the context in which it's used. Let's break down some of the most common meanings:

**Science and Technology:**

1. **International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants**: This is a special collection of tiny living organisms found in plants, like bacteria and fungi. It's located in New Zealand and is a valuable resource for scientists studying plant life.
2. **International Congress on Mathematical Physics**: This is a conference where experts from around the world come together to discuss and share their knowledge about mathematical physics.
3. **Internet Control Message Protocol**: This is a protocol used by computers to communicate with each other. It's like a secret language that computers use to exchange information.
4. **Ischemic cardiomyopathy**: This is a type of heart disease that occurs when the heart muscle doesn't get enough oxygen.

**Other Uses:**

1. **Institute of Contemporary Music Performance**: This is a school in London, UK, that teaches people how to perform modern music.
2. **International Commission on Missing Persons**: This is a group of countries working together to find people who have gone missing.

So, when you see "ICMP," it might refer to any of these things, depending on the situation.

adult_technical.text:
The acronym ICMP can represent various entities across different domains. In the realm of science and technology, ICMP may refer to the International Collection of Microorganisms from Plants, a culture collection located in New Zealand, or the International Congress on Mathematical Physics. Additionally, ICMP can denote the Internet Control Message Protocol, a protocol utilized in computer networking. In the context of medicine, ICMP can also stand for Ischemic cardiomyopathy, a type of heart disease.

Furthermore, ICMP can represent the Institute of Contemporary Music Performance, situated in London, UK, or the International Commission on Missing Persons, an intergovernmental organization.

samples.title: Stormarn (district)
samples.original_text:
Stormarn () is a district in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany. It is bounded by (from the north and clockwise) the districts of Segeberg and Ostholstein, the city of Lübeck, the district of Lauenburg, and the city-state of Hamburg.

History

In medieval times the name Stormarn was applied to a larger area, of which the present-day district is only the eastern half. It was the home of the Saxon tribe the Sturmarii.

Stormarn became a part of Holstein in the 12th century.  When Schleswig-Holstein became a province of Prussia in 1867, the Prussian administration established the district of Stormarn, with Wandsbek as its capital. In 1937 the southwestern part of the district was incorporated into Hamburg, and the district lost half of its population. Since Wandsbek was now a borough of Hamburg, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe after the war. In 1970 Stormarn again lost a substantial portion of its territory, when the city of Norderstedt was founded in order to become a part of the Segeberg district.

Geography

The river Trave runs through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. In the southernmost portion of Stormarn there are the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

Coat of arms
The coat of arms displays a white swan, with a crown around its neck, on red ground. The swan has been the heraldic animal of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

Towns and municipalities

References

External links
Official website (German)

Districts of Schleswig-Holstein
Regions of Schleswig-Holstein

However, in 1937, a large part of the district was added to Hamburg, and the population of the district was cut in half. After the war, the capital was moved to Bad Oldesloe. In 1970, another part of the district was lost when the city of Norderstedt was created.

The river Trave flows through the district before entering the city of Lübeck. The southern part of Stormarn includes the eastern suburbs of the Hamburg metropolitan area.

The coat of arms of Stormarn shows a white swan with a crown around its neck on a red background. The swan has been a symbol of Stormarn since the Middle Ages.

samples.title: Europe of Democracies and Diversities

Europe of Democracies and Diversities (EDD) was a Eurosceptic political group with seats in the European Parliament between 1999 and 2004. Following the 2004 European elections, the group reformed as Independence/Democracy (IND/DEM).

Members
June Movement (Denmark), 3 seats
People's Movement against the EU (Denmark), 1 seat
Hunting, Fishing, Nature, Tradition (France), 6 seats
ChristianUnion – Reformed Political Party (Netherlands), 3 seats

Combats Souverainistes (France), 1 MEP defected from Rally for France/UEN group in March 2001
League of Polish Families (Poland), after Poland joined the EU in May 2004

References

External links

Former European Parliament party groups

samples.title: Punt
samples.original_text:
Punt or punting may refer to:

Boats
Punt (boat), a flat-bottomed boat with a square-cut bow developed on the River Thames
Falmouth Quay Punt, a small sailing vessel hired by ships anchored in Falmouth harbour
Norfolk Punt, a type of racing dinghy developed in Norfolk
Cable ferry, known as a punt in Australian English

Places
 Land of Punt, a trading partner of Ancient Egypt possibly based in the Horn of Africa region
 Puntland, a region in north-eastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province

Sports and recreation
 Punt (gridiron football), a way of kicking a ball in the American or Canadian varieties of football
 Punt (Australian football), a way of kicking a ball in the Australian variety of football
 A type of goal kick in association football

Other uses
 Punt (surname), a surname
 The Punt or Punt Éireannach, also known as the Irish pound, which was the currency of Ireland prior to its changeover to the Euro
 El Punt, a Catalan newspaper
 Punt gun, a type of extremely large shotgun, mounted directly on punt boats
 A punt or punty, a tool used in glassblowing
 A punt mark or pontil mark, left by the glassblowing tool
 Punt (wine bottle), the indented bottom of a wine bottle
 Punt, a colloquial term in British English for bet or wager in gambling
 PUNT, the Spanish acronym of the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea

See also
 Punter (disambiguation)
 Pundt

easy_general.text:
The word "punt" can mean many different things depending on the context. Here are some examples:

**Boats:** A punt is a type of boat with a flat bottom and a square-cut bow. It was developed by people on the River Thames. Another type of punt is the Falmouth Quay Punt, which is a small sailing vessel hired by ships anchored in Falmouth harbor. There's also the Norfolk Punt, which is a type of racing dinghy from Norfolk. In Australian English, a punt can refer to a cable ferry.

**Places:** The Land of Punt was a trading partner of Ancient Egypt, possibly located in the Horn of Africa region. Puntland is a region in northeastern Somalia, centered on Garowe in the Nugaal province.

**Sports and recreation:** In football, a punt is a way of kicking a ball. In American or Canadian football, a punt is a way of kicking a ball. In Australian football, a punt is a way of kicking a ball. In association football, a punt is a type of goal kick.

**Other uses:** Punt can also be a surname. The Punt or Punt Éireannach, also known as the Irish pound, was the currency of Ireland before it changed to the Euro. El Punt is a Catalan newspaper. A punt gun is a type of extremely large shotgun mounted on punt boats. A punt or punty is a tool used in glassblowing. A punt mark or pontil mark is left by the glassblowing tool. A punt is the indented bottom of a wine bottle. Punt is a colloquial term in British English for a bet or wager in gambling. PUNT is the Spanish acronym for the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.

**See also:** Punter (disambiguation) and Pundt.

In summary, the word "punt" can mean many different things depending on the context. It can refer to a type of boat, a place, a way of kicking a ball in football, a surname, a currency, a newspaper, a type of shotgun, a tool used in glassblowing, a mark left by the glassblowing tool, the indented bottom of a wine bottle, a colloquial term for a bet or wager in gambling, and an acronym for the United National Workers' Party, a former political party in Equatorial Guinea.
