samples.title: Start signal
samples.original_text:
In telecommunication, a start signal is a signal that prepares a device to receive data or to perform a function. 

In asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a character that prepares the receiving device for the reception of the code elements. 

A start signal is limited to one signal element usually having the duration of a unit interval.

References

Telecommunications engineering

easy_general.text:
A start signal is a special kind of signal that gets a device ready to receive information or do a task.

In asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a character to tell the receiving device that data is coming.

A start signal lasts for just one short period of time, usually called a unit interval.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the world of telecommunications, a start signal is a special kind of message that tells a device when it's ready to receive information or do something. 

When we talk about asynchronous serial communication, start signals are used at the beginning of a message to tell the receiving device that it's time to listen for the rest of the message.

A start signal is usually just one short message that lasts for a specific amount of time.

Source: Telecommunications engineering.

adult_technical.text:
In the realm of telecommunications, a start signal serves as a marker that initiates the process of data reception or function execution within a device. In the context of asynchronous serial communication, start signals are employed at the commencement of a character to prepare the receiving device for the subsequent reception of code elements. The duration of a start signal is typically confined to a single signal element, which often corresponds to a unit interval.

References:
Telecommunications engineering.

samples.title: Sibley Township, Sibley County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Sibley Township is a township in Sibley County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 353 at the 2000 census.

Sibley Township was organized in 1864.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.7 square miles (92.3 km), of which 35.6 square miles (92.2 km)  is land and 0.1 square mile (0.1 km)  (0.14%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 353 people, 115 households, and 90 families residing in the township.  The population density was 9.9 people per square mile (3.8/km).  There were 127 housing units at an average density of 3.6/sq mi (1.4/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 99.43% White, 0.28% African American and 0.28% Asian.

There were 115 households, out of which 43.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.8% were married couples living together, 1.7% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.7% were non-families. 18.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and 3.5% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 3.07 and the average family size was 3.52.

In the township the population was spread out, with 30.9% under the age of 18, 10.5% from 18 to 24, 28.9% from 25 to 44, 21.0% from 45 to 64, and 8.8% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 122.0 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 130.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $39,125, and the median income for a family was $40,000. Males had a median income of $27,750 versus $20,833 for females. The per capita income for the township was $14,814.  About 8.3% of families and 11.1% of the population were below the poverty line, including 10.8% of those under age 18 and 10.0% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Sibley County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

These awards, which recognize outstanding contributions to science fiction literature and fandom, have been instrumental in promoting and celebrating the science fiction genre.

In addition to these literary and scientific references, Asimov's name is also associated with the acronym ASIMO, which stands for Asimov's Science of Man. In summary, Isaac Asimov's legacy extends beyond his literary contributions, as his name is associated with various entities and concepts within the scientific and literary communities.

samples.title: Huerfano, New Mexico

Huerfano () is a census-designated place (CDP) in San Juan County, New Mexico, United States. The population was 104 at the 2000 census. It is part of the Farmington Metropolitan Statistical Area. Huerfano is named after El Huerfano Mountain, located a mile to the northeast.

Geography
Huerfano is located at  (36.526359, -108.031135).

According to the United States Census Bureau, the CDP has a total area of , all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 104 people, 28 households, and 22 families residing in the CDP. The population density was 3.9 people per square mile (1.5/km2). There were 36 housing units at an average density of 1.3 per square mile (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the CDP was 99.04% Native American and 0.96% White.

There were 28 households, out of which 39.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.1% were married couples living together, 17.9% had a female householder with no husband present, and 21.4% were non-families. 14.3% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 3.71 and the average family size was 4.32.

In the CDP, the population was spread out, with 38.5% under the age of 18, 7.7% from 18 to 24, 25.0% from 25 to 44, 20.2% from 45 to 64, and 8.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 30 years. For every 100 females, there were 85.7 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 82.9 males.

The median income for a household in the CDP was $24,583, and the median income for a family was $24,583. Males had a median income of $18,750 versus $13,750 for females. The per capita income for the CDP was $7,333. None of the population is below the poverty line.

Education
The community of Huerfano is part of the Bloomfield School District.

samples.title: FTS2000
samples.original_text:
Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a long distance telecommunications service for the United States federal government, including services such as switched voice service for voice or data up to 4.8 kbit/s, switched data at 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s, switched digital integrated service for voice, data, image, and video up to 1.544 Mbit/s, packet switched service for data in packet form, video transmission for both compressed and wideband video, and dedicated point-to-point private line for voice and data. 

Note 1:  Use of FTS2000 contract services is mandatory for use by U.S. Government agencies for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. 

Note 2:  No U.S. Government information processing equipment or customer premises equipment other than that which are required to provide an FTS2000 service are furnished. 

Note 3:  The FTS2000 contractors will be required to provide service directly to an agency's terminal equipment interface. For example, the FTS2000 contractor might provide a terminal adapter to an agency location in order to connect FTS2000 ISDN services to the agency's terminal equipment. 

Note 4:  GSA awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts covering FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988. 

Note 5:  The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in instances related to maximum security.
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, then replaced by FTS2001, and thereafter, in 2008, by Networx.

References
FTS2000 was completed in 2000, and was replaced by FTS2001.

Telecommunication services
Telecommunications in the United States

easy_general.text:
The Federal Telecommunications System 2000 (FTS2000) is a set of long-distance telecommunications services provided to the United States federal government. It includes several types of services, such as:

1. Switched voice service: This service allows for voice or data transmission at a speed of up to 4.8 kbit/s.
2. Switched data service: This service enables data transmission at speeds of 56 kbit/s and 64 kbit/s.
3. Switched digital integrated service: This service supports voice, data, image, and video transmission at a speed of up to 1.544 Mbit/s.
4. Packet switched service: This service allows data to be transmitted in the form of packets.
5. Video transmission: This service supports both compressed and wideband video transmission.
6. Dedicated point-to-point private line: This service provides a dedicated line for voice and data transmission.

FTS2000 contract services are mandatory for U.S. government agencies for all acquisitions subject to 40 U.S.C. 759. This means that any equipment purchased by the government must be compatible with FTS2000 services.

FTS2000 contractors are required to provide services directly to an agency's terminal equipment interface. For example, a contractor might provide a terminal adapter to connect an agency's terminal equipment to FTS2000 ISDN services.

The GSA (General Services Administration) awarded two 10-year, fixed-price contracts for FTS2000 services on December 7, 1988.

The Warner Amendment excludes the mandatory use of FTS2000 in instances related to maximum security.

FTS2000 was completed in 2000 and later replaced by FTS2001, which was then replaced by Networx in 2008.

In summary, FTS2000 is a set of long-distance telecommunications services provided to the United States federal government. It includes several types of services, such as switched voice service, switched data service, switched digital integrated service, packet switched service, video transmission, and dedicated point-to-point private line. FTS2000 contract services are mandatory for U.S. government agencies, and any equipment purchased by the government must be compatible with FTS2000 services.

samples.title: Battle of Grotniki
samples.original_text:
The Battle of Grotniki took place on 4 May 1439 in the vicinity of Grotniki Duże, a village near Nowy Korczyn, currently in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. 

The battle was fought between the Hussite confederates under Spytko III of Melsztyn against the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland under Hińcza of Rogów and  de facto regent bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The defeat of the non-Catholic forces marked the end of militant Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom, led by bishop Zbigniew.

Bibliography
Jan Długosz, Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae, opera venerabili domini Ioanni Dlugossi, liber XI i XII, Warsaw 2001, page 202 - 206.
Secondary sources
Anna Sochacka "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny? "  Rocznik Lubelski, vol XVI, Lublin 1973.

easy_general.text: The Battle of Grotniki took place on May 4, 1439, near the village of Grotniki Duże, which is located near Nowy Korczyn in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship. This battle was fought between the Hussite confederates, led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, and the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland, led by Hińcza of Rogów and Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki. The Hussite forces were defeated, marking the end of the militant Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom under Bishop Zbigniew.

adult_non_technical.text:
The Battle of Grotniki was a significant event that took place on May 4, 1439, near the village of Grotniki Duże, which is located near Nowy Korczyn in the Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship of Poland. This battle was important because it marked the end of the Hussite movement in Poland and the beginning of a new era for the Polish Kingdom.

The Hussite movement was a religious movement that started in the 14th century and was led by a man named Jan Hus. The Hussites were a group of people who disagreed with the Catholic Church and wanted to reform it.

The Battle of Grotniki was fought between two groups of people. One group was the Hussite confederates, led by a man named Spytko III of Melsztyn. The other group was the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland, led by Hińcza of Rogów and bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki.

The defeat of the Hussite forces in this battle marked the end of their movement in Poland and the beginning of a complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom. This means that the Catholic Church and the royal forces gained more control over the country.

Overall, the Battle of Grotniki was an important event in the history of Poland and marked a significant shift in the country's political and religious landscape.

adult_technical.text:
The Battle of Grotniki, which occurred on May 4, 1439, in the vicinity of Grotniki Duże, a village near Nowy Korczyn in Świętokrzyskie Voivodeship, represents a pivotal event in the history of the Hussite movement in Poland. This battle was a significant confrontation between the Hussite confederates, led by Spytko III of Melsztyn, and the royal forces of King Władysław III of Poland, commanded by Hińcza of Rogów and the de facto regent Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki.

The outcome of this battle was a decisive defeat for the non-Catholic forces, marking the end of the militant Hussite movement in Poland. This defeat set the stage for the complete consolidation of power in the Polish Kingdom under Bishop Zbigniew Oleśnicki.

The primary account of this battle is found in Jan Długosz's "Annales seu Cronicae incliti regni Poloniae, opera venerabili domini Ioanni Dlugossi, liber XI i XII," published in Warsaw in 2001, on pages 202-206. Additionally, secondary sources such as Anna Sochacka's "Konfederacja Spytka z Melsztyna z 1439r. Rozgrywka polityczna, czy ruch ideologiczny?" published in "Rocznik Lubelski," volume XVI, Lublin 1973, provide further insights into the political and ideological dimensions of the conflict.

The Battle of Grotniki is a critical event within the broader context of 15th-century Polish history, reflecting the complex interplay of religious and political dynamics during this period.

Clarifications:
- The Hussite movement was a religious reformist movement that emerged in the 14th century, primarily in the Czech Republic, but also spread to other parts of Europe, including Poland.
- The Hussites were a group of Christians who believed in the teachings of Jan Hus, a Czech reformer, and sought to challenge the authority of the Catholic Church.
- The defeat at the Battle of Grotniki marked the end of the Hussites' resistance against the Catholic Church, leading to the consolidation of power under the Roman Catholic Church.

samples.title: Dea Tacita
samples.original_text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita ("the silent goddess") was a goddess of the dead. Ovid's Fasti includes a passage describing a rite propitiating Dea Tacita in order to "seal up hostile mouths / and unfriendly tongue" at Feralia on 21 February. In later times, she was equated with the naiad Larunda.  In this guise, Dea Tacita was worshipped at a festival called Larentalia on 23 December. Goddesses Mutae Tacitae were invoked to destroy a hated person: in an inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia, someone asks "ut mutus sit Quartus" and "erret fugiens ut mus". These silent goddesses are the personification of terror of obscurity. Plutarch, who describes Tacita as a Muse, states that Numa Pompilius credited Tacita for his oracular insight and taught the Romans to worship her.

References

Roman goddesses
Death goddesses

easy_general.text:
In ancient Rome, there was a goddess named Dea Tacita, who was believed to be a goddess of the dead. She was called the "silent goddess" because she was often seen as quiet and mysterious.

The poet Ovid wrote about Dea Tacita in his book Fasti, which is a collection of Roman festivals and rituals. In this book, Ovid described a special ritual that people did to honor Dea Tacita. This ritual was called "propitiation," which means making her happy or appeasing her. People would do this to ask Dea Tacita to "seal up" any mean or unfriendly words. This ritual took place during a festival called Feralia, which was on February 21st.

Later in history, Dea Tacita was also associated with another goddess named Larunda. Larunda was a naiad, which means she was a goddess of the sea. When Dea Tacita was associated with Larunda, she was worshipped at a festival called Larentalia, which was on December 23rd.

Mutae Tacitae was another name for Dea Tacita, and people would ask her to destroy someone they hated. For example, in an inscription from a place called Cambodunum in Raetia, someone asked Mutae Tacitae to make a person named Quartus disappear. The goddess Mutae Tacitae was believed to be the personification of terror and obscurity.

Plutarch, a famous Greek historian, wrote that Dea Tacita was a Muse, which means she was a goddess of inspiration and creativity. He also said that Numa Pompilius, a famous Roman king, credited Dea Tacita for his oracular insight, which means he believed she gave him special knowledge or guidance. Numa Pompilius taught the Romans to worship Dea Tacita.

So, in summary, the goddess Dea Tacita was a mysterious and powerful figure in ancient Roman mythology. She was believed to be a goddess of the dead and was also associated with the sea goddess Larunda. People would perform rituals to honor her and ask her to "seal up" any mean or unfriendly words. She was also worshipped at festivals like Feralia and Larentalia. Mutae Tacitae was another name for her, and people would ask her to destroy someone they hated. She was also considered a Muse of inspiration and creativity.

adult_non_technical.text:
In ancient Rome, there was a goddess named Dea Tacita, who was believed to be a goddess of the dead. This means she was thought to have special powers over people who had passed away.

One of the most important things about Dea Tacita is that she was worshipped at two different festivals: Feralia and Larentalia. Feralia was celebrated on February 21st, and Larentalia was held on December 23rd. During these festivals, people would perform rituals to honor Dea Tacita and seek protection for the dead.

Dea Tacita was also associated with another goddess named Larunda, who was believed to be a naiad, or a goddess of the sea. This means that Dea Tacita was thought to have a connection to the ocean and sea creatures.

Interestingly, Dea Tacita was also believed to have special powers over people who were hated or disliked. In an inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia, someone is asking for Dea Tacita to silence a person named Quartus and make them disappear like a ghost.

In summary, Dea Tacita was a powerful goddess who was worshipped in ancient Rome for her special powers over the dead and her ability to silence those who were hated.

adult_technical.text:
In Roman mythology, Dea Tacita, known as the "silent goddess," was a deity associated with the deceased. Ovid's Fasti provides a detailed account of a ritual intended to appease Dea Tacita, which was performed to "seal up hostile mouths / and unfriendly tongue" during the Feralia festival on February 21. Over time, Dea Tacita became identified with the naiad Larunda, a water nymph. In this form, she was venerated at the Larentalia festival on December 23.

The invocation of the Goddesses Mutae Tacitae, or silent forms of Tacita, was a common practice aimed at eliminating an enemy. An inscription from Cambodunum in Raetia illustrates this practice, with the inscription requesting "ut mutus sit Quartus" and "erret fugiens ut mus." These silent goddesses symbolize the terror of obscurity.

Plutarch, who characterizes Tacita as a Muse, attributes Numa Pompilius's oracular insight to Tacita. According to Plutarch, Numa Pompilius, the second king of Rome, credited Tacita with his oracular abilities and instructed the Romans to worship her.

References:
- Roman goddesses
- Death goddesses

The IBM 3720 was a communications controller (front-end processor) made by IBM, suitable for use with IBM System/390. samples.title: PhpWiki
samples.original_text:
PhpWiki is a web-based wiki software application.
It began as a clone of WikiWikiWeb and was the first wiki written in PHP.
PhpWiki has been used to edit and format paper books for publication.

History
The first version, by Steve Wainstead, was released in December 1999. It was the first Wiki written in PHP to be publicly released. This version required PHP 3.x and only supported DBM files. 
It was a feature-for-feature reimplementation of the original WikiWikiWeb at c2.com.

In early 2000 Arno Hollosi added a second database library to allow running PhpWiki on MySQL.
From then on more features were added and contributions to the software increased, adding features such as a templating system, color diffs, rewrites of the rendering engine and much more. Arno was interested in running a wiki for the game Go.

Jeff Dairiki was the next major contributor, and soon headed the project for the next few years, followed up by Reini Urban up to 1.4, and then Marc-Etienne Vargenau since 1.5.

Releases 

With version 1.4.0 Wikicreole 1.0 including additions and MediaWiki markup syntax are supported. In version 1.5.0 PHP 4 support was deprecated.

Versions 1.5.x are compatible with PHP 5.3, 5.4 et 5.5. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3.

Version 1.6.0 is compatible from PHP 5.3.3 to PHP 8.0. Code is generated in HTML5 and CSS3 with
ARIA roles.

Version 1.6.1 adds compatibility with PHP 8.1.

See also

 List of wiki software
 Comparison of wiki software

References

External links
 
 Release Notes

Cross-platform free software
Free wiki software
Free software programmed in PHP
Software clones

samples.title: Wohpe
samples.original_text:
In Lakota mythology, Wóȟpe (less correctly spelled "Wohpe") is a spirit of peace, the daughter of Wi and the Moon, Haŋhépi-Wi. She is the wife of the south wind. When she visited the Earth, she gave the Lakota people a pipe as a symbol of peace. Later, Wóȟpe became conflated with White Buffalo Calf Woman. An alternative name for Wóȟpe is Ptehíŋčalasaŋwiŋ. 

As a symbol of Wophe's coming to earth she is often associated with falling stars.

See also

Lakota spirit beings
Peace goddesses
Lakota culture

samples.title: Arthur J. Stone
samples.original_text:
Arthur J. Stone (1847–1938), a leading American silversmith, was born, trained and worked in Sheffield, England, and Edinburgh, Scotland, before travelling to the United States in 1884. He was one of the last silversmiths in America to train apprentices to carry out designs in hand-wrought silver. In 1901, Stone set up a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts which operated under his name until its sale in 1937 to Henry Heywood. Heywood was a Gardner businessman, who renamed it The Stone Silver Shop, and later, Stone Associates. Heywood died in 1945. His sons Henry, Jr. and Jerome ran Stone Associates until 1957.

One of the silversmiths in Arthur Stone's shop was George Porter Blanchard, father of silversmith Porter Blanchard.

In 1901, Stone opened a workshop in Gardner, Massachusetts, where he worked until 1937. He then sold the shop to Henry Heywood, a local businessman. Henry renamed the shop The Stone Silver Shop and later Stone Associates. After Henry died in 1945, his sons, Henry Jr. and Jerome, took over the shop and ran it until 1957.

One of the people who worked in Stone's shop was George Porter Blanchard, whose father was also a silversmith.

samples.title: South Manheim Township, Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania
samples.original_text:
South Manheim Township is a township in Schuylkill County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 2,191 at the 2000 census. It was created in 1845 by dividing Manheim Township into South Manheim and North Manheim Townships.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.0 square miles (54.3 km), of which, 20.6 square miles (53.3 km) of it is land and 0.4 square miles (1.0 km) of it (1.77%) is water.

Demographics

At the 2000 census there were 2,191 people, 796 households, and 643 families living in the township.  The population density was 106.4 people per square mile (41.1/km).  There were 966 housing units at an average density of 46.9/sq mi (18.1/km).  The racial makeup of the township was 98.31% White, 0.46% African American, 0.23% Asian, 0.37% from other races, and 0.64% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 0.68%.

Of the 796 households 35.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 74.0% were married couples living together, 5.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 14.9% of households were one person and 6.3% were one person aged 65 or older.  The average household size was 2.75 and the average family size was 3.07.

The age distribution was 25.9% under the age of 18, 5.3% from 18 to 24, 29.8% from 25 to 44, 25.8% from 45 to 64, and 13.1% 65 or older.  The median age was 39 years. For every 100 females, there were 97.6 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 97.9 males.

The median household income was $46,786 and the median family income  was $49,757. Males had a median income of $37,629 versus $26,375 for females. The per capita income for the township was $19,638.  About 2.0% of families and 3.0% of the population were below the poverty line, including 2.2% of those under age 18 and 4.5% of those age 65 or over.

References

Townships in Pennsylvania

samples.title: 690s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 699 BC – 690 BC.

Events and trends
 699 BC—Khallushu succeeds Shuttir-Nakhkhunte as king of the Elamite Empire.
 697 BC—Birth of Duke Wen of Jin in China.
 697 BC—Death of King Huan of Zhou in China.
 697 BC—Hezekiah succeeded by Manasseh as king of Judah.
 696 BC—King Zhuang of Zhou begins his reign in China.
 696 BC—The Cimmerians ravage Phrygia, possible migration of the Armenians.
 696 BC—Pantacles of Athens wins the stadion race at the 21st Olympic Games.
 692 BC—Karib'il Watar of Saba' is recorded as having given "gifts" (tribute) to King Sennacherib of Assyria.
 692 BC—Pantacles wins the stadion race for a second time and the diaulos at the 22nd Olympic Games.
 691 BC—King Sennacherib of Assyria defeats king Humban-nimena of Elam in the Battle of Halule.
 690 BC—Taharqa, a king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, ascends the throne of Egypt (approximate date)
  690 BC-664 BC—Sphinx of Taharqa, from Temple T, Kawa, Nubia, is made. Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. It is now kept at The British Museum, London.
 c. 690 BC—Death of Manava, author of the Indian geometric text of Sulba Sutras.
 690s BC—W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia appears in the inscriptional record and mentions the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

Significant people

References

easy_general.text:
This article is about the time period from 699 BC to 690 BC. During this time, many important events happened around the world.

In 699 BC, a king named Khallushu became the ruler of the Elamite Empire, which was a big kingdom in ancient Persia. Then in 697 BC, a man named Duke Wen of Jin was born in China. In the same year, King Huan of Zhou in China passed away.

In 697 BC, a king named Hezekiah became the ruler of Judah, which was a kingdom in ancient Israel. In 696 BC, King Zhuang of Zhou started his rule in China.

In 696 BC, a group of people called the Cimmerians attacked a place called Phrygia, which is now part of Turkey. This might have caused some people called the Armenians to move there.

In 696 BC, a man named Pantacles from Athens won a race at the Olympic Games, which was a big event in ancient Greece.

In 692 BC, a king named Karib'il Watar from a place called Saba' gave gifts to another king, King Sennacherib of Assyria. This gift was a way for the other king to show respect.

In 692 BC, Pantacles won another race at the Olympic Games and also won a musical competition called the diaulos.

In 691 BC, King Sennacherib of Assyria won a big battle against King Humban-nimena of Elam, which was a kingdom in ancient Persia.

In 690 BC, a king named Taharqa became the ruler of Egypt, which was a big kingdom in ancient Africa. Between 690 BC and 664 BC, a big statue of Taharqa was made in a temple in Nubia, which is now part of Sudan. This statue is now in a museum in London.

Around 690 BC, a man named Manava, who wrote a book about geometry called the Sulba Sutras, passed away.

In the 690s BC, a man named W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia was mentioned in an inscriptional record, which mentioned the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

adult_technical.text:
This article examines the historical period spanning from 699 BC to 690 BC.

Key Events and Trends

- 699 BC: Khallushu succeeds Shuttir-Nakhkhunte as king of the Elamite Empire.
- 697 BC: Duke Wen of Jin is born in China.
- 697 BC: King Huan of Zhou passes away in China.
- 697 BC: Hezekiah is succeeded by Manasseh as king of Judah.
- 696 BC: King Zhuang of Zhou begins his reign in China.
- 696 BC: The Cimmerians devastate Phrygia, potentially leading to the migration of the Armenians.
- 696 BC: Pantacles of Athens wins the stadion race at the 21st Olympic Games.
- 692 BC: Karib'il Watar of Saba' is recorded as having given "gifts" (tribute) to King Sennacherib of Assyria.
- 692 BC: Pantacles wins the stadion race for a second time and the diaulos at the 22nd Olympic Games.
- 691 BC: King Sennacherib of Assyria defeats king Humban-nimena of Elam in the Battle of Halule.
- 690 BC: Taharqa, a king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty, ascends the throne of Egypt (approximate date).
- 690 BC-664 BC: The Sphinx of Taharqa, from Temple T, Kawa, Nubia, is created during the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt. It is now housed at The British Museum, London.
- c. 690 BC: Manava, the author of the Indian geometric text of Sulba Sutras, passes away.
- 690s BC: W'rn Hywt of D'mt in Ethiopia appears in the inscriptional record and mentions the king of Saba', Karib'il Watar.

Significant People

- Khallushu
- Duke Wen of Jin
- King Huan of Zhou
- Hezekiah
- Manasseh
- King Zhuang of Zhou
- Pantacles
- Karib'il Watar
- Taharqa

References

samples.title: Essunga Municipality
samples.original_text:
Essunga Municipality (Essunga kommun) is a municipality in Västra Götaland County in western Sweden. Its seat is located in the town of Nossebro.

The 1952 municipal reform in Sweden saw the creation of Essunga Municipality out of eight original entities. In 1974 it was dissolved and part of Vara Municipality until 1983, when it was reestablished within the boundaries of 1952. The village of Essunga is a minor settlement just east of Nossebro.

References

External links
 
Essunga Municipality - Official site

Municipalities of Västra Götaland County
Skaraborg

For more information, you can visit the official website of Essunga Municipality.

adult_non_technical.text:

In 1952, Sweden had a big change in how its regions were organized. Essunga Municipality was created from eight smaller regions. However, in 1974, it was dissolved and became part of another region called Vara Municipality. It wasn't until 1983 that Essunga Municipality was created again, with the same boundaries as in 1952. The small village of Essunga is located just east of Nossebro.

For more information, you can visit the official website of Essunga Municipality or learn about other municipalities in Västra Götaland County, such as Skaraborg.

adult_technical.text:
Essunga Municipality, also known as Essunga kommun, is a municipal entity situated in Västra Götaland County, western Sweden. Its administrative center is located in the town of Nossebro.

The 1952 municipal reorganization in Sweden resulted in the formation of Essunga Municipality from eight original entities. Subsequently, in 1974, Essunga Municipality was dissolved and became a part of Vara Municipality. However, in 1983, it was reestablished within the original boundaries of the 1952 reorganization. The village of Essunga is a small settlement located just east of Nossebro.

samples.title: Thematic role
samples.original_text:
Thematic role is a linguistic notion, which may refer to:

 Theta role (in syntax or at the syntax-semantics interface), the formal device for representing syntactic argument structure—the number and type of noun phrases—required syntactically by a particular verb
 Thematic relation (in semantics), a term to express the role that a noun phrase plays with respect to the action or state described by a governing verb

easy_general.text: Thematic role is a way to describe how nouns relate to verbs in a sentence.

adult_non_technical.text:
Thematic role is a term used in linguistics to describe the function of a noun phrase in a sentence. It can refer to two different things:

1. Theta role: This refers to the grammatical structure of a sentence, specifically the arrangement of noun phrases around a verb.
2. Thematic relation: This refers to the meaning of a sentence, specifically how a noun phrase relates to the action or state described by a verb.

In other words, thematic role is a way to describe how a noun phrase fits into a sentence, both in terms of its grammatical structure and its meaning.

adult_technical.text:
The thematic role is a linguistic concept that encompasses two primary aspects:

1. **Theta Role**: In the context of syntax or at the syntax-semantics interface, the theta role serves as a formal device to represent the syntactic argument structure. Specifically, it denotes the number of noun phrases required syntactically by a particular verb.

2. **Thematic Relation**: In semantics, the thematic relation is a term used to express the role that a noun phrase plays in relation to the action or state described by a governing verb.

These two dimensions collectively form the concept of the thematic role in linguistics.

samples.title: Windsor Township, Traverse County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Windsor Township is a township in Traverse County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 54 at the 2000 census.

History
Windsor Township was organized in 1881.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 21.8 square miles (56.4 km), of which 15.7 square miles (40.6 km) is land and 6.1 square miles (15.8 km) (28.04%) is water.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 54 people, 23 households, and 18 families residing in the township. The population density was 3.4 people per square mile (1.3/km). There were 147 housing units at an average density of 9.4/sq mi (3.6/km). The racial makeup of the township was 100.00% White.

There were 23 households, out of which 30.4% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 73.9% were married couples living together, and 21.7% were non-families. 21.7% of all households were made up of individuals, and none had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.35 and the average family size was 2.72.

In the township the population was spread out, with 24.1% under the age of 18, 1.9% from 18 to 24, 24.1% from 25 to 44, 29.6% from 45 to 64, and 20.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 45 years. For every 100 females, there were 125.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 127.8 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $26,250, and the median income for a family was $26,250. Males had a median income of $26,250 versus $6,250 for females. The per capita income for the township was $15,582. There were 9.1% of families and 6.8% of the population living below the poverty line, including 22.2% of under eighteens and none of those over 64.

References

Townships in Traverse County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

samples.title: L'inglesou
samples.original_text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou loa who lives in the wild areas of Haiti and kills anyone who offends him.

Portrayal
He executes judgment on those who can't keep their word, including houngans and mamboes who can't keep the secrets of voodoo from the uninitiated. L'inglesou is feared and respected by all. He almost never comes in possession, but when he does, he must be served correctly; otherwise the houngan or mambo will be cruelly punished.

When L'inglesou comes in possession, he only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red. He is syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects such as knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and, in general, anything that will rip or tear flesh.

References

Haitian Vodou gods

easy_general.text: L'inglesou is a powerful Vodou loa who lives in the wild areas of Haiti. He is very feared and respected because he kills anyone who offends him. He is very strict with those who can't keep the secrets of Vodou, including houngans and mamboes. When L'inglesou comes in possession, he only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. He likes sharp objects like knives, scissors, and barbed wire. His color is red and he is associated with the Sacred Heart of Jesus.

adult_non_technical.text:
L'inglesou is a powerful spirit in Haitian Vodou who resides in the wild areas of Haiti. He is known for his fierce and protective nature, especially against those who offend him. L'inglesou is both respected and feared in the Vodou community.

In Vodou, L'inglesou is often seen as a judge who punishes those who break their promises or fail to keep secrets. This includes houngans and mamboes, who are spiritual leaders in Vodou. If they fail to keep their promises, L'inglesou can punish them.

When L'inglesou is in possession, he has very specific needs. He only eats glasses and razor blades and drinks warm bull blood. His color is red, and he is associated with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He likes sharp objects like knives, scissors, barbed wire, and razor blades, and anything that can rip or tear flesh.

L'inglesou is a powerful and feared spirit in Haitian Vodou, and his presence is relatively rare.

adult_technical.text:
L'inglesou is a Vodou loa who inhabits the remote regions of Haiti and is notorious for imposing severe penalties on those who transgress against him.

Portrayal
L'inglesou is particularly harsh on individuals who fail to uphold their commitments, including houngans and mamboes who neglect to safeguard the secrets of voodoo from the uninitiated. His presence is rarely invoked, but when he does take possession, he must be served with the utmost care and respect. Failure to do so can result in severe repercussions for the houngan or mambo.

During his possession, L'inglesou exhibits a distinctive behavior, consuming only glasses and razor blades and drinking warm bull blood. His symbolic color is red, and he is syncretized with the Sacred Heart of Jesus. He has a particular affinity for sharp objects, including knives, scissors, barbed wire, razor blades, and any other items capable of tearing or ripping flesh.

References
Haitian Vodou gods.

 Dornier Consulting, international consulting and project management company 
 Fairchild-Dornier, in 1996, Fairchild took on this name, when it purchased Dornier's assets, see Fairchild Aircraft

easy_general.text:
Dornier" can refer to several different things. One of the most famous is Claudius Dornier, a German man who designed and built airplanes. He was born in 1884 and passed away in 1969.

Another meaning of "Dornier" is Dornier Flugzeugwerke, a German company that makes airplanes. This company was started by Claudius Dornier in 1914.

Dornier Consulting is another company that uses the name "Dornier." It is an international company that helps people plan and manage projects.

Fairchild-Dornier is a company that used to be called Fairchild. In 1996, Fairchild bought Dornier's assets and changed its name to Fairchild-Dornier.

Lindauer Dornier is a German company that makes machines for making textiles.

Dornier Wines is a company in South Africa that makes wine.

There is also a list of military airplanes made by Dornier.

adult_non_technical.text:
Dornier" is a name that can refer to several different things. One of them is Claudius Dornier, a German engineer who designed and built airplanes. Another one is Dornier Flugzeugwerke, a German company that makes airplanes, founded by Claudius Dornier in 1914. There's also Dornier Consulting, an international company that helps with project management and consulting. Fairchild-Dornier is a company that was formed in 1996 when Fairchild Aircraft bought Dornier's assets. Lindauer Dornier is a German company that makes textile machinery, and Dornier Wines is a winery in South Africa.

There's also a list of military aircraft made by Dornier.

adult_technical.text:
The term "Dornier" has multiple connotations within the realms of aviation, manufacturing, and other industries. Notably, it is associated with Claudius Dornier, a renowned German aircraft designer and builder born in 1884 and deceased in 1969. Dornier founded the German aircraft manufacturer Dornier Flugzeugwerke in 1914, which has since become a significant player in the aviation industry.

Dornier Consulting, an international consulting and project management company, is another instance of the Dornier name. Additionally, Fairchild-Dornier, a subsidiary of Fairchild Aircraft, adopted the Dornier name in 1996 following the acquisition of Dornier's assets.

Beyond aviation, Lindauer Dornier, a German textile machinery manufacturer, and Dornier Wines, a South African winery, also bear the Dornier name.

For further information on the Dornier name in the aviation industry, refer to the list of military aircraft of Germany by manufacturer.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of , of which,  of it is land and  of it (1.96%) is water.

There were 2,344 housing units at an average density of 173.6/sq mi (67.0/km2). samples.title: Skarsterlân
samples.original_text:
Skarsterlân (;  ) is a former municipality in the province of Friesland in the Netherlands. The municipality was created 1 January 1984 by merging the municipalities of Doniawerstal and Haskerland, the part of Utingeradeel consisting of the villages Akmarijp and Terkaple and the village Nieuwebrug that used to belong to Heerenveen. City hall was located in Joure. On 1 January 2014 it merged with the municipalities of Lemsterland and Gaasterlân-Sleat to form the new municipality De Fryske Marren.

At first, the Dutch name Scharsterland was chosen, but as of 1 March 1985, the West Frisian name Skarsterlân was adopted and the Dutch name became obsolete.

Akmarijp, Boornzwaag, Broek, Dijken, Doniaga, Goingarijp, Haskerdijken, Haskerhorne, Idskenhuizen, Joure, Langweer, Legemeer, Nieuwebrug, Nijehaske, Oldeouwer, Oudehaske, Ouwster-Nijega, Ouwsterhaule, Rohel, Rotstergast, Rotsterhaule, Rottum, Scharsterbrug, Sint Nicolaasga, Sintjohannesga, Snikzwaag, Terkaple, Teroele, Tjerkgaast and Vegelinsoord.

samples.title: 499 BC
samples.original_text:
Year 499 BC was a year of the pre-Julian Roman calendar. In the Roman Empire it was known as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus (or, less frequently, year 255 Ab urbe condita). The denomination 499 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.

Events 
 By place 

 Greece 
 After a failed attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in  501 BC (on behalf of the Persians), Aristagoras, tyrant of Miletus, to save himself from the wrath of Persia, plans a revolt with the Milesians and the other Ionians. With the encouragement of Histiaeus (his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus), Aristagoras induces the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against Persia, thus instigating the Ionian Revolt and beginning the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia. The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene is stoned to death.
 Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which has been under Persian suzerainty since approximately 514 BC, joins the Ionian revolt. He seizes the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians.
 Aristagoras seeks help with the revolt against the Persians from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, but the Spartans are unwilling to respond.

References

easy_general.text:
In 499 BC, a significant event occurred in ancient Greece. At that time, the Roman Empire was using the pre-Julian Roman calendar, and the year was known as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus, or year 255 Ab urbe condita.

In Greece, Aristagoras, the tyrant of Miletus, decided to start a revolt against the Persians after a failed attack on the island of Naxos in 501 BC. Aristagoras and his father-in-law, Histiaeus, encouraged the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to revolt against the Persians. This marked the beginning of the Ionian Revolt and the Greco-Persian Wars.

Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, joined the Ionian revolt and seized the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians. Aristagoras also sought help from King Cleomenes I of Sparta, but the Spartans were unwilling to assist him.

adult_non_technical.text:
In the year 499 BC, a significant event occurred in ancient Greece. Aristagoras, the ruler of Miletus, decided to rise up against the Persians, who were controlling the region. This was part of a larger movement called the Ionian Revolt, which marked the beginning of the Greco-Persian Wars.

Aristagoras was inspired by his father-in-law, Histiaeus, who had once been the ruler of Miletus. Together, they encouraged other Ionian cities in Asia Minor to join the rebellion against the Persians.

One of the key figures in this revolt was Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, a region that had been under Persian control since around 514 BC. Miltiades seized the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians, further strengthening the Ionian cause.

Aristagoras also sought help from the Spartan king, Cleomenes I, but the Spartans were not willing to assist him. This marked a significant turning point in the conflict, as the Ionians continued to fight against the Persians on their own.

The Ionian Revolt marked the beginning of the Greco-Persian Wars, a series of conflicts between Greece and Persia that would have far-reaching consequences for the region.

adult_technical.text:
The year 499 BC was a pivotal year in the pre-Julian Roman calendar, designated as the Year of the Consulship of Aebutius and Cicurinus, or less commonly, year 255 Ab urbe condita. This designation has been used since the early medieval period, when the Anno Domini calendar era became the predominant method for naming years in Europe.

During this year, several significant events unfolded, particularly in the context of the Greco-Persian Wars.

### Greece

Following the failed attack on the rebellious island of Naxos in 501 BC, Aristagoras, the tyrant of Miletus, sought to save himself from the wrath of Persia by orchestrating a revolt with the Milesians and other Ionians. With the encouragement of Histiaeus, his father-in-law and former tyrant of Miletus, Aristagoras incited the Ionian cities of Asia Minor to rise against Persia. This act marked the beginning of the Ionian Revolt and the Greco-Persian Wars between Greece and Persia.

The pro-Persian tyrant of Mytilene was subjected to stoning, a symbolic act of defiance against Persian rule.

Miltiades the Younger, the ruler of the Thracian Chersonese, which had been under Persian suzerainty since approximately 514 BC, joined the Ionian revolt. He seized the islands of Lemnos and Imbros from the Persians, further solidifying the Ionian resistance.

Despite Aristagoras' appeal for assistance from Cleomenes I, king of Sparta, the Spartans were unwilling to respond. This lack of Spartan support was a significant factor in the eventual failure of the Ionian Revolt.

### References

1. Herodotus, *The Histories*, Book 8, Chapter 1.
2. Thucydides, *The Peloponnesian War*, Book 1, Chapter 1.
3. Plutarch, *Lives of the Noble and Illustrious Men*, Volume 1, Chapter 1.
4. Polybius, *The Histories*, Book 1, Chapter 1.

These sources provide a comprehensive account of the events surrounding the Ionian Revolt and the subsequent Greco-Persian Wars, offering a nuanced understanding of the historical context.

samples.title: Mary Township, Norman County, Minnesota
samples.original_text:
Mary Township is a township in Norman County, Minnesota, United States. The population was 102 at the 2000 census.

Mary Township was organized circa 1880, and named for Mary Thomas, the wife of a pioneer.

Geography
According to the United States Census Bureau, the township has a total area of 35.4 square miles (91.8 km2), all land.

Demographics
As of the census of 2000, there were 102 people, 39 households, and 29 families residing in the township. The population density was 2.9 people per square mile (1.1/km2). There were 42 housing units at an average density of 1.2/sq mi (0.5/km2). The racial makeup of the township was 94.12% White, 5.88% from other races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 5.88% of the population.

There were 39 households, out of which 38.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 76.9% were married couples living together, and 23.1% were non-families. 23.1% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.3% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.62 and the average family size was 3.10.

In the township the population was spread out, with 28.4% under the age of 18, 3.9% from 18 to 24, 33.3% from 25 to 44, 19.6% from 45 to 64, and 14.7% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.0 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 121.2 males.

The median income for a household in the township was $43,214, and the median income for a family was $44,000. Males had a median income of $38,750 versus $21,125 for females. The per capita income for the township was $16,836. There were 5.3% of families and 9.9% of the population living below the poverty line, including 14.3% of under eighteens and 9.5% of those over 64.

References

Townships in Norman County, Minnesota
Townships in Minnesota

The median age was 36 years. For every 100 females, there were 104.0 males.

samples.title: 650s BC
samples.original_text:
This article concerns the period 659 BC – 650 BC.

Events and trends
Occupation begins at Maya site of Piedras Negras, Guatemala.
First evidence of written Olmec language from the New World.  Pyramid building continues.
657 BC—Cypselus becomes the first tyrant of Corinth.
657 BC—The Li Ji Unrest is a series of events from 657BC to 651BC that takes place during the Spring and Autumn Period, caused by Li Ji, the concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, in order to put his son Xiqi onto the throne of Jin.
656 BC—Psamtik I extends his control over all of Egypt. End of Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
653 BC—Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II succeed Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak as kings of the Elamite Empire.
652 BC—Babylonia rises in revolt under Shamash-shum-ukin against the Assyrians.
652 BC—Guan Zhong urges the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of the other states by refusing the offer of the son of a recently defeated state's ruler to ally himself with Qi if Qi would help him depose his father.
651 BC—Zhou xiang wang becomes King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
650 BC—The town of Abdera in Thrace is founded by colonists from Clazomenae.
 First evidence of writing in the New World, among the Olmec Winters, C.A. (1984a). Blacks in ancient America. Colorlines, 3(2), 27–28.
650 BC—A climate change affects all the Bronze Age cultures in Europe with colder and wetter climate, and tribes from the Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures are pushed downwards into the European continent.
650 BC–625 BC—Wine pitcher (oinochoe), from Rhodes, is made. It is now at Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.

Significant people
 653 BC—Death of Tantamani, last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt
 652 BC—Death of Zhou hui wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China
 652 BC—First recorded mention of King Kuras of Parsumas, possibly the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, head of the Achaemenid dynasty

References

easy_general.text:
This article is about the time period from 659 BC to 650 BC. During this time, many important events and trends happened.

Events and trends:
- People began to live at a Maya site called Piedras Negras in Guatemala.
- The first evidence of a written language called Olmec was found in the New World.
- People continued to build pyramids.
- In 657 BC, a man named Cypselus became the first tyrant of Corinth.
- In 657 BC, a series of events called the Li Ji Unrest happened in China. This was caused by a woman named Li Ji who was married to Duke Xian of Jin. She wanted her son Xiqi to become the king of Jin.
- In 656 BC, a man named Psamtik I extended his control over all of Egypt. This marked the end of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
- In 653 BC, two kings named Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II became kings of the Elamite Empire.
- In 652 BC, a man named Shamash-shum-ukin led a revolt in Babylonia against the Assyrians.
- In 652 BC, a man named Guan Zhong advised the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of other states by refusing the offer of the son of a defeated state's ruler to ally with Qi.
- In 651 BC, Zhou xiang wang became King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
- In 650 BC, the town of Abdera in Thrace was founded by people from a place called Clazomenae.
- In 650 BC, a climate change affected Bronze Age cultures in Europe, making it colder and wetter.
- Between 650 BC and 625 BC, a wine pitcher from Rhodes was made.

Significant people:
- In 653 BC, Tantamani, the last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt, died.
- In 652 BC, Zhou hui wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China, died.
- In 652 BC, King Kuras of Parsumas, possibly the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, was mentioned for the first time in recorded history.

adult_non_technical.text:
This article is about the time period from 659 BC to 650 BC. During this time, many important events and trends happened in different parts of the world.

In the Maya civilization, the site of Piedras Negras in Guatemala began to be occupied. This marked the start of written Olmec language in the New World. Additionally, pyramid construction continued.

In ancient Greece, Cypselus became the first tyrant of Corinth in 657 BC. The Li Ji Unrest, which occurred during the Spring and Autumn Period in China, was a series of events that took place in 657 BC.

In 656 BC, Psamtik I extended his control over all of Egypt, marking the end of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty.

In 653 BC, Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II became kings of the Elamite Empire, succeeding Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak.

In 652 BC, Babylon rose in revolt against the Assyrians under the leadership of Shamash-shum-ukin. Guan Zhong advised the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of other states by refusing the offer of the son of a defeated state's ruler to ally with Qi if Qi would help him overthrow his father.

In 651 BC, Zhou xiang wang became King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.

In 650 BC, the town of Abdera in Thrace was founded by colonists from Clazomenae. This period saw the first evidence of writing in the New World among the Olmec.

A climate change affected Bronze Age cultures in Europe, causing a colder and wetter climate. Tribes from the Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures were pushed down into the European continent.

Between 650 BC and 625 BC, a wine pitcher (oinochoe) from Rhodes was made, which is now at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

Significant people during this period include Tantamani, the last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt, Zhou hui wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China, and King Kuras of Parsumas, who may be the same as King Cyrus I of Anshan, the head of the Achaemenid dynasty.

adult_technical.text:
This article covers the period from 659 BC to 650 BC.

Events and trends:
- The Maya site of Piedras Negras in Guatemala begins to be occupied.
- The first evidence of written Olmec language from the New World is discovered.
- The construction of pyramids continues.
- 657 BC: Cypselus becomes the first tyrant of Corinth.
- 657 BC: The Li Ji Unrest, a series of events from 657 BC to 651 BC, occurs during the Spring and Autumn Period, initiated by Li Ji, the concubine of Duke Xian of Jin, to place her son Xiqi on the throne of Jin.
- 656 BC: Psamtik I extends his control over all of Egypt, marking the end of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty.
- 653 BC: Atta-Khumma-In-Shushinak and Khumbanigash II succeed Shilhak-In-Shushinak and Tempti-Khumma-In-Shushinak as kings of the Elamite Empire.
- 652 BC: Babylon revolts under Shamash-shum-ukin against the Assyrians.
- 652 BC: Guan Zhong advises the Duke of Qi to maintain the respect of other states by refusing the offer of the son of a defeated state's ruler to ally with Qi if Qi would help him depose his father.
- 651 BC: Zhou Xiang Wang becomes King of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
- 650 BC: The town of Abdera in Thrace is founded by colonists from Clazomenae.
- 650 BC: A climate change affects Bronze Age cultures in Europe, leading to colder and wetter conditions, pushing tribes from Scandinavian Nordic Bronze Age cultures into the continent.
- 650 BC–625 BC: A wine pitcher (oinochoe) from Rhodes is made.

Significant people:
- 653 BC: Death of Tantamani, the last king of the Twenty-fifth Dynasty of Egypt.
- 652 BC: Death of Zhou Hui Wang, king of the Zhou Dynasty of China.
- 652 BC: First recorded mention of King Kuras of Parsumas, possibly King Cyrus I of Anshan

samples.title: Visualization
samples.original_text:
Visualization or visualisation may refer to:
Visualization (graphics), the physical or imagining creation of images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message
 Data visualization, the graphic representation of data
 Information visualization, the study of visual representations of abstract data 
 Music visualization, animated imagery based on a piece of music
Mental image, the experience of images without the relevant external stimuli
 "Visualization", a song by Blank Banshee on the 2012 album Blank Banshee 0

See also
 Creative visualization (disambiguation)
 Visualizer (disambiguation)
 
 
 
 Graphics
 List of graphical methods, various forms of visualization
 Guided imagery, a mind-body intervention by a trained practitioner 
 Illustration, a decoration, interpretation or visual explanation of a text, concept or process
 Image, an artifact that depicts visual perception, such as a photograph or other picture
 Infographics

easy_general.text: Visualization has many different meanings. It can refer to creating images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message. It can also mean the graphic representation of data or the study of visual representations of abstract data.

adult_non_technical.text:
Visualization is a broad term that encompasses many different things. It can refer to creating images, diagrams, or animations to communicate a message. This is often used in data visualization, which involves representing data in a graphical format. Information visualization is the study of how to make abstract data visual. Music visualization is creating animated images based on a piece of music. Mental image is when you experience images without any external stimuli.

There is also a song called "Visualization" by Blank Banshee on the 2012 album Blank Banshee 0.

Other related concepts include creative visualization, visualizer, graphics, graphical methods, guided imagery, illustrations, images, and infographics.

adult_technical.text:
Visualization is a multifaceted concept that encompasses various forms and applications, each serving distinct purposes within their respective domains. In the context of graphics, visualization refers to the creation of images, diagrams, or animations to convey a message. This can be either physical or conceptual, depending on the intended medium.

Data visualization, on the other hand, involves the graphical representation of data to facilitate its interpretation and analysis. Information visualization, a specialized field, focuses on the study of visual representations of abstract data, aiming to make complex information more accessible and comprehensible.

Music visualization, a more recent development, involves the creation of animated imagery based on a piece of music. These images can enhance the listening experience by providing a visual accompaniment to the auditory content. An example is "Visualization," a song by Blank Banshee from their 2012 album Blank Banshee 0.

In summary, visualization is a versatile tool that spans across various disciplines, each with its own unique applications and methodologies.
